title: Superintendent of Schools to Retire in 2024
author: Staff Writer
content:
Superintendent of schools to retire in 2024

 January 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 987
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — Superintendent of Kent County Public Schools, Dr. Karen Couch will be retiring at the end of the current school year, effective June 30. The announcement came at this month's Board of Education meeting. Board President Joe Goetz and Vice President Francoise Sullivan were re-elected to their positions during the Jan. 8 meeting as well.Couch said it has been an honor to collaborate with the exceptional team of administrators, teachers, staff and board members.
"Our collective commitment to the students and families of this county has been profound," Couch said. "Throughout my tenure, we achieved significant milestones, a testament to our collective dedication to excellence in education. This commitment consistently drove us to adapt and innovate, ensuring our students receive the best education possible."
Upon the delivery of Couch's announcement, Goetz, described the meeting as a "heavy night" with the weight of the superintendent's decision in the air.
"But you're not gone," Goetz told Dr. Couch. "And we'll have time to celebrate and we'll have time to reflect on where we've been and where we're going."
Goetz said everyone is a link in the chain driving KCPS, with many having come before them and more to follow. He said they will all do the best they can to continue providing students with a top-quality education.
"Working with you has been an absolute joy," Goetz said to Couch. "There's been a lot of ups and downs, but we'll celebrate all that as we move forward."
As a first step in the KCPS leadership transition, the Board of Education is holding a special meeting at 5:30 p.m. Tuesday, Jan. 23 to discuss the search for the next superintendent. The meeting will be held at the KCPS Administrative Building, 5608 Boundary Ave., Rock Hall.
Couch is retiring in the back half of her third four-year term as the superintendent of KCPS. Her most recent contract renewal was approved in the spring of 2021 for four years.
She first came on board at KCPS on July 1, 2013, having led a candidate field of nearly 20 applicants.
Couch was named the Maryland Superintendent of the Year in 2021. She made her mark on KCPS early, launching a technological revolution by bringing computers and smartboards into classrooms, greatly expanding teachers' and students' access to educational resources.
She built a collaborative environment in schools through fostering professional learning communities, which brought teachers together to share best practices to help reach all students.
She also made KCPS one of the first school systems in Maryland to adopt universal all-day prekindergarten, giving children an important head start on their education. "Amidst numerous budgetary challenges, including declining enrollment and limited resources,
we remained committed to prioritizing organizational improvements and addressing the diverse needs of our students and staff," Couch said.
She improved the school buildings themselves through targeted renovations, enhanced safety features like security vestibules and launching the planning process for a new middle school.
"During my tenure, we also executed a comprehensive six-year Facilities Strategic Plan,
revitalizing educational facilities untouched for over 25 years," she said. "Moreover, we successfully fulfilled preliminary state requirements for the construction of a new middle school while advocating for legislation to increase state funding participation for the project."
Sullivan, praised Couch's professionalism in the face of myriad challenges including tight budgets, declining student enrollment and the COVID pandemic. "You have helped our schools accomplish so much in the time that you've been here and it hasn't been easy," Sullivan told Couch. "You have always been professional and represented our schools really well, and I can only imagine how tough that probably was for some things."
Hailing from New Mexico, Dr. Couch previously served from 2001 to 2013 as the superintendent of the Moriarty-Edgewood School District, about an hour east of Albuquerque. In 2010, she was honored as the New Mexico Superintendent of the Year.
Couch moved to Kent County with a reputation for having turned that rural school district into one of the top-achieving in the state through a focus of continuous school improvement and the incorporation of research-based education programming.
She has likewise implemented similar strategies at KCPS, increasing the visibility and participation in the Career and Technical Education (CTE) program at Kent County High School, encouraging the growth of Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) programs and training elementary school teachers in the renowned Orton-Gillingham method of English language arts instruction.
Trish McGee, the longest serving among the current Board of Education members, was first elected the year after Couch's hiring. McGee covered the search process that saw Dr. Couch come onboard as the associate editor of the Kent County News.
Speaking at the Jan. 8 Board meeting, McGee said Couch paid out of her own pocket for travel from New Mexico to Kent County for one of her first interview visits. McGee said that showed just how prepared Couch was willing to go the distance to address the challenges faced by KCPS.
"I think every decision she ever made personally and professionally was really about how to move our school district forward," McGee said. "And I can't think of a greater legacy than something like that."
Couch's tenure at KCPS caps off a career in education that began in 1980 when she became a kindergarten teacher in the Las Cruces Public Schools in southern New Mexico. She was then employed by the Alamogordo Public Schools and rose through the ranks in that district from teacher to principal and, ultimately associate superintendent.
Along the way, she earned her master's degree and later received her doctorate in educational administration from New Mexico State University.
Couch said she is confident that KCPS will continue to nurture and inspire every child who walks through its doors and she eagerly anticipates hearing all those future success stories.
"As I begin a new chapter, I know that our work has laid a strong foundation for continued student success," Couch said. "The legacy of our efforts is not in the programs we've started or the facilities we've renovated, but in the lives of the students we've touched."

title: Blueprint Pillar Chairs Share Caroline's Progress
author: Connie Connolly
content:
DENTON — At the Jan. 9 meeting of the Caroline County Board of Education, several supervisors provided updates on progress towards meeting requirements of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a set of policies and dedicated funding seeking to transform several aspects of the state's public education system by 2026.Assistant Superintendent Dr. Tara Downes said the district has been receiving additional guidance from the Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) and Accountability and Implementation Board (AIB) since spring 2023.
As a result, required tasks have been "chunked out" over a more manageable timeline, and the pillar chairs are "actually ahead of schedule" with some aspects of the plan.
"The pillar chairs have been phenomenal in being proactive when it comes to the work," Downes said.
According to its website, "The Blueprint for Maryland's Future was passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 to transform public education in the state into a world-class education system. The Blueprint will increase education funding by $3.8 billion each year over the next 10 years, enrich student experiences and accelerate student outcomes, as well as improve the quality of education for all children in Maryland, especially those who have been historically underserved."
"The Blueprint really involves everything that we're doing on a daily basis," said Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons.
According to the Blueprint website, "The bold work of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future is organized into five distinct pillars." Each pillar has a set of objectives to help administrators and educators align instruction and community support to them and determine needed resources.
Pillar 1: Early Childhood Education
The main focus of Pillar 1 is the expansion of pre-kindergarten for three-year-olds and four-year-olds, said CCPS Supervisor of Instruction Elizabeth Saylor, who serves as Pillar 1 chair.
Of the 375 pre-K students enrolled as of Sept. 30, 58 are in pre-K three and 317 are in pre-K four. The main focus currently are Tier One families who are "up to 300% of the federal poverty level, or 319 students. As of Jan. 9, 395 students were enrolled in pre-K," Saylor said.
A challenge is the need for private daycare providers, who must follow Blueprint's criteria. Providing more qualified and more certified staff is another challenge both for Pillar 1 compliance and workforce development, an objective of Pillar 2.
"Making sure families and students are ready for kindergarten" is ultimately the focus of the pillar, Saylor said.
Pillar 2: High Quality and Diverse Teachers and Leaders
CCPS Supervisor of Human Resources Dr. Rob Willoughby addressed four objectives of Pillar 2, which focuses on the recruitment of high quality and diverse teachers and leaders.
Chesapeake College has been "a fantastic partner with us through the Maryland Leads" grant initiative, he said. The district recently signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Mount St. Mary's University, which offers a fully online bachelor's degree in elementary education.
Willoughby's group is looking at other ways of providing staff and enhancing qualifications, including encouraging National Board Certified Teacher credentialing.
Forty-eight teachers are currently in the process of pursuing that certification. "That is 10% of our teaching staff pursuing a really rigorous national certification," he said.
A Pillar 2 challenge includes a starting teacher salary of $60,000 by Blueprint's July 1, 2026, deadline.
"Our starting teacher salary this year $53,167, and … we're about $6,800 to the end," Willoughby said. "If you divide that over the three fiscal years we have, that means it needs to go up at least $2,278 (per year)."
Pillar 3: College and Career Readiness
Blueprint's third pillar focuses on students' college and career readiness.
College and Career Readiness Director Lindsey McCormick explained the progress being made towards complying with Pillar 3 of the Blueprint as the district works under interim standards. Students are assessed at the end of their 10th grade year and can choose a career pathway. The district offers 16 Career and Technology Education (CTE) pathways.
In addition to pursuing a college track and taking advanced placement courses, students can receive career counseling. Students in AP courses are now required to sit for the exams in the spring; the tests are paid for by the district.
"I am very pleased to say that this year through our MOU with the (Upper Shore) Workforce Investment Board, we have added one high school and one middle school career coach that are in the buildings five days a week working with students," McCormick said.
She said the district is growing the youth apprenticeship program and modeling it for businesses.
If students are not college and career ready, the district is working on a pilot program to provide supports, including online study, to help them meet state standards, McCormick said. Chesapeake College supplied data from the past three years that showed students' learning online was just as successful as classroom learning.
Pillar 4: More Resources to Ensure that All Students are Successful
Pillar 4 of Blueprint seeks to provide students with more resources that could help them succeed.
Supervisor of Instruction Christal Harkowa, one of the co-chairs for Pillar 4, updated the school board on multilingual learners.
The district has hired two multilingual learner family coordinators to work with Spanish- and Haitian Creole-speaking constituents.
"We have really been able to improve our communication with our families," Harkowa said. "They are very dedicated; they stay after (school), they attend all kinds of after school events, parent conferences when we need them for 504 or IEP (Individualized Education Program) meetings to make sure our parents understand what the needs of their students are and to be able to advocate and ask questions."
She said her goal by the end of this school year is to "identify MLL families for parent leadership opportunities."
To support MLLs in instruction and language acquisition, the district is providing ongoing professional development for teachers and instructional assistants while "being respectful of their planning time," Harkowa said. Another focus is helping students develop English proficiency in elementary school.
Supervisor of Special Education Erica McDonald discussed the objective of closing the achievement gap for students with disabilities.
The leadership team created a mission statement at the beginning of the current school year, provided Goalbook toolkit training and additional training to help teachers and co-teachers meet objectives and monitor "disproportionate identification and disciplinary practices."
"Our special education teacher specialists have really taken on the role of educational diagnosticians," she said.
A Blueprint objective is to "establish or enhance Community Schools in areas of concentrated poverty." Three CCPS schools — Federalsbury Elementary, Greensboro Elementary and Colonel Richardson Middle School — meet the criteria and have district coordinators assigned to them.
Supervisor of Student Services Nicole Fisher reported the Pillar 4 team is committed to evidence-based practices, but challenges facing the district are providing adequate behavioral health staffing and transportation.
Simmons said "As Blueprint ratchets up, all nine of our schools are going to qualify for Concentration of Poverty funding due to the FARMS (Free and Reduced-Price Meals) rates in all of our schools … in about another two or three years."
Pillar 5: Governance and Accountability
"Pillar 5 is what pulls together all of the other pillars," Simmons said, explaining that the pillar focuses on governance and accountability.
Two main areas of focus are the "stakeholder engagement plan" and Blueprint funding and resources which require "money following the students."
"Pillars 1 through 4 have done an incredible job of reaching out to community members, and they've got strong, robust teams that are getting lots of feedback," Simmons said, elaborating on the stakeholder engagement objective.
"There are shifts — monumental shifts in some areas — for the way that we're doing (Blueprint)," he said. "But eventually we'll stop talking about Blueprint, and we'll just be talking about what it is that we're doing that connects to the strategic plan, because the overlap will be there when it's closer to full implementation."
The complete report is linked in the Jan. 9 meeting agenda, where you can also watch the complete school board meeting at carolineschools.new.swagit.com/videos/294177
The MSDE Blueprint Implementation Plan is available at bit.ly/BlueprintPlanMSDE. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Superintendent Shares Schools' Budget Constraints with Commissioners
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Superintendent shares schools' budget constraints with Commissioners

 January 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 512
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County Public Schools officials shared good news and bad news with the Caroline County Commissioners at a Jan. 16 meeting.The good news: Caroline County Public Schools ended the year with a $3.25 million surplus.
The not-so-good news: The Blueprint for Maryland's Future unfunded mandate puts the fiscal squeeze on the budget and pandemic-based grant funding disappears in fiscal year 2025, officials said.
Chief Finance Officer Erin Thornton and Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons shared with the commissioners what they need to prepare for as the school district's budget planning continues.
"We have always been good stewards of the money and we're fiscally conservative, trying not to just spend money just to spend it, so we were prepared to end the year with money on the books," Thornton said.
The unassigned fund balance is currently at $9.5 million, "which is approximately 8.4% of our current operating budget," she said. "Our target range for a fund balance is one to 10%. So, we are approaching a high, which is where we want to be."
Commissioner Frank Bartz asked about maintaining support services salaries, something that he said is not addressed in the Blueprint.
"A lot of people in the county work for support services," he said. "I just want to make sure that they're taken care of."
"You're spot on," Simmons said. "The Blueprint addresses teachers only and leaves out two-thirds of our workgroup, and (it) does not take into consideration any support staff or administration. Required increases to salaries are … for the most part, to classroom-based teachers with kids on the workload."
Simmons said the Supportive Services Association is a negotiated employee group.
"Their contract was ratified to be closed from 2012 until next year, so that has been a closed contract with a required 1% in step every year, and then it's 1% in addition to whatever the teachers get. Their contract comes open next year for us to negotiate."
Simmons said the "biggest challenge that we're going to see this year" is the Blueprint formula's increase of 1.7% over last year's budget "when inflation is currently still running over 3%, and that factors in no increases in health insurance, which is probably 5% to 7% right now, we're hearing."
That percentage does not factor in any pay increase. Blueprint requires first-year classroom teachers to be earning $60,000 by fiscal year 2027.
"After this year, the budget increases roughly 5%," Simmons said. "We're sitting in a different position in our county than some of our colleagues are in others. … A lot of the larger systems are looking at significant cuts of teaching positions because (of) that 1.7% increase. It's a regressive budget no matter how you cut it, when it's only that much of an increase, and the cost of living is definitely a lot higher."
When COVID funding and (Maryland) Leads funding "dries up in September at the same time as we're getting a 1.7% increase, that's the perfect storm," Simmons said. "And again, we'll weather it for our staff. We'll figure it out. I really, truly believe we will. It's just going to be a really tough year." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Eastern Shore Delegation to Ask Governor for Cade Formula Restoration
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Eastern Shore Delegation to ask governor for Cade formula restoration

 January 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: General Assembly 
 
 482
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — At a meeting Friday, the Eastern Shore Delegation voted to send a letter to the governor's office asking that the Cade Funding Formula for community colleges be restored in a supplemental budget.Gov. Wes Moore's proposed fiscal year 2025 budget calls for the reduction of $22 million in Cade formula funding to community colleges in the state.
The Cade formula essentially ties state funding for community colleges to state funding for designated University System of Maryland institutions, according to the Maryland Association of Community Colleges.
Moore's proposal would reduce the Cade formula from 29% to 26.5%.
That percentage — the amount of funding community colleges receive from the state — is based on the funding given to public four-year institutions per full-time equivalent student.
At the Eastern Shore Delegation meeting, legislators were joined by the presidents of colleges that are located on the Eastern Shore, as well as MACC Executive Director Brad Phillips.
Phillips called rebasing the Cade formula a "budget word" for inequity.
"Look at it this way," he said. "If you're giving a student a dollar to go to a University System of Maryland or a four-year public institution, the policy goal is that 29 cents goes to community colleges. ... (with the reduction,) you're cutting community colleges out. You're still providing a dollar to our four-year friends."
Wor-Wic Community College President Deborah Casey told the delegation she had spent hours preparing a budget with an 11% cut.
"That's $1.5 million for Wor-Wic Community College," she said of the budget cut. "That doesn't work for us."
Casey said that she can't build infrastructure and carry Wor-Wic in the best direction with a budget reduction of this magnitude.
"And you're expecting and asking us, and holding us accountable to making sure we're meeting many needs of this community," she said. "Please help us get that full funding."
Phillips said Maryland's community colleges are up 8.3% in enrollment this year.
"So this is a cut that would actually stretch less funding to more students," he said.
During the meeting, both Casey and Chesapeake College President Cliff Coppersmith mentioned increases in enrollment at their schools.
Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico) said this increased enrollment is one reason why this formula change is concerning.
Del. Jefferson Ghrist (R-36, Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline), who made the motion to send the letter, said the Maryland Department of Legislative Services had given the House Appropriations Committee, which he is a member of, a list of possible cuts that could be made in order to restore the Cade formula to 29%.
"There's a lot of places that we can go to find money to restore that," he said.
Ghrist said getting the Cade formula restored in a supplemental budget, however, would make the job of the House Appropriations Committee easier.
"That way it'll be done before we start really getting down to work on the budget," he said. "That would make our jobs a heck of a lot easier on the committee." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Caroline Students Sign Apprenticeship Agreements
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Caroline students sign apprenticeship agreements

 February 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 350
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County Public Schools recently signed on to four youth apprenticeship agreements, three in the CCPS Technology Department and one in the Chesapeake Culinary Arts Center.Four students and their parents completed the paperwork necessary to finalize the apprenticeship agreement:
Evamarie Vargas Villacorta, North Caroline High School junior, and father Norman Vargas (CCAC)Dana Velasquez-Cifuentes, North Caroline High School junior, and father Ediberto Velazquez (Technology)Lawrence (Will) Johnson, North Caroline High School senior, and parents Billy and Roseann Johnson (Technology)Wilson Clough, Colonel Richardson High School junior, and his parents Michael and Amy Clough (Technology)
Supervisor of Technology Jason Wielgosz and CCPS Food Services Chef David Murray signed the employer portions of the agreement, and CCPS Youth Apprenticeship Coordinator Eric Cook signed on behalf of the CCPS Youth Apprenticeship Program.
"This is an exciting day for CCPS and a long time in the making," said Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons.
Simmons explained that former Assistant Superintendent Milton Nagel envisioned CCPS — the largest employer in Caroline County — engaging in youth apprenticeships, and he laid the groundwork for it to happen.
Simmons thanked Cook and school counselors for their diligence in bringing the program to fruition, and Wielgosz and Murray for working through the logistics for apprenticeships in their departments. He said it all came together with "the right opportunities with the right students at the right time."
CCPS's Director of College and Career Readiness Lindsey McCormick and school counselors Ann Ferkler, Jacqueline Holtzman and Jennifer Reed attended the meeting to congratulate and support their students.
The Maryland State Department of Education sent representatives Tracy Kyttle, director of apprenticeships and industry-recognized credentials; Jennifer Griffin, career programs and apprenticeship specialist; and Pamela Clay, career and technical education associate. Shay Lewis-Sisco, career coach from Dorchester County Public Schools also attended to learn more about the CCPS youth apprenticeship process.
More information about the Youth Apprenticeship Program may be found on the Caroline County Public Schools website. Local businesses interested in partnering with Youth Apprenticeship or students and parents interested in the program should contact Cook at cook.eric@ccpsstaff.org.
All event photos may be viewed on the Caroline Flickr page, www.flickr.com/photos/142694579@N05/

title: Talbot Board of Education Passes FY2025 Budget
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Talbot Board of Education passes FY2025 budget

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 301
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The proposed Talbot County Public Schools fiscal year 2025 budget is headed to the County Council for final approval.At a Talbot County Board of Education meeting Wednesday evening, board members voted to approve the budget and send it to the Talbot County Council.
The proposed unrestricted operating budget is $79.9 million dollars. This is a nearly $7.9 million increase from fiscal year 2024.
TCPS Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones said that while this seems like a larger increase than recent years, the increase is meant to offset a decrease in federal funding.
"This unrestricted budget coupled with the decrease in all of our federal programs nets to a 3.4% increase," she said.
This means that the district is asking for a total of 3.4% more money than it received for fiscal year 2024.
TCPS Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the district is losing $4.8 million in grant funding for fiscal year 2025.
TCPS Director of Communications Debbie Gardner said in an interview that the $4.8 million came from two COVID-19 related grants — the Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief Fund and the Maryland Leads grant.
The proposed capital budget for fiscal year 2025 is $12.1 million. Capital requests include the renovation and expansion of Chapel District Elementary School, the installation of a turf field at Easton High School, the replacement of auditorium lights at Easton High School, the installation of a basketball court at Easton Elementary School, an update to the stadium lighting at Easton High School and a playground replacement at St. Michaels Elementary School.
Next month, the proposed budget will be presented to the County Council. A public budget hearing, held by the County Council, is set for May.
Board President Emily Jackson thanked TCPS staff for "the huge lift" of preparing the budget.
"Go forth and get this passed," she said. "You can do it."

title: TCPS gives Blueprint updates
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
TCPS gives Blueprint updates

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 480
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Updates regarding the Blueprint for Maryland's Future were shared at a Talbot County Board of Education meeting Wednesday.The Blueprint is a plan, passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021, that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education across the state through increasing education funding by $3.8 billion each year over the next 10 years
Helga Einhorn, Talbot County Public Schools assistant superintendent for curriculum and instruction, gave updates at the meeting.
Einhorn said the Maryland State Department of Education has approved the College and Career Readiness Standard.
The approved standard — which determines whether students are mastering the standards necessary to prepare them for dual enrollment, advanced placement, post-secondary education and careers — offers two options.
First, students can be considered college and career ready if they have earned a high school grade point average of at least 3.0 and either earned an A, B or C in Algebra I or scored proficient or above on the Algebra I Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program.
The second way students can be considered college and career ready is if they score proficient or above on the English Language Arts 10 MCAP and Algebra I MCAP.
Einhorn said that if students do not meet the College and Career Readiness Standard, a team from the school will meet with that student and their family to develop a plan to get them on track.
Einhorn said this new standard will go into effect immediately. however, she said the interim standard will also remain in effect until July 1, 2025.
The interim standard states that students can be considered college and career ready if they achieve certain scores on either the Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for College and Careers, the early fall MCAP or the spring MCAP for both English 10 and either Algebra I, Algebra II or Geometry.
Another update Einhorn gave at the meeting is that the district has hired Sharon Gaskins as a strategic facilitator to support the district's efforts with the Blueprint.
"(Gaskins) has over 25 years in education and really has been a change agent working with organizations to ensure that they meet their goals," Einhorn said.
Einhorn said the district was able hire Gaskins using grant funding through the Blueprint's Accountability and Implementation Board.
Einhorn also gave an update on a report that the district will need to submit to the Accountability and Implementation Board and MSDE by March 15.
The report will detail the district's implementation of the Blueprint so far. Einhorn said this includes discussing any challenges the district might be facing with implementation.
This report is a way for the state to monitor that school districts are "able to transform" through reshaping and adapting new polices and practices that create a more equitable system, Einhorn said.
"I'm here tonight to assure you that we will meet that March 15 deadline," she said. "And I look forward to sharing some of the findings in that report." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: KCPS Calendar Approved with Post Labor Day Start
author: Staff Writer
content:
KCPS calendar approved with post Labor Day start

 February 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 284
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Kent County Board of Education has approved the calendar for the 2024-25 school year.As required by the State of Maryland, the approved calendar includes 180 instruction days for students. Two inclement weather days are built into the calendar.
The 2024-25 school year will begin with a staggered start.
Students in first through sixth grades and ninth-graders will begin school Tuesday, Sept. 3, the day after Labor Day. The first day for students in 10th, 11th and 12th grades is Wednesday, Sept. 4. Pre-kindergartners and kindergartners start school Thursday, Sept. 5.
Longer breaks during the year are Thanksgiving, Nov. 27 through Dec. 1; winter break, Dec. 21 through Jan. 1; and spring break April 17 to April 21.
Additional observed holidays are Martin Luther King Day Monday, Jan. 20; Presidents Day Monday, Feb. 17; and Memorial Day, Monday, May 26.
There are half days and days off in the calendar for staff professional development.
The last day of school is Thursday, June 12. That will be a half day for students.
The full 2024-25 calendar is available for view and download at kent.k12.md.us.
The calendar was developed with input from a committee led by Dan Hushion, supervisor of human resources, and comprising Kent County Public Schools staff and parents.
Staff and community input was sought through two online surveys throughout the development process.
Two drafts calendars were presented to the Board of Education at its meeting Feb. 12, both with post-Labor Day starts.
Survey results showed that of the 327 survey respondents, 75% preferred the calendar that ultimately received the Board of Education's unanimous approval during a meeting Feb. 12.
The other draft, which received 25% of the votes, had longer breaks throughout the school year with last day of school being Friday, June 20. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dorchester Superintendent Stepping Down March 1
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester superintendent stepping down March 1

 February 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 96
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent David Bromwell will be stepping down effective March 1.According to a statement from the Dorchester County Board of Education, although Bromwell's term ends June 30, he and the board have "mutually decided" that he will step down in March.
The news release states that the Board of Education will vote on an interim superintendent to serve the rest of Bromwell's term at the next Board meeting on Thursday.
Valerie Goff, DCPS communication and community outreach specialist, said in a text message that no other information is available at this time. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat. All rights reserved.

title: School Board Adopts 2024-2025 Calendar
author: Connie Connolly
content:
School board adopts 2024-2025 calendar

 February 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 743
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County students will be heading back to school before Labor Day this year.Offered two alternatives — a pre- or post-Labor Day start — the five-member Board of Education voted unanimously Feb. 6 to approve the pre-Labor Day calendar for the 2024-2025 school year.
English, Spanish and Haitian Creole translations of the calendar are posted on the Caroline County Public Schools website.
The school year start date is Wednesday, Aug. 28.
CCPS Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons presented the two calendars, along with results of a survey distributed to parents, teachers and staff.
While the current school year calendar began after Labor Day, the school board considered factors that mitigated against the later start, including the presidential election day, which necessitates closing schools Tuesday, Nov. 5, and Christmas falling on a Wednesday.
Fall sports practices will begin Aug. 14. Winter break will begin Dec. 20.
The calendar committee emailed a link to the survey Jan. 12 to over 5,400 parents, guardians and all CCPS staff members. A reminder email was sent Jan. 22, and the survey was closed Jan. 26. Some community members provided feedback, as well.
Although 75% of the 3,500 parents and guardians who responded favored a post-Labor Day start, 696 staff respondents, or 70% preferred a pre-Labor Day start.
Before reviewing the feedback, Simmons cautioned the school board, saying, "No matter what decision you make, you're going to make people upset, period. There is no perfect calendar, period."
Board member and retired Caroline County teacher Donna DiGiacomo favored the earlier start.
"So, one calendar starts Aug 28; the other starts Sept. 3, but the end date is just one day difference," DiGiacomo said. The adopted calendar gets "students in a routine quicker, and you have a shorter week when you start — you have three days, so everybody's not dead by Friday."
She said a 4-day first day of school "doesn't sound like a lot, but it's a lot."
Winter break begins with a half-day Friday, Dec. 20, and students returning to school Jan. 7.
"A hard shutdown over winter break for two solid weeks" would result in reduced heating costs and "significant savings" during "the hardest budget year we're going to have," Simmons said.
The post-Labor Day calendar would have had students returning Thursday, Jan. 2, 2025.
"This might not be a popular thing to say, but the reality is not a whole lot is going to get done on that Thursday and Friday," DiGiacomo said.
Other factors influencing the pre-Labor Day start were academic quarter dates and required parent-teacher conferences, which "we talked about ad nauseum," Simmons said.
Calling the process "wonky" and comparing it to a game of dominoes, Simmons explained the factors that prompted the calendar committee to go through "seven or eight drafts to get down to the two that made the most sense."
For example, the first quarter parent-teacher conference day will occur Nov. 5, even though it's election day, because the first quarter ends Nov. 8 and the conference day "has to fall before the first report card goes out, before grades are secured," Simmons said.
The adopted calendar has four inclement weather days built in. If they are not used, they come off the calendar.
State law, teacher contracts, mandatory conferences, state testing days, a set number of half-days, a mid-year transition day all dictate certain days off. Once all of the days off are built in, "it becomes a game of counting to 90 twice" to achieve a state-mandated 180-day school year, Simmons said.
DiGiacomo recommended surveying students next year and considering staggered starts for sixth grade and ninth grade students as they change schools.
"The pluses of draft two are just not as many as the pluses in draft one," said Rick Barton, president of the school board.
Although he liked "the idea of a longer break," school board Vice President Mark Jones was ambivalent.
"I honestly don't like either one of them, really," he said.
That ambivalence was reflected in the overall survey results, with 54% of all respondents preferring a post-Labor Day start and 46% going with the pre-Labor Day calendar.
Anticipating mixed reactions from the public and staff as well, Jones asked, "When do we want to hear complaints? Do we want to hear them right before the first day of school, or do we want to hear them after Christmas break? I think I'd probably rather hear them at the beginning of the year and get it out of the way."
To view the 2024-2025 CCPS school year calendar, visit www.carolineschools.org/page/ccps-school-calendar. The calendars are available in English, Spanish and Haitian Creole. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Thompson Voted Interim DCPS Superintendent
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Thompson voted interim DCPS superintendent

 February 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 636
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County Board of Education voted to appoint Jymil Thompson as interim superintendent of Dorchester County Public Schools at a Board meeting Thursday.Thompson, who has been assistant superintendent since September, will serve the final months of David Bromwell's term as superintendent.
"I'm humbled and I'm appreciative and I'm gracious that you have afforded me this opportunity," Thompson, who led the Board meeting Thursday, said. "I don't take this lightly, and I want to make sure that I do the best job that I can do."
Thompson stressed that this is not a one-person job.
"I need the whole district to help," he said. "I need the whole district to collaborate with each other."
Thompson — who came to Dorchester County in 2017, serving as assistant principal and then principal at Mace's Lane Middle School until 2020 — called Dorchester County "a diamond in the rough," saying that it will take a village to get the district moving in the right direction.
"Not saying that we aren't, and (that) we haven't made some progress," he said. "But I still think we've got some ways to go in order to make sure that we move from 23rd to the top-tier school district in Maryland."
On Feb. 16, the Board of Education announced that Bromwell would not be seeking reappointment when his term ends on June 30. A week later, on Wednesday, Feb. 21, the Board announced that Bromwell would be stepping down from his position, effective March 1.
Bromwell was officially appointed as superintendent in 2020 with a four year term. Before that, he served as interim superintendent for the district. In his time at DCPS, he has also served as a teacher in the district and as the principal of Cambridge-South Dorchester High School.
According to the Feb. 21 statement from the Board of Education, the decision for Bromwell to step down in March was "mutually decided" by him and the Board. In the Feb. 16 statement, the Board expressed gratitude to Bromwell for his years of service to DCPS.
Valerie Goff, DCPS communication and community outreach specialist, said Bromwell, who was not present at the Board meeting Thursday, had no comments at this time.
At the meeting, Board Vice President Susan Morgan acknowledged that the district is experiencing change "once again."
"But I do trust in our teachers, our administrators, our directors and, now, our interim superintendent, to keep us moving forward," she said. "Through everything we as a Board do, we always keep in the front of our minds what's best for all the children that we serve."
Board Member Chris Wheedleton said the search for the district's next leader can't happen without "recognizing the value of somebody who has given close to 40 years of service to the district."
"I want to thank Mr. Bromwell for his service and for what he has done," Wheedleton said.
Earlier in the meeting, Milton Nagel and Bill Middleton from the Maryland Association of Boards of Education presented on what to keep in mind when conducting a superintendent search.
Nagel told the Board that although it was not their reason for attending the meeting, MABE does conduct superintendent searches for its member districts.
"If the Board so desires to engage in that conversation about potentially having MABE do a search, we can certainly facilitate that," he said.
In a statement released later that night, the Board said it will begin the search for a new superintendent to take office July 1.
Toward the end of his remarks at the meeting Thursday, Thompson, who is also a board member of the Talbot County Board of Education, told the public that they will get mad at him.
"But I want you to also understand this — and I mean this from the bottom of my heart — that I'm always going to make the best decisions that I think are right for kids," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Jymil Thompson Resigns from Talbot County Board of Education
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Jymil Thompson resigns from Talbot County Board of Education

 March 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 311
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Jymil Thompson has resigned from his District 1 seat on the Talbot County Board of Education.At a board meeting Wednesday, Board President Emily Jackson announced the news of Thompson's resignation.
"Our wonderful Dr. Jymil Thompson has been forced to resign his seat on the board as he was appointed interim superintendent of Dorchester County Public Schools," she said.
Jackson said the board will miss him and wishes him the best of luck in his new position.
Last month, the Dorchester County Board of Education voted to to appoint Jymil Thompson as interim superintendent of DCPS. He is serving the final months of David Bromwell's term as superintendent. Bromwell officially stepped down from the position March 1.
Before taking on the role of interim superintendent, Thompson served as assistant superintendent for DCPS. He began that role in September.
Thompson, who was sworn in to the Talbot County Board of Education in December of 2022, said in an interview that he will miss working on the Talbot County Board of Education.
"I've always been on the other side of the fence in relation to education," he said. "But on the board side, I learned a lot about policy, budgeting and things of that nature. So it was a very valuable experience."
He said his experience as a board member is beneficial to his new role as interim superintendent, particularly when it comes to understanding the relationship between a superintendent and board of education.
TCPS Executive Assistant Charlene Gould said Thursday that the governor's office has been notified of the District 1 vacant seat. The governor's office is responsible for appointing someone to fill that seat until Thompson's term expires in 2026.
Thompson said his advice for whoever fills his seat is to listen.
"I just learned to listen," he said about when he started on the board. "And then make decisions after I listened to what people had to say." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland’s Teacher Shortage: Will the Blueprint’s Plan for Better Pay, Training Do Enough?
author: Aidan Hughes and Daranee Balachandar Capital News Service
content:
Maryland’s teacher shortage: Will the Blueprint’s plan for better pay, training do enough?

 March 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AIDAN HUGHES and DARANEE BALACHANDAR Capital News Service | Section: Business 
 
 1505
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fifth-grade teacher Melissa Carpenter works a 10-hour day on average during the week, and her job sometimes requires her to put in hours on weekends, too."I feel like teaching is one of those jobs where we go to work to do more work — to do work after work," said Carpenter, who teaches at William B. Wade Elementary School in Waldorf, in Charles County.
Carpenter's long hours are far from unique among Maryland's educators, as the state and nation grapple with a teacher shortage.
The U.S. Department of Education keeps a Teacher Shortage Areas database — and it found that for the current school year, Maryland was short of teachers in 28 subjects, which the state defines as "areas of certification." That's up from 17 five years earlier.
Some teacher certification areas — such as English as a second language, health science and special education — are short on teachers from pre-K through the 12th grade.
The Blueprint for Maryland's Future — a landmark state law reforming public education — aims to fix that problem by "elevating the stature of the teaching profession" through higher pay, better training and stronger recruitment efforts.
However, experts and educators have mixed views about whether that will successfully address the root causes of the shortage.
"Money is a huge help, but it's not everything," said Simon Birenbaum, director of grading, assessment and scheduling at Baltimore City Public Schools. "Human capital is the biggest issue, and money can help with that problem, but recruiting, training and retaining high-quality teachers and staff has to be the primary focus. No amount of money can compensate for a lack of highly-skilled educators."
Documenting the shortageMaryland's teacher woes follow national trends. The National Center for Education Statistics reported 86% of U.S. K-12 public schools faced challenges in hiring teachers for the current school year.
Amid the shortage, the Blueprint calls for hiring an unspecified number of additional teachers to ease the workload of classroom veterans.
"You hear a lot about the teacher shortage — and how are we going to implement all these Blueprint programs, which require additional staffing, when we have a teacher shortage?" asked Addie Kaufman, executive director of the Maryland Association of Secondary School Principals.
Shortages stem, in part, from the fact that teachers are leaving the profession. In Prince George's County, 1,126 teachers resigned between July 2022 and July 2023 — up from 989 the previous year, The Washington Post reported. Meanwhile, 625 resigned in Montgomery County Public Schools, up from 576 a year earlier.
Dorchester County experienced the highest attrition rate in Maryland during the 2021-22 school year at 18%, according to a Department of Education report.
"I used to never have people just quit in the middle of the year," said Dorchester County Superintendent Dave Bromwell, who recently retired. "The pandemic told some people, you know what? If you're not happy, move on."
All those factors end up impacting teachers like Carpenter. She said her grade level saw an influx of students, with around 30 students in her own fifth grade class this year.
"Our class sizes are growing, and we don't have the support in place to help some of our struggling learners," she said.
'teaching isn't approved'Schools are suffering from a long-term decline in the number of people interested in becoming teachers.
That decline has been ongoing since the mid-'70s, "but it gets worse and worse and worse, year over year," said Mike Hansen, an education policy expert at the Brookings Institution.
According to the State Department of Education, 9,134 people were enrolled in teacher preparation programs in the state in 2012. That number plummeted by about half by 2017, but rose to 6,037 by 2020.
Why is teaching becoming less appealing as a career? Zid Mancenido, a lecturer at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, has been studying that issue.
"One of the major findings of my research has been that people are taught over time that teaching isn't a great career," he said in a 2022 interview on the school's website. "There are all these tiny interactions they have over their lifetime that give them this feeling that teaching isn't approved, that they should be aspiring to other careers that might be more prestigious or well-paid."
Amid the shortage, many schools hire less-credentialed "conditional" teachers — those who have not yet received their professional certifications. Maryland's issuance of conditional certificates more than doubled between 2018 to 2022, a state Department of Education report said.
In Charles County, where Carpenter works, 12.4% of all teachers held conditional certificates by 2021 — a rate only surpassed by Baltimore City (13.4%) and Prince George's County (14.3%).
Carpenter said experienced teachers are leaned on to help the conditional hires.
"Which would be fine if you had one or two teachers who needed that support. But we have a massive amount of teachers who are conditional right now," she said.
The Blueprint's pay bumpIn order to address the teacher shortage, the Blueprint provides a number of measures that lawmakers hope will encourage people to become teachers and ensure that existing ones don't leave for more lucrative out-of-state positions — or exit the profession altogether.
A key Blueprint initiative increases teacher pay to a minimum of $60,000 by 2026. In some counties, that means a nearly $15,000 pay bump for new teachers.
David Larner, chief human resource and professional development officer at the Howard County Public School System, said the pay raise will attract teachers from other states and build up Maryland's teacher workforce.
"If our salaries are higher than salaries in surrounding states … then candidates are more likely to come," Larner explained.
However, Hansen, of the Brookings Institution, expressed skepticism about the likely impact of the measure on the state's teacher shortage.
Hansen argued that rather than a universal rise in minimum salary levels, money should be targeted where it's needed the most — attracting teacher talent in high-need schools and specialized fields like STEM subjects and special education. He also highlighted research that suggests salary is just one of many factors that can lead to teacher attrition.
"I think we need to be paying teachers more — I don't think paying a $60,000 minimum wage is the way to do it," he said.
Boosting careers and diversityThe Blueprint also aims to improve teacher quality by encouraging educators to obtain additional training.
The plan provides for a salary increase of $10,000 for teachers who become National Board Certified, an advanced teaching credential that fewer than 6% of Maryland teachers held at the start of 2023, according to the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards. Teachers in high-need areas may see their annual salaries increase by up to $17,000 by becoming certified.
"We want to professionalize the career of teaching, and I think that is absolutely what we should be doing," said Stephanie Novak Pappas, principal of the Holabird Academy, an elementary and middle school in Baltimore.
However, Hansen questioned the Blueprint's emphasis on National Board certification.
"We don't have a lot of evidence that actually getting your NBC makes you a better teacher," Hansen said.
The Blueprint also calls on school districts to create a diverse workforce. The Accountability and Implementation Board — which oversees the Blueprint — will evaluate those efforts.
A diverse workforce has significant benefits, according to David Blazar, an education policy expert at the University of Maryland.
Blazar said that increasing the share of Black teachers has "exceptionally large impacts on students' short and long term outcomes," he said. "I'd say some of the largest impacts I've seen across all of the educational intervention literature."
But maximizing the benefits of a more diverse workforce will be complicated, Blazar said. Even if the state's teacher workforce came to match the demographics of its students, there would likely still be "clustering of Black teachers within certain districts, and within certain schools within districts," he said.
Hansen echoed those concerns, and said that teachers nationwide remain even more racially segregated than students. Rather than aiming to make the teachers within individual districts reflect the exact racial demographics as their students, he suggested that policymakers should "maximize exposure and access to a diverse set of teachers for every student" across different regions.
A work in progressBeyond the Blueprint, the General Assembly last year passed the Maryland Educator Shortage Reduction Act, which requires the state to set recruitment goals for teacher education programs, creates an alternative teacher prep program for early childhood educators and establishes a $20,000 yearly stipend for eligible student teachers.
Gov. Wes Moore, who proposed the legislation, said upon signing it that it is intended to place "world class teachers in every classroom."
Carpenter, the Charles County teacher, said future changes may be necessary, too.
"We will have new students next year, and they will [have] different needs. So we need to make sure that we are constantly evolving," she said.
Meanwhile, Sparkle Jefferson, an assistant principal at Flintstone Elementary School in Prince George's County, stressed that reinforcing the teacher workforce is key to the Blueprint's overall success.
"It lands in the hands of our educators, and if we don't have educators who are highly qualified or able to do the work, then the Blueprint work would never get accomplished," she said.
Local News Network Director Jerry Zremski contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

The Blueprint for Maryland’s Future and the Educator Shortage Reduction Act propose higher salaries, expanded training, and recruitment incentives. Teachers and administrators, like Melissa Carpenter and Simon Birenbaum, question whether these measures will suffice.

title: Board of Education Member Donna DiGiacomo Resigns
author: Tom McCall
content:
Board of Education Member Donna DiGiacomo resigns

 March 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: News 
 
 547
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — After three years and four months in office, Caroline County Board of Education member Donna DiGiacomo has resigned, citing concerns following a back-and-forth between DiGiacomo and Superintendent Derek Simmons at the board's March 5 meeting.She emailed her resignation to the Maryland Superintendent of Education Monday.
"My problem on the board is I care about the students and I care about teachers," she said in an interview Monday afternoon. "I got a lot of pressure to make it look like we all agreed. But the thing that got me that I finally said I cannot in any way, shape or form be associated with was at the March 5 meeting."
"The superintendent called some employees minions. I was like 'did you just say minions? Mindless people who just do what you say?'" she said.
The exchange between Simmons and DiGiacomo, which can be viewed in the recorded meeting on the board's website, resulted from a conversation in which the superintendent discussed the district's upcoming switch from Apple laptops to Google Chrome ones.
He talks about how many people it took to get the computers ready for summer.
"For getting the devices ready for summer, we don't quite need quite the large numbers of minions, as the devices come in more ready to go out the door. So it helps us on that end as well," he said in the meeting.
DiGiacomo asks, "Minions?... I guess just the word kind of offends me… 'Minions' offends me. It did offend me."
Simmons said, "I didn't mean to offend you. I was thinking Minion movies."
Members of the board laughed.
She said, "A minion is a person that does what they, without thinking. That is all. It is derogatory."
Simmons responded, "Wasn't meant to be offensive, Mrs. DiGiacomo."
She said, "I don't think anyone would be appreciative of that," before the board returned to their initial discussion.
Simmons did not directly respond to a request for comment about the exchange, though the school district did issue a press release following DiGiacomo's resignation.
DiGiacomo's term was supposed to end Nov. 30. She came to the position after 20 years as a high school English teacher.
"The main statement I am trying to make by resigning eight months early is I do not want anyone to think that I condone what is going on," she said.
"... I am not trying to start trouble. I just want people to know that I really did try my best," she said. "But I can't be a part of something that doesn't respect the employees. Calling people minions is not respectful. I don't want people to think I quit. It is a moral thing for me."
"I think the people who voted for me have the right to know why I made that decision," she said.
The Board of Education's statement on the resignation thanks DiGiacomo for her time on the board.
In it, Board President Richard Barton stated, "On behalf of the Caroline County Board of Education, we thank Mrs. DiGiacomo for the time she spent on the board and appreciate her service to the staff and students of Caroline County Public Schools."
The board also said, "regarding the vacancy this resignation creates, the board will discuss options as they pertain to Maryland law with the board attorney at their next meeting."
The next meeting is on April 2 at 6 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the resignation of a member of a county Board of Education, directly relating to school governance and policy, which falls under the Education category.

summary: On March 27, 2024, Caroline County Board of Education member Donna DiGiacomo announced her resignation, effective immediately. Superintendent Derek Simmons and Board President Richard Barton thanked her for years of service, noting the board will appoint a replacement per Maryland State Department of Education guidelines.

title: DCPS Enters Agreement to Increase Professional Development for Administration
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
DCPS enters agreement to increase professional development for adminstration

 April 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 327
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County Board of Education approved a purchasing agreement at a board meeting March 25 that will bring coaching and professional development support for district administrators.Specifically, the agreement states that Creative Leadership Solutions will hold a kick-off event in the summer and offer seven on-site professional learning sessions and eight on-site coaching days, according to meeting documents.
Dorchester County Public Schools will use Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief III funding to pay the nearly $138,000 for three years of the organization's services.
At the board meeting, Interim Superintendent Jymil Thompson said the DCPS executive team expects all its principals to become "great instructional leaders," but not enough professional development has been provided to those leaders.
Thompson said Creative Leadership Solutions will provide instructional leadership and help the district improve its tier one instruction over a three-year period. In education, tier one instruction is instruction given to the entire classroom.
"Right now we see the deficit across the district as it relates to tier one instruction," Thompson said. "And this is the way that we think we're going to improve our tier one instruction, by providing professional development to our leadership."
Thompson said the district has to put its money where its mouth is.
"We're trying to shift our mindset to put instruction first," he said. "And we believe that this is the way to do it: By training our staff and training our leadership to be instructional leaders."
Thompson said Creative Leadership Solutions will cater their services to what the district needs.
At a Cambridge City Council meeting later that day, Thompson gave a presentation to the council on the overall picture of the school system where he talked about the need for improving tier one instruction. He spoke about the importance of having a school calendar that allows the district to provide time for professional development.
"We can't expect teachers to be good at their craft if we're not continuously training them to be better at their craft," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a school board's agreement to fund professional development for district administrators, which directly relates to education policy and administration.

key_people: Jymil Thompson — Interim Superintendent, Dorchester County Public Schools
summary: On April 2, 2024, Dorchester County Public Schools, led by interim superintendent Jymil Thompson, signed an agreement with the Dorchester County Board of Education to expand professional development for administrators, aiming to strengthen leadership and improve school performance.

title: Talibah Chikwendu Appointed to Dorchester Board of Education
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Talibah Chikwendu appointed to Dorchester Board of Education

 April 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 293
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Cambridge — Talibah Chikwendu has been appointed by the Dorchester County Council to fill the open District 2 Dorchester County Board of Education seat.A graduate of Dorchester County Public Schools, Chikwendu said she has been involved with DCPS in some capacity her entire life. She became a school librarian 10 years ago and has served as a high school teacher for the past five years. She said she applied for the vacant seat because she saw it as an opportunity to continue to serve the school system.
"It is important, with a lot of the things that are coming up for Dorchester County Public Schools, that District 2 has a voice in making those decisions," she said. "Because, by and large, most of the school children in the county are in this district."
In a press release, the County Council said it believes the board will benefit from Chikwendu's institutional knowledge from working in the district.
Chikwendu was appointed to fill the rest of Theresa Stafford's term, which ends in 2026. Stafford, who was elected to the Board of Education in 2022, passed away in mid-December after battling cancer for several years.
Chikwendu said her first order of business as a board member is to figure out exactly where the district is right now.
"I mean at this point in the year, we are in the middle of budget season, we are about to end the school year," she said. "At this point, it's a function of acclimating myself to just what is happening and where I'm needed."
Chikwendu said she wants to be of service to the community. She said she doesn't do things without a reason and knows how to be transparent.
"I'm hoping I can use those things to bring value to my community," she said.

title: Talbot Board of Education/July 16
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Education/July 16

 July 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 164
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Board of Education took the following actions at its July 16 meeting:Approved the new Talbot County Public Schools strategic plan, which lays out the district's goals and visions for the next five years.Introduced policy updates on the employee code of conduct and video recording in schools. The policy updates weren't eligible for a vote on July 16.Heard from Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones on the district's search for a new retirement plan. Jones said TCPS currently has seven different retirement plan providers, an "overwhelming" number. She said the district hopes to narrow it down to one, interviewing finalists in August and potentially rolling it out this October.Reviewed data from the 2024-2025 school year in the following areas: literacy test scores, math and English test scores and student and staff climate surveys.Heard an update on the construction of a staff health center on Idlewild Avenue. Jones said work is expected to finish around September and could open in October.

title: No Primary Election to be Held for Caroline County Board of Education Seats
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
No primary election to be held for Caroline County Board of Education seats

 April 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 138
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Caroline County's Board of Education election for District 2 will go straight to the 2024 General Election ballot and will not be a part of the primary election on May 14.According to the Caroline County Board of Election, this contest will not be on the primary election ballot because less than three candidates have filed for candidacy.
Candidates for local county offices file candidacy in the Election office. This contest appears on the Caroline County ballot along with the State and Federal offices that are up for election.
The sole candidate is Stefanie Johnson, who runs under the committee Stefanie Johnson for Caroline BOE. Caroline County has two Board of Education seats up for vote this year.
Caroline County residents can vote on November 5, 2024 either in person during early voting or on election day or by mail.
