Assistant Superintendent Jodi Colman, with Board leaders Talibah Chikwendu and Sheri Hubbard, said the program aims to ensure continuity of instruction.

title: Lack of Funding a 'Recipe of Frustration'
author: Staff Reports
content:
Lack of funding a 'recipe of frustration'

 August 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Reports | Section: News 
 
 1210
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Upwards of 200 individuals gathered at the Queen Anne's County Public Schools Board of Education building in solidarity of Queen Anne's County Education Association members raising their voices against proposed employee layoffs as the board held a closed executive session Aug. 20."We teach our students to collaborate and talk together, well, let's walk the walk," Education Association President Cecilia Mitchell said about the assembly.
Marching from Centreville Elementary School to the building at 202 Chesterfield Avenue, teachers, parents, students, supporters and members of the education union wore "red for ed" against cuts proposed in an effort to balance the district's budget.
According to the meeting's agenda on the board website, the closed session was held "To consult with counsel to obtain legal advice; To conduct collective bargaining negotiations or consider matters that relate to the negotiations."
Creating "joyful noise," as Mitchell put it, the rally attendees carried signs of support for school staff and verbally chanted against cuts. In front of the building, participants inscribed chalk messages on the sidewalk.
"People love the school systems here. The future lives in that building," Mitchell said, pointing to nearby Centreville Elementary.
"It's deeply frustrating that QACPS wants to cut some of our lowest-paid educators who work directly with our students, and at the start of the year, no less. We don't know how many people, or what job titles," Mitchell said in a statement ahead of Tuesday's rally. "There are any number of ways to deal with budget problems, but not if you won't talk to your educators."
According to a press release issued by the Association, they were notified on Aug. 14 of the potential layoffs of "an unknown number of QACPS support staff, who are among the lowest-paid employees in QACPS."
The Association seeks the superintendent and school board to address the budget shortfall before pushing it on to employees, Mitchell said.
The layoffs announcement came after the school district asked Queen Anne's County educators on Aug. 12 to accept five unpaid furlough days during the 2024-25 school year.
The educators association said they asked for documentation to justify the furloughs and were "sent no response nor documentation, and then refused to meet on any of the dates offered to discuss the matter."
Seeking budget transparency, the Association has filed a formal information request, with questions including where the money was going, and what is being done that doesn't involve cutting positions, according to Mitchell.
"So, we just have two questions for Dr. Saelens. First, why are you asking us to cut our salaries if you won't ask the county for additional funding, and second, why won't QACPS answer our questions about the budget crisis like the law requires?" Mitchell said.
Other measures needed to be exhausted first before the proposed Reduction In Force and layoffs of essential support staff, she said.
Mitchell highlighted the effect layoffs would have on the livelihood of support staff, who ensure the optimal running of the school, while making up the smallest portion of school system employees, "And they make the least amount of money," she said.
According to a statement from Superintendent Patricia Saelens, the school system sought to balance the budget through attrition.
Saelens noted the "severely underfunded Blueprint For Maryland's Schools, coupled with overall inflation has created a recipe of frustration" — a deficit that Queen Anne's County is not alone in facing, she said.
As a result of that lack of attrition there is still a current shortfall of two million dollars. Saelens wrote in a letter to staff on Aug. 19, "This summer, we have worked to do a detailed budget analysis and determine what could be cut to put those funds into salaries. We have identified numerous items to help reduce the budget shortfall. We will cut scanning, tutoring and locally funded conferences. We will reduce our legal line item. We will cut school block grants by 10%."
Additionally Saelens wrote the district is canceling the Cenergistic Energy contract, and repurposing the staff tuition reimbursement line. "While these measures will help, it is simply not enough to balance the budget," she stated, "Under Maryland Law, a local board of education is prohibited from carrying a budget deficit."
Saelens contends the district met with the union on July 18 and 31 to discuss a retirement incentive and potential furlough days. The retirement incentive was not successful as only two employees took advantage, still leaving them under the attrition necessary to balance the budget.
Together with the union, Saelens said they selected dates that purposely would not impact student days. "We also determined the proposed furlough days would be for all employee units, including the superintendent and all administrative staff. These proposed five days would have avoided the need to reduce any member of our staff," she said, "We know that each of our employees are vital to the successes of students. It was our intention to keep our staff whole."
Saelens said they provided the union with all the information they requested within 24 hours, meeting again on Aug. 6 and sharing a draft MOU regarding proposed furlough days.
Given the upcoming start of the school year, we requested that they provide us with their decision by Aug. 12, Saelens said. The union responded in writing informing leadership that they "formally decline Queen Anne's County Public Schools proposal of furlough days for the 2024-2025 school year".
As a result, Reduction In Force (RIF) letters were issued on Aug. 14, in accordance with the RIF process outlined in the negotiated agreement, Saelens concluded.
Whether proposed furlough dates or RIF, the teacher's union has a ratified contract based on an offer the BOE presented to the union that was accepted, according to Mitchell.
"We must take care of each other," she said.
Showing support for fellow union members and district bus drivers, Tony Mansfield stated the rally was a "good start" and sought collaborative efforts to come up with a budget that does not include reductions and a solution that honors the contract ratified in June.
School psychologist Julie Rock, of Matapeake Middle School and Kent Island Elementary School, stated it was her job to advocate for students and the rally highlighted the invaluableness of the various support needed within the walls of the schools. "Right now, the students that need us the most are going to be losing the support," Rock said.
Standing alongside QACEA was Lori Hrinko, President of Cecil County Classroom Teachers Association. "This isn't about you wanting more, this is about what's right for our kids," Hrinko told the crowd.
Hrinko encouraged everyone to be involved in their school districts, as students represented the future generations.
QACEA is a local affiliate of the Maryland State Education Association (MSEA), which in turn is an affiliate of the National Education Association, and Mitchell voiced appreciation of the organizations' support.
Working to promote change through action, Mitchell hoped to inspire students of all ages and showcase that change is possible.
Mitchell noted issues cannot be addressed by avoiding dialog or shifting blame, "Problems can only be solved with conversation, creative solutions and direct contact," she said.
Moving forward, Mitchell seeks to have all groups unite with the same underlying goal: identify the best interests for the good of students. "[Working] together; real numbers, real decisions," Mitchell said.
More information about QACEA can be found at https://qacea.org.
The Board of Education will next meet for a regular meeting Sept. 4 at 6 p.m.

title: TCPS Superintendent Addresses Mailers Questioning District Spending
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
TCPS superintendent addresses mailers questioning district spending

 August 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 484
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Many county residents opened their mailboxes earlier this month to a mailer questioning Talbot County Public Schools for its spending rates per student.The 14-by-8.5-inch flyers are two-sided. One side includes a screenshot from the U.S. News & World Report's web page on the district's finances. "And what are taxpayers getting for all this money?" the flyer reads.
On the other side, it reads: "Despite all of this spending, math proficiency for students in Talbot County stands at a dismal 17.2%, well below the state average. It doesn't add up! With all this taxpayer money being spent, what are they teaching our kids?"
Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi briefly addressed the mailers during an Aug. 14 Board of Education meeting.
"There (were) inaccurate monetary figures on that card, number one," Pepukayi said. "Yes, I will say we have work to do in the area of math, and that's one of our priorities."
The superintendent said there will be a Board of Education work session in September to show recent state testing data that is currently embargoed. The state average math proficiency rate for the 2022-23 school year was about 25%, according to the Maryland Department of Education.
Return addresses indicate the mailers were sent by Pay Attention America Inc., with an address listed as 1000 N. West St. in Wilmington, Delaware.
The group's registered agent is listed online through the Delaware Department of State as The Corporation Trust Company, also located in Wilmington. The company offers registered agent services and has provided these services to more than 300,000 businesses, according to its website.
Representatives from The Corporation Trust told The Star Democrat that Pay Attention America is newly formed, and thus, no contact information can be publicly provided since the group hasn't filed an annual tax report.
Though not confirmed to be behind the mailers, a website with a domain of payattentionamerica.com describes itself as a "group of concerned citizens across the United States of America joined to combat the decline of our beloved country." No contact information or addresses are listed on the website.
As of Tuesday evening, The Star Democrat has not received a response from a contact form submitted on the website payattentionamerica.com.
Resident Hilary Spence received the flyer in her mailbox on Aug. 9. She was most struck by "the anonymity" of the mailers for such a small community. "It's hard to have dialogue with nobody to (have) dialogue with," she said.
"That's what offends me the most, to be honest, as a local resident supportive of public schools," Spence said. " … It's like if you have something to say to me … say it to my face."
Easton resident Shari Wilcoxon had a different stance on the mailers.
"I was actually pretty excited to see that someone was willing to tell the truth to the public," Wilcoxon said. "Because I feel like most people have absolutely no idea of the state of the education system in Maryland." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a public school superintendent responding to concerns about district spending and student performance, which directly relates to education policy and administration.

She urged residents to review the detailed financial report released by the Talbot County Board of Education.

title: Talbot Schools Welcome Back Teachers and Staff
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot schools welcome back teachers and staff

 August 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 510
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Hundreds of teachers and staff gathered in the Easton High School auditorium Thursday morning to celebrate the dawn of a new school year.Talbot County Public Schools hosted its annual Opening Day celebration, welcoming new teachers and presenting staff members with special awards before school begins Monday. Bands from the district's schools joined together to welcome staff, and many other students performed and introduced speakers for the gathering.
Jeremy Hillyard, the district's 2024-2025 Teacher of the Year, and Rosario Steele, the district's 2024-2025 Support Staff of the Year, were each presented with a 2025 Chevrolet Trax from Hertrich Chevy Buick GMC of Easton.
General Manager Pat Papineau thanked Hillyard, Steele and all of the district's teachers for their dedication to their professions.
"I imagine that a lot of people think that your guys' job starts a few minutes before the kids get there and ends a few minutes after the kids leave," Papineau said. "That couldn't be farther from the truth. … It's pretty much nonstop. You're continuously trying to improve yourself, you're continuously investing in yourself, you're continuously investing in your students."
Hillyard, a Spanish and English second language math teacher at Easton High, and Steele, an instructional assistant for English second language students, both delivered speeches to the crowd.
"Each of us in this room plays an important role in our students' stories," Hillyard said. "And it's our job and up to us to make that role a supporting one by always having their backs."
"This job has been the most rewarding experience in my life," Steele said. "I have witnessed those students that start as ninth graders with very little English inspire me when I see them in the community after graduation."
Many other awards were handed out during the event. AJ Rojas, the district's facilitator of interpretation and translation, was presented with the Wardell Brine Multicultural Award. Robin Werner, director of teaching and learning, was named winner of the Brewster Merrill Technology Award.
Named after a past superintendent, the J. Sam Meek Unsung Hero Award was presented to three staff members: Charlotte Compton and Heather Ewing, teachers at Easton Elementary, and George Larrimore, a bus driver since 2010.
MOVING FORWARDDistrict Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi closed Thursday morning's festivities with a speech indicating major areas for the district to focus on. Some examples were staffing, transportation, dress code and student behavior.
"I believe in bite-sized chunks and taking it slow, so that it's not a lot and it doesn't seem overwhelming," Pepukayi said.
She noted that adding mentors for incoming teachers and math coaches has been successful for the district. Pepukayi said the district will begin working on a new four-year strategic plan, as the current plan wraps up in 2025.
At the end of her speech, Pepukayi indicated the district is maintaining its three priorities of improvement heading into the 2024-2025 school year: academic equity in math, an "engaging" environment for students and staff, and recruiting and retaining a more diverse staff.
"We're going to stay the course with these three priorities as we continue to move into this next year of transforming and performing together," Pepukayi said. 

 © Copyright 2024

title: Chapel District Elementary Breaks Ground on Renovation Project
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Chapel District Elementary breaks ground on renovation project

 August 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 423
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CORDOVA — With the school year set to begin Monday, construction at Chapel District Elementary School is in full swing.Administrators, teachers, county representatives and students celebrated a groundbreaking for renovation work at the school on Friday afternoon. The Whiting-Turner Contracting Company is leading construction, which started Aug. 5.
A short ceremony outside the school provided attendees insight into the renovations and what benefits will follow. Speakers included Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi, Principal Kari Clow, Talbot County Council President Chuck Callahan, Board of Education President Emily Jackson, Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers Executive Director Cristy Morrell and two students, Abdiel Santamaria and Laney Childress.
"This groundbreaking ceremony symbolizes not just the start of construction, but the beginning of a vision coming to life," Clow said. "A vision of a school that will provide an environment where our students can thrive, learn and grow into the leaders of tomorrow."
Construction on the multimillion-dollar project is expected to take a couple years. The school was built in 1952 and last renovated in 1994.
During Friday's groundbreaking ceremony, Pepukayi thanked the school's teachers and staff and emphasized safety is a top priority as the school year begins and construction continues.
"Together the Chapel District Elementary School staff has shown patience and flexibility to work with Whiting-Turner and associates, keeping safety a priority while the project moves forward," Pepukayi said.
The Talbot County Council allocated a projected $26.9 million in capital project funding to Talbot County Public Schools for the renovations. That funding is expected to span across both fiscal years 2025 and 2026.
This April, the state's Interagency Commission on School Construction unanimously approved a $3.8 million funding request for the project. Lisa Vaughn, capital project manager for the commission, said on Friday that the "kids are worth every penny."
According to previous Star Democrat reporting, the project includes a full renovation of the existing building and around 16,000 square feet of additions. There will be additional learning space for the school, as well as the Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers site located in the building.
The school's media center is moving to the center of the building, and the playground is also under renovation.
On behalf of the board, Jackson thanked the county and state for funding the renovation.
"Funding these improvements for our cherished elementary school shows the collective commitment, not only to education, not only to rural education, but to rural education for our earliest learners," Jackson said. "It does not go unappreciated or unnoticed."
Following the ceremony, administrators, teachers, staff and students took turns shoveling the dirt to commemorate the beginning of construction. 

 (c) Copyright 2024

title: Students Head Back to School in Talbot County
author: Tom McCall
content:
Students head back to school in Talbot County

 August 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 347
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Easton Elementary School was lit up with colorful backpacks and beaming smiles as students returned to campus Monday morning, ready for a new school year.Teachers were welcoming the students back from summer break, as was principal Lisa Devaric, who greeted students as they streamed in.
"We have been preparing for this day for weeks," Devaric said, "actually since the last day of school. What goes into class lists, and transportation and cleaning the building, new teachers. I am proud to say that we are fully staffed, all certified positions. There are 189 people on staff."
She added enthusiasm to the effort.
"I am so excited and energized. This is why we do what we do to see these sweet little faces coming through our building every day. It is a happy day," Devaric said.
Superintendent of Talbot County Schools Sharon Pepukayi had a welcome sign and was waving to families as they arrived.
"Our theme this year is transforming and performing together. After two years, going into my third, we realized we are better together," Pepukayi said, referring to the amount of time she has served as superintendent.
Getting ready does not start on the first day of school, she said.
"We have been working hard this summer with a lot of professional development we put it in place based on feedback we have received from staff but also internal data," Pepukayi said.
These efforts included training and preparations to accommodate multilingual learners.
"The school district is not an isolated entity. The whole community comes together for our families. I want the kids to walk in feeling confident, walking in with a sense of belonging, that they can use their voice to ask for what they need instead of being afraid," she said.
Amy Dodson, the Talbot County Board of Education School Board member for District 3, dropped off her three kids at Easton Elementary Monday morning.
"As a mom you are always a little anxious the first day, but they are in great hands," she said. "The took off. They are going to do great."
This article has been updated to correct a name spelling. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Board member Amy Dodson highlighted the Board’s commitment to community support.

title: State Test Scores: Local Districts Increase in English and Math, Dip in Science
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
State test scores: Local districts increase in English and math, dip in science

 August 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 481
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland State Department of Education released 2023-2024 test scores Tuesday morning, indicating slight statewide increases in English and math proficiency.Test results from the Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program for the 2023-2024 school year were presented at Tuesday's Maryland State Board of Education meeting. Results showed a 0.5% statewide increase in English proficiency and a 0.8% statewide increase in math proficiency. 48.4% of students tested proficient in English, and 24.1% of students tested proficient in math.
Talbot, Caroline and Dorchester counties all fall below these state averages, though those three districts did increase in English and math proficiency from the 2022-2023 school year.
TALBOTThe 2023-2024 results show Talbot County Public Schools saw an increase in English and math proficiency, while following state trends with dips in science scores.
English proficiency increased 2.8% to be 47.3% proficient, which ranks 14th in the state out of 24 districts. Math proficiency increased 1.1% to be 18.3% proficient, which ranks 18th in the state.
Science levels for TCPS dropped along with the state, as Talbot County fell from 29.5% to 16.9% proficiency in fifth grade science. The county dropped from 30% to 20.1% in eighth grade science. District-wide rankings fell four spots for each category, as Talbot is now 19th in fifth grade science and 16th in eighth grade science.
"The 23-24 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment results showed modest improvement across all MD Districts," Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said in a statement emailed to the Star Democrat. "In Talbot County, our overall margin of progress as a district was slightly larger than what the State achieved as a whole. These results will inform our continued work on the initiatives that we put in place to provide our educators with the resources needed to ensure student success. We also know that student success is measured by many indicators in addition to state assessment scores."
CAROLINETendencies for Caroline County Public Schools in math and reading proficiency align with state trends. However, like Talbot, Caroline County dropped in rankings for science proficiency.
English proficiency rose 2.1% to 45.3%. Math proficiency rose 3.9% to 19.7%. Both rankings slot Caroline County at 15th statewide.
Caroline County's proficiency marks went from 34.4% to 17% in fifth grade science and 22.1% to 19.3% in eighth grade science. The district's rankings fell from 13th to 18th in fifth grade science and 15th to 17th in eighth grade science.
DORCHESTERWhile Dorchester County Public Schools still ranks in the bottom four for English and math proficiency rates, the district did see year-to-year increases in those two categories.
In English, the district rose 1.4% to 33.7% proficiency, which ranks 22nd in the state. In math, the district rose 1% to 12.3% proficiency, which ranks 21st in the state.
Dorchester County's science proficiency marks went from 23.5% to 14.4% at the fifth grade level, and from 19.1% to 15.3% at the eighth grade level. Its fifth grade science ranking, though, did increase from 22nd to 20th. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on state test scores and district performance, which directly relates to the education system and academic outcomes.

Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi praised progress under the Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program and Blueprint for Maryland’s Future, urging continued focus on science instruction.

title: Plans to Address Test Scores, Cell Phones Shared by District Staff at Moms for Liberty Meeting
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Plans to address test scores, cell phones shared by district staff at Moms for Liberty meeting

 August 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 686
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Monday evening, Talbot County's chapter of Moms for Liberty, a nationwide conservative political organization, held a meeting with Sharon Pepukayi, superintendent of Talbot County Public Schools, and other district professionals.During this meeting, attendees shared their concerns about the state of education in Talbot County, including low math scores, and student cell phone use.
Jan Greenhawk, chapter chair for Moms for Liberty, expressed gratitude for the attendance of the district representatives, including Debbie Gardner, director of communications for Talbot County Public Schools; Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent for school leadership and Student Success; and Vulieka Jarmon-Horsey, assistant superintendent of administrative services, systems and strategies.
"Y'all don't realize what a privilege it is to have a superintendent and a school board and her staff that will come in and talk to your group and answer questions," Greenhawk said. "Believe me when I say that because I have friends who are chapter chairs on the western shore. That does not happen."
Greenhawk noted there may be times "we disagree, and that's okay, but we can talk through issues."
During the meeting, Pepukayi shared news of a research-based math and English language arts curriculums that will be implemented in schools.
In addition to the new curriculum, the county has added some positions to help, such as math coaches. According to Pepukayi, while these changes are important, it is essential to roll it out slowly so as to not overwhelm teachers.
Pepukayi's emphasis on changes to the math curriculum comes after an anonymous countywide postcard was mailed to county residents criticizing Talbot County Public Schools.
The 14-by-8.5-inch, two-sided post cards were sent out to the residents of Talbot County last week. The flyers included a screenshot from the U.S. News & World Report's web page on the district's finances, and on the other side they shared that Talbot County students' math proficiency stands 17.2% below the state average.
Shari Wilcoxon, an attendee of the meeting, expressed concern over the postcards that were sent to residents. She told representatives in the meeting that there will be "multiple other ones coming out."
The following morning, a second round of similar postcards arrived in residents' mailboxes. Instead of addressing math scores, this postcard addressed English proficiency, stating that 59% of students in third through eighth grade are not proficient in English.
CELL PHONE USE
During the question-and-answer portion of the meeting, several attendees asked for the district's overall stance on student cell phone usage during school hours. Pepukayi shared the district's policy on cell phone usage may be different from what is practiced in the classroom.
Pepukayi said the district is piloting a new program called YONDER as a way to limit cell phone usage in the classroom.
"It's a cell phone pouch, and what it is is a student comes into school, they put their cell phone in this pouch, and it locks," Pepukayi said.
According to Pepukayi, the pouches will stay with the students and will be locked all day until they leave and press the pouch up against a magnet, which will allow them access to their cell phones.
Pepukayi said the roll out of the pouches have not begun yet. The district would need to communicate the plan with families and have a board presentation on it. The draft plan is to start rollout after Thanksgiving.
Robert Jurrius, a math teacher at Easton Middle School, said it is difficult for students to stay off their cell phones, but it is made worse by parents who text their kids during school hours.
"I'm going to say with all authority that I can muster, (parents) need to break that addiction that you have to be able to reach a child every time anything occurs," Jurrius said.
Toward the end of the meeting, Pepukayi said it was important for her to take the time to talk to community groups and hear their concerns. It falls under the district's theme of "transforming and performing together."
"I'm a big proponent of people knowing the facts, and number two, making sure we're partnering with anyone who wants to help our Talbot County Public students be successful," Pepukayi said. "And so whatever that looks like, we'll partner and we'll talk about the issues." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: New Student Board Member Sworn-In
author: Staff Writer
content:
New student board member sworn-in

 September 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 281
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The newest — and youngest — member of the Kent County Board of Education officially took her seat at the meeting table earlier this month.Alden Swanson is a rising junior at Kent County High School and this year's student member of the Board of Education.
While her one-year term began in July, she was on her family's annual commercial salmon fishing trip in the Alaskan tundra for that month's meeting.
Upon her return, Swanson was sworn in by board President Joseph Goetz at a meeting in Rock Hall held Monday evening, Aug. 12.
"I'm really excited to be on the board and I'm hoping I can do some good in the position," Swanson said at the meeting.
Swanson was elected to the position by her peers at Kent County High School. She is a member of Kent County High School's cross country team and the band.
Swanson is the oldest of four siblings. Her parents are Robbi Behr, a Kent County Public Schools alum, and Matthew Swanson. They are the illustrator and author duo behind the children's books "Sunrise Summer" and "Everywhere, Wonder" the chapter book series "The Cookie Chronicles" and "The Real McCoys."
As the student member of the Board of Education, Alden Swanson will offer a monthly report on upcoming school events, provide board members with the student perspective on issues and cast an advisory vote.
Goetz thanked Alden Swanson at the Aug. 12 meeting for "putting herself out there" and running for student board member. He was joined by the other Board of Education members in saying he looks forward to working with her.
"It's a pleasure to have you here," Goetz told Alden Swanson. "I encourage you to be a part of the conversation." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: County Agrees to Audit of School System Financial Records
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
County agrees to audit of school system financial records

 September 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 494
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — The Queen Anne's County Commissioners unanimously approved hiring an independent auditing firm to conduct a performance audit of the Queen Anne's County Public School's Board of Education's financial records and budgetary development procedures Sept. 10."The county does not suspect any fraudulent activity, but believes it is prudent for transparency to our citizens that we engage a third party firm to conduct a performance audit in order to assess the operational decisions of the school system, evaluate whether the finance office is properly structured and designed to deliver a complete, accurate, reliable financial information and ensure that no fraud is occurring," said Commissioner President Jim Moran, presenting a statement from the County Commissioners.
The Board of Education is funded by both the county and the state of Maryland and has faced several challenges over the past few years, "Which has now led to potential staff and service reductions to our local school system," he said.
According to Moran, financial challenges faced by the Board of Education include:
Significant turnover and instability in its accounting function over the past several years, particularly in the Chief Financial Officer position and finance office.
Request for operational funding for the FY 24-25 fiscal year that far exceeded its maintenance of effort requirements and previously agreed upon increases
Budgetary requests that have increased materially over the time despite flat student enrollment numbers.
"Despite these concerns, the commissioners provided an additional $6.2 million in funding over last year's FY 24, which is $7 million above the required MOE (Maintenance of Effort), Moran said. This equates to a total county allocation of $75.1 million plus an additional $42.1 million in state funding, for a total operating budget of $118,400,000 for FY 25, according to Moran.
"However, the board is currently operating with a projected budgetary deficit just six weeks into FY 25 and there are concerns that this trend will continue to get worse in the coming years," he said.
The commissioners reiterated the audit was "not a witch hunt" but a means in which to support the Board of Education including assistance in identifying resources, guidelines, and best practices with the County's Finance Department and the Spending Affordability Committee.
Commissioner Chris Corchiarino noted when things go wrong some people have a tendency to get caught up in the blame game and not put forth viable solutions.
"We want to fix things," he said.
Commissioner Jack Wilson noted the audit would be a good first step and "huge push toward transparency across the board" and with the current fiscal state of Maryland, time was of the essence.
Commissioner Phil Dumenil noted Superintendent Patrica Saelens, the Board of Education, and leadership have been "more than cooperative" regarding the endeavor and a review of the financial books.
With the Board of Education's next fiscal year budget process beginning soon, work is underway narrowing down potential firms to expedite the auditing process as quickly as possible, and no final schedule has been set, County Administrator Todd Mohn said.
The audit is capped not to exceed $100,000.

title: Caroline County Pilots Cell Phone Pouches in Schools, Other Districts to Follow
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County pilots cell phone pouches in schools, other districts to follow

 September 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 610
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Some students in Caroline County are without access to their phones to begin the school year due to new cell phone restrictions.Caroline County Public Schools began a policy where students at Colonel Richardson Middle School and Lockerman Middle School put their phones in locked pouches during the day to prevent usage during class.
The students carry the pouches, designed by the company Yondr, during the entire school day, with their phones inside but not accessible. At the conclusion of school, a magnetic, unlocking device lets the students unlock the pouches and retrieve their phones.
Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said middle school was the right level to implement the test of the technology.
"Middle school students are wrestling with a lot of things, a lot of changes," Simmons said. "There's a lot going on for kids at that time, a lot of research is talking about the impact of devices on kids at that age in particular."
As Caroline County pilots the Yondr pouches, Talbot and Dorchester counties are preparing for implementation later this fall. Across the board, there is a common goal of improving in areas such as student achievement, attendance and discipline.
Simmons said his district attempted to take a strict stance on cell phone usage after the pandemic. However, teachers and administrators found it hard to enforce the policies in large classrooms and settings.
"The devil was in the details of implementation," Simmons said. "Saying it and getting folks to be able to monitor was really hard. … Being able to keep an eye on every kid who's (looking at a phone) … it's impossible."
The pouches cost about $30 each. Simmons said Yondr believes the pouches will last three to four years.
Dorchester County Public Schools will be implementing a similar pilot later this school year. Valerie Goff, DCPS communication and community outreach specialist, said the district is hoping to begin its pilot before the end of October for middle school students only.
Talbot County Public Schools may follow suit soon thereafter. At an Aug. 26 Moms for Liberty meeting with school administration, TCPS Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the district hopes to roll out the same Yondr pouches after Thanksgiving.
Pepukayi and Easton Middle School math teacher Robert Jurrius responded to questions about access to cell phones in the event of a school emergency.
"I need you to pay attention when something bad is happening," Jurrius said on Aug 26. "And there is no circumstance where a child looking at their phone at that moment is going to be safer. Parents might feel better that they can reach their child, but they're actually endangering their child."
"What I've heard from the emergency response and the crisis management people," Pepukayi said, "is they want students to be able to listen to the directions of where they need to go and what they need to do versus being distracted in looking at their phone."
Simmons said the same regarding the situation of a school emergency while kids' phones are locked in pouches. "If there's an absolute emergency, we need the kids to focus in on their teacher," he said.
In Caroline County Public Schools, Simmons said the district will track if there's a decrease in student discipline or increases in student focus and achievement. If results are positive, the policy could extend to other schools in the district.
While the superintendent did say the high school level "presents an interesting dilemma" and a need for balance as students are being prepared for adulthood, it's the next step if Caroline County's pilot yields improvements.
"If we do see positive impacts in the middle, it absolutely warrants that we look at it at our high schools in some settings," Simmons said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: For Dorchester Superintendent, It's All About Teaching and Learning
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
For Dorchester superintendent, it's all about teaching and learning

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 746
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — When Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson stepped into a third grade classroom at Sandy Hill Elementary during one of the first weeks of the school year, he saw sheer energy."They might have been doing a social emotional learning lesson," Thompson recalled. "And the kids were so involved. They were standing up in their chairs. And the teacher was so energetic."
Everyone was engaged. And for the student that didn't want to get involved, the teacher had him help her with the lesson on the computer so that he was still participating.
Neither the third grade teacher nor the school's principal knew Thompson would be stopping by Sandy Hill Elementary that day.
"And so you know it wasn't a dog and pony show," he said.
For Thompson, who visits the school system's buildings and classrooms every week, the reason for these visits isn't to catch principals and teachers doing the wrong thing. It's to create a comfortable atmosphere of teaching and learning and to offer guidance when needed.
"I used to be a principal, I used to be assistant principal and teacher," Thompson said. "So I want to make sure that they are comfortable with me and know I'm here to help better them and get them supports to be better."
Since becoming superintendent in June, Thompson has made known his hope of bringing the district's ranking up from 23rd to 15th in the state. In an effort to do this in four years, the district has identified different steps to making that happen.
This year, the district is focusing on instructional leadership, taking a top-down approach in an effort to improve student success. Thompson considers instructional leadership — or leadership that focuses on teaching and learning — as his top priority this school year.
"Outside of the teacher, administration has the most impact on student achievement, without a doubt," he said, adding that because principals oversee the entire school, and not just one classroom, they have the most impact on student achievement.
Jodi Colman, assistant superintendent of academics and student services, said that Dorchester County is usually toward the bottom when it comes to rankings among the other school districts in the state.
"And at this point in time, the only way we're going to change that rating and our students are going to start performing at higher academic levels is (if we) focus on instructional leadership within the school system," she said.
In March, the Dorchester County Board of Education approved a purchasing agreement to bring coaching and professional development support for district administrators.
Thompson, the then-interim superintendent, said at the March 25 board meeting that the district executive team expects all its principals to become "great instructional leaders," but not enough professional development has been provided to those leaders.
On Sept. 16, Thompson said this professional development support includes leadership meetings twice per month that focus on how administrators should give feedback to teachers on how to improve in the classroom.
"Making sure that (administrators are) continually developing (teachers') skills to deliver the best instruction to the kids," he said.
In order to jump from 23rd in the state to 15th in four years, Thompson said the district will need to be consistent with developing instructional leadership and follow through on it.
"Making sure that I'm having meetings with the principals, having conversations on how they're progressing on their goals," he said. "And if they're not progressing, how can we shift and go in a little different direction to ensure that they're meeting their goals?"
Thompson thinks one of the biggest challenges the district faces this year will be getting people comfortable with change and holding them accountable to those changes. He said that often, people automatically think accountability is negative, but when you don't hold people accountable, you end up doing them a disservice.
"We don't want to fire anybody," he said. "We want people to do what they were hired to do. And we want to be able to provide the supports when people are struggling at their craft, and then help them improve their craft. When we talk about accountability, that's what we mean."
Colman said that change can be uncomfortable. She said she hopes that by the end of the year, people in the district will find a comfort in being uncomfortable.
"We're only going to make this move if we all know that we've got the same target and (know) that we're all going to have to push ourselves to probably go and do things that we're not normally used to doing," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Dorchester County school superintendent, instructional leadership, and efforts to improve student achievement, which are core education issues. It also mentions the school board's actions, giving a secondary relevance to local government.

title: Talbot School Board Sees Test Scores, Improvement Initiatives
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot school board sees test scores, improvement initiatives

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 836
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — State test scores released last month show a slight increase in math and English proficiency levels at both the district and state levels.Talbot County's Board of Education discussed that trend and others during a work session on Monday, taking a first deep dive into the test results from 2023-2024's Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program.
In English, 47.3% of Talbot County Public Schools students tested proficient, a jump of 2.8% from 44.5% in 2022-2023. In math, 18.3% of students were proficient, up 1.1% from 17.2% the year prior. The district slots in 14th and 18th, respectively, in those categories among the state's 24 districts.
ENGLISH TRENDS"One of the things that the board is always interested in is how does Talbot County Public Schools compare to other districts in the state," said Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership, while presenting the English results. "And I wish that I could give you better news and say that we have flip-flopped the map, but if you compare this year's results to last year across the state, you will see very little change. There is not a single district in the state who is leapfrogging in improvements on this map."
Einhorn and Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi emphasized that the district internally tracks student learning levels. This is done at benchmarks throughout the year.
"I can assure this board that more than 47% of our students are mastering grade level standards," Einhorn said of the English proficiency rate. "It's just that they are not showing it across the state on this particular assessment."
Some positives for the English rates included third grade proficiency and the growth for certain cohorts and subgroups. Third grade English proficiency saw a significant jump from the 2022-2023 school year.
Einhorn pointed out that in 2023, sixth grade students were 40.1% proficient. That same group of students came in at 43.8% proficient on the seventh grade test. "For that cohort of students, it's growth," Einhorn said.
Einhorn said all student groups saw growth in English rates, though Black students had the smallest increase.
"We are reaching every student in some sense, in some capacity," Board President Emily Jackson said of the subgroups. "Maybe not as well as we could, but we're getting there, we are making growth, and that's what I want to see."
MATH TRENDSIn math, the district has many initiatives to increase proficiency. Einhorn said the number of elementary math coaches has increased from three to six, along with an addition of one middle school math coach.
The district is implementing an adaptive testing program called Measures of Academic Progress for kindergarten through eighth grade to track student growth.
In 2023-2024's state test scores, TCPS students showed increases across the board.
"We see slight increases for each one of our student groups," Einhorn said. "We have less of an increase for our Hispanic and Latino students. And we still continue to have fewer than 5% of our Black students and our multilingual learners proficient in mathematics."
For proficiency levels below 5%, the state does not indicate exact percentages. Of the 24 districts, the Talbot district is one of three below the 5% mark in math proficiency among Black students, and one of nine districts below the 5% mark in math proficiency among multilingual students.
Einhorn and Jackson each thanked the Talbot County Council for its commitment in funding education, particularly the math coaches in elementary schools.
"When you see movement like we did in third grade," Jackson said, "I think that we are making really intentional, really important, really good funding decisions that have a big impact on learning."
EXPERT REVIEWSAs required by the state's education initiative, Blueprint for Maryland's Future, experts vetted by the Maryland Department of Education will be reviewing school districts across the state. Einhorn said state reviewers will be visiting three elementary schools in Talbot County this year.
Those schools will be Chapel District Elementary, St. Michaels Elementary and White Marsh Elementary. They were chosen for separate reasons. Einhorn stated: Chapel for reviewers to look at literacy instruction, St. Michaels to review practices for multilingual learners and White Marsh due to success in state testing.
"They had significant growth in their math achievement across all grades in this last MCAP assessment," Einhorn said of White Marsh Elementary. "So they want to know what White Marsh is doing well."
Jackson asked how the district can take lessons learned from these three schools to its largest elementary school, Easton Elementary.
"Can you speak to how we plan to address that?" Jackson asked. "How do you take what you've learned at a very small, very specific population and duplicate it or replicate it at a school like Easton Elementary?"
"One of the things that we do even though it's a larger school, we have committed the same types of resources but just on a larger scale," Einhorn said. "So while our smaller elementaries might have one math coach, we see multiple math coaches to be able to service the number of classrooms that we have at Easton Elementary."
Einhorn said other schools in the district will have state reviews in the next year or two. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While it involves a local school board (a form of local government) and mentions funding decisions, the primary focus is on educational outcomes.

title: Dorchester MCAP Data Shows Some Progress, Some Areas of Concern
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester MCAP data shows some progress, some areas of concern

 September 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 483
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Public Schools' Spring 2024 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program successes — along with district concerns — were shared during a Board of Education meeting on Thursday.Although the district ranks in the state's bottom four for MCAP English and math proficiency rates, it did see year-to-year increases.
In English, the district rose 1.4% to 33.7% proficiency, ranking 22nd in the state out of 24 districts. In math, the district rose 1% to 12.3% proficiency, ranking 21st in the state.
During the meetingThursday, Jodi Colman, the district's assistant superintendent of academics and student services, showed proficiency rates and rankings in the state broken down by grade level.
Colman said there were eight grade levels where the district's state ranking in math increased and six grade levels where the district's state ranking in English increased.
In fifth grade science, where 14.4% of students were considered proficient on the 2024 MCAP assessment, the ranking went up to 20th in the state for 2024 compared to 22nd the previous year.
Colman said that at a statewide assistant superintendent meeting recently, Dorchester County was mentioned for its growth in third grade math, sixth grade math and middle school algebra.
"I thought that was nice to be highlighted across the state as seeing a district that is actually moving some of their scores," she said after mentioning that math scores across the state were pretty stagnant in the 2024 MCAP compared to the previous year.
Colman also brought up concerns regarding district MCAP scores.
According to the data Colman shared, 30.6% of 10th graders scored proficient on the English assessment last school year, ranking last in the state.
Colman said the district is looking at its support pathway classes, which it hopes will affect the 10th grade data "more significantly."
Colman also brought up elementary English scores. She said that as students go up in grade, English proficiency levels decrease.
Colman said there have been discussions about whether the district should resume using its instructional program for elementary English or adopt a new one. The district's language arts supervisor is researching this.
Moving forward, the district is getting feedback from the state on a new comprehensive literacy plan, Colman said.
"We are also looking at, across the board, our tier one instruction for any content level," she said. "Making sure that we're really using that instructional planning model, that we're thinking through strategically with our students and that do we have good, formative assessment data to use in order to change teaching within our classrooms. And I think we have a lot of work to do in that area."
Colman said that although the MCAP scores aren't "exactly where we want them," there is hope in the county about increasing the scores going forward.
"So I'm excited about that," she said.
After Colman's presentation, Superintendent Jymil Thompson said although the score increases might not be "monumental," they show progress.
"If we continue that progress over the years, it will add up," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dorchester Schools to Create Strategic Plan for Coming Years
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester schools to create strategic plan for coming years

 September 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 338
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Cambridge — During the first Dorchester County Board of Education meeting of the school year, the board heard about an initiative to create a strategic plan for the school years ahead.Dorchester County Public Schools is developing this plan with Integrated Impact Group, a consulting firm out of Pennsylvania.
During the meeting on Sept. 19, consultant Connie Casson walked the board through the firm's process. She said the purpose of the plan is to guide the work of the district from 2025 through 2028.
"This is kind of a long run for a strategic planning process," she said. "So we want to be really inclusive. We want to be very engaging and come up with something that feels just a little bit scary but very doable for DCPS."
Casson said the questions they want to answer in developing this plan include how to best prepare students, how to recruit and retain the best teachers and staff, how to provide students with opportunities to explore careers in local industries, and how to do best with the resources available.
To create the plan, Casson said September and October will be spent reviewing district data and understanding where the district is right now.
"This will include student surveys, parent surveys and staff surveys," she said.
In the coming months, through June, time will be spent researching and exploring what other districts are doing, prioritizing strengths and new initiatives, making plans and turning those plans into budgets, communicating district priorities to local partners, and starting to plan for next school year and beyond.
Casson said Integrated Impact Group will give monthly updates to the board. She said they have set up an email account, planning@dcpsmd.org, that people can reach out to.
The district and Integrated Impact Group will be holding three community meetings for residents to share their ideas and priorities for the school years ahead. These meetings will be held Oct. 14 at Hurlock United Methodist Church, Oct. 15 at St. Luke Methodist Church and Oct. 16 at South Dorchester School. All three meetings will begin at 6 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Two Student Representatives Appointed to Talbot Board of Education
author: Staff Report
content:
Two student representatives appointed to Talbot Board of Education

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 325
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Two student representatives were appointed to the Talbot County Board of Education earlier this month.Gabriella Streaker, a senior at Easton High School, and Brynn Lizewski, a senior at St. Michaels Middle High School, were sworn in as student board members at the board's monthly meeting on Sept. 18. They will serve on the board for the 2024-2025 school year.
Streaker is president of the Easton National Honor Society, class treasurer and a member of both the soccer and swim teams. She plans to attend college for health sciences and go to medical school to become a pediatrician or surgeon.
"I am extremely honored and excited to serve as student member of the board, not only to fulfill a position with a high level of leadership but more importantly to represent my peers, teachers, staff, parents and the community," Streaker said in a press release.
Lizewski is president of the Student Government Association and a member of both the tennis and field hockey teams. She plans to study political science and women's studies after high school and then attend law school.
"I am very excited for this new position and cannot wait to have a real insight on local politics," Lizewski said in a press release. "Our small community matters so much, and I'm excited to see the backbone of our local education system."
Board of Education members and Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi welcomed the student board members and encouraged them to provide their feedback and opinions as the school year moves along.
"Welcome to our board," Board Vice President Candace Henry said at the Sept. 18 meeting. "We love to hear feedback from the schools, and so we welcome all of your feedback."
"We are excited to have these student leaders represent their schools this year," Pepukayi said in a press release. "The board values their input and feedback about important issues in our district and enjoys hearing their monthly reports from their respective school communities."

title: How Maryland Schools Are Cracking Down on Cell Phones This Fall
author: Madison Korman Capital News Service
content:
How Maryland schools are cracking down on cell phones this fall

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MADISON KORMAN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 387
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Classrooms across Maryland are a bit more quiet this fall, with students under new rules to keep their phones off and out of sight.At least a third of Maryland public schools have tightened up the rules this fall, according to a Capital News Service survey conducted this month.
Meanwhile, public schools in and around Baltimore are cracking down on phones during instruction — and, in some cases, even on the bus.
In Caroline County, on the eastern shore of Maryland, public schools have a new pilot program in two middle schools. It requires students to place their phones in locked pouches. The pouches stay with the students but remain locked until the end of the school day.
"Today's youth battle constant distraction caused by cell phone alerts and messaging that interrupt their ability to focus," Supt. Derek L. Simmons said in a recent notice to students and parents. He said this "creates a negative impact on school culture and learning."
Elsewhere, administrators are getting creative about persuading students to go along with the plan.
In St. Mary's County, Supt. Scott Smith recently released a video describing the district's new plan to limit the distractions caused by cell phones.
In the video, he comically stops midway through his presentation of the new rules to take out his phone and text, showing students how difficult it can be to have a conversation when they are disengaged and on their phones.
"Hold on, just wait a second, I'm just going to text him real fast," Smith said in the video, pretending to send a message.
"That's really rude isn't it?" he then pointed out. "We're supposed to be having a conversation, and I'm interrupting myself and I'm getting on my phone and I'm texting."
"I'm not really here right?" Smith said. "I'm kind of distracted."
Since the start of the school year, in St. Mary's County, they have confiscated around 30 cell phones per day, Smith told the school board in a recent meeting. That's out of 10,000 students, he said at the meeting.
"We have had many conversations about the joy of being in a classroom without the distraction of cell phones," Smith said, adding that he and his staff "continue to work with our secondary students about the joy and some of the challenges of cellular devices and how we can maximize our joy and fun in life." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses new policies in Maryland public schools regarding cell phone use, which directly relates to educational administration and classroom practices.

Scott Smith — Superintendent, St. Mary's County Public Schools

Superintendents Derek L. Simmons and Scott Smith cite distraction and academic decline, implementing the policy under Maryland State Dept. of Education guidance.

title: Talbot Board of Education Candidates Speak at Town Hall Forum
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot Board of Education candidates speak at town hall forum

 October 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 820
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Candidates for the Talbot County Board of Education fielded questions during an open forum Wednesday evening at the Avalon Theatre.The town hall, hosted by The Talbot Spy and the Avalon Foundation, centered on many issues facing Talbot County Public Schools, including standardized test scores, student engagement and teacher retention.
Three of seven seats on the board are up for grabs in next month's election. Incumbent Candace Henry and Ann O'Connor are squaring off for the District 2 seat. In District 5, incumbent Anna Howie and Karla Wieland-Cherry are running.
The District 6 seat, currently held by Mary Wheeler, is a race between Kerry Gunshenan and Cynthia Jurrius.
Henry, O'Connor, Howie and Jurrius attended Wednesday's town hall, answering moderator and audience questions. Wieland-Cherry and Gunshenan did not attend.
TEST SCORESScores released in August showed slight improvements in math and English proficiency rates in the district. The four candidates, though, were adamant that test scores must improve.
In English, 47.3% of Talbot County Public Schools students tested proficient, a jump of 2.8% from 44.5% in 2022-2023. In math, 18.3% of students were proficient, up 1.1% from 17.2% the year prior. The district slots in 14th and 18th, respectively, in those categories among the state's 24 districts.
"Our scores are not what we want," Henry said. She added that an increase in math coaches in the elementary schools and other forms of benchmark testing are current district initiatives.
"Standardized testing is a snapshot in a period of time," Henry said. "(Superintendent Sharon) Pepukayi has worked with her team to really be intentional about gathering data from students on a more consistent basis."
In recent months, county residents have received flyers in the mail questioning the test scores, along with district spending and, most recently, a health education framework bill proposed at the state level.
"These flyers that came out are pretty alarming," O'Connor said. "And I don't look at them as a negative on teachers. Teachers don't want these scores. The system is broken."
O'Connor, who is backed by Talbot County's chapter of Moms for Liberty, a nationwide conservative political organization, said a lack of "meaningful homework" is a "deficiency." She advocated for summer reading and said the district should look at what nearby private schools are doing in order to raise TCPS test scores.
Jurrius, who along with Henry and Howie is endorsed by the Talbot County Education Association labor union, addressed the most recent mailer sent to residents. That mailer stated, in part, that "radical politicians are more worried about forcing harmful gender ideology" on students, referencing a state Senate bill from 2023 that did not pass.
Jurrius stated she does not believe educators are indoctrinating students.
"This destructive polarization isn't helpful," Jurrius said. "And whoever is behind it, (I) would love to see them contribute in a positive way. I think if we all work together, we can do some amazing things to increase our schools' test scores."
STUDENT ENGAGEMENTAcross the state, many districts are exploring ways to reduce cell phone use and other distractions in schools. TCPS has plans to roll out a pilot program for cell phone pouches sometime after Thanksgiving.
Howie, an assistant principal at Federalsburg Elementary School in Caroline County, said Caroline County's current pilot of those same cell phone pouches has been a success.
"You can see engagement going through the roof," Howie said.
She emphasized that technology should be an addition to student learning and not the sole focus. "A computer isn't a replacement, right. A computer should be a tool," she said.
O'Connor said the same of computers. She said cell phones do not belong in schools and added she hopes to see an increased focus on books.
"Going back to the basics," O'Connor said. "Are we reading books? Are books coming home? … I don't see them as much."
Jurrius advocated for "restorative practices" in student discipline to hold students accountable for actions. She said suspensions aren't always the solution.
"Students right now are different," Jurrius said. "They have different challenges in their lives, their social media, their mental health issues."
TEACHER RETENTIONCandidates discussed the need for effective recruitment and retention of teachers and staff amid shortages in the district, along with strategies to rectify those shortcomings.
Howie emphasized the importance of retaining teachers and staff. She said looking at intent forms earlier will help the district and board understand why teachers leave.
"Being very intentional in having those conversations early … instead of getting that intent form at the end of the year and just start tallying up," Howie said.
Henry added that the district should especially consider the feedback from teachers and staff that decide to stay. She hopes to see specific attention dedicated toward the district's "Grow Your Own Teachers" scholarship program.
"We should be growing teachers from our communities that can come back and teach in our communities," Henry said.
Residents in Districts 2, 5 and 6 will see the respective school board candidates on the ballot on Election Day, which is Nov. 5. The three candidates elected will serve four-year terms.

Forum notable for absent candidates

title: Karla Wieland-Cherry
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Karla Wieland-Cherry

 October 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Karla Wieland-Cherry, 55, is a resident of Trappe and is running for the District 5 seat on the Board of Education.She is a registered nurse and an associate real estate broker. She volunteers with many local organizations. Wieland-Cherry said she grew up in a home that kept up with and often interacted with politics, both local and national. She is married and has two children.
Why are you running for office?
I am running for the Talbot County Board of Education to work to improve our local school system for students, parents and our community.
Goals I hope to achieve will be to improve test scores by enticing more qualified teachers to teach in Talbot County and retaining current teachers; raising education benchmark standards; increase use of CTE programs; improve student discipline rules; improve school safety measures; improve open communication transparency between schools, teachers, administration and parents and the community.
What are your priorities if elected?
After speaking with teachers in different grades at local schools, the constant concern I hear is the lack of student discipline and their safety as teachers. Teachers can't teach and students can't learn… and test scores can't improve… and teachers won't want to come teach in a county… if they are in an environment where everyone feels unsafe.
Teachers have a distrust of the current board and feel that they don't listen to them and take their concerns seriously. I want to rebuild that trust by listening to teacher concerns and addressing those in a more supportive manner to make necessary changes.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces and how do you think the board needs to address it?
Lack of teachers and staff seems to be the biggest issue. As I mentioned already in the prior questions, my priority will be to listen to teachers and rebuild the trust that is currently missing with the present board.
I will also work to improve communication between schools, teachers, parents and the community and work to create a more secure learning environment for everyone.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?
Everyone should take their own initiative to investigate local school data from reliable resources. These postcards are one way of bringing awareness to the community and open communication channels amongst parents, teachers, administration and the board to ask questions about their authenticity.
In speaking with many parents of all grade levels of students, I consistently hear that there is no open communication, especially with the current board.
What are your thoughts on the Blueprint For Maryland's Future? What concerns or benefits do you see?
Teachers I've spoken with are frustrated and don't know Blueprint well, and what they do know is vague with no clear guidelines to how it's implemented. Funding Blueprint is based on inequities of and poverty levels of students for priority funding. Blueprint prioritizes equity learning.
We need to recognize every student's individuality and work to strengthen those individual skills for college/career readiness. We need to stop looking at certain groups as "minorities" and overlooking their skills as worthy individuals capable of learning instead of trying to make everyone "equal" to someone else. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Anna Howie
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Anna Howie

 October 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Anna Howie 
 
 511
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Anna Howie, 49, is a resident of Easton and the current District 5 member of the Talbot County Board of Education. She was appointed to the post by Gov. Wes Moore in October, 2023.Howie is the assistant principal at Federalsburg Elementary School. She is married and has three children.
Why are you running for office?
I am running for the District 5 seat of the Talbot County Board of Education to represent students, families and other stakeholders. We are making gains in our school district, and I want to continue to ensure that our students and teachers have access to high quality instructional materials that will have an impact on student achievement and success.
What are your priorities if elected?
My priorities align with the goals set by the members of the Board of Education and the superintendent, Dr. (Shraron) Pepukayi. My two main areas of focus are increasing student achievement in the areas of mathematics and reading, and recruiting and retaining quality teachers.
Having teachers that provide outstanding instruction to our students will ensure that our students will be academically successful.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces, and how do you think the board needs to address it?
The most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools face right now is providing exceptional education opportunities for all students while being fiscally responsible.
Currently, the curriculum coordinating committee has brought high quality resources to the board for approval in the areas of reading and mathematics. These resources are paid for through educational grants. Utilizing grants is a responsible way of ensuring that we are providing our students with high quality instructional materials while being fiscally responsible.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?
The postcards that have been mailed out focused on student test scores as well as other concerns. In terms of student test scores, we have purchased new high quality instructional materials. Our 2024 data reflects growth in all subgroups as well as certain subject areas and grades.
Student test scores are not just a concern for our district but across the State. Through the Governance and Accountability pillar of the Blueprint, expert review teams will be visiting schools across the state to review literacy and mathematics instruction in our classrooms and provide quality feedback for improvement.
What are your thoughts on the Blueprint For Maryland's Future? What concerns or benefits do you see?
I believe that the pillars of the Blueprint reflect the areas that all Maryland Schools want to address. Those pillars address early childhood education, high quality and diverse teachers, college and career readiness, more resources for students to be successful, and governance and accountability.
The Blueprint identifies and prioritizes the needs that we see in our district and across the state. In order for our students to be college and career ready by 10th grade, we need to start addressing their needs in pre-Kindergarten and ensure that they are receiving the resources they need to be successful in every grade. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
