summary: On Nov. 23, Dorchester County Public Schools announced it will review its oldest elementary facilities after teachers Karen McGowan and Christy Starling urged upgrades. Assistant Superintendent Michael Collins will lead the audit, coordinating with the Board of Education, the Maryland Interagency Commission, and the Built‑To‑Learn and Capital Improvement programs.

title: Caroline Commissioners Hear Update on Potential for New Middle School
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Commissioners hear update on potential for new middle school

 November 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 560
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Commissioners were given an update Tuesday morning on potential plans for a new middle school in the county.Bill Mengel, director of operations at Caroline County Public Schools, presented a revised fiscal year 2026 capital improvement plan to the commission. That improvement plan includes a priority item of year one and year two funding for a potential new middle school building.
Mengel noted that while the district was in the "talking phase" in August and September, it has "transitioned into the planning phase." This will soon include working with a consultant and eventually procuring a feasibility study, which may be complete in around six to eight months, Mengel said.
"One thing I've learned about building a new school is that it's a very serious endeavor," he said. "It takes a very long time to build one, approximately five years. But things change very, very quickly. That's really what kind of happened here, early October."
Currently, Colonel Richardson Middle School in Federalsburg and Lockerman Middle School in Denton serve as the district's two middle schools. It is unclear if the district will aim to build an entire new school, renovate, or add on. Mengel said those outcomes are largely dependent on the feasibility study's recommendation and the Board of Education's subsequent approval or denial.
The revised capital improvement plan was unanimously approved by the three commissioners Tuesday. Its top priority requests are $500,000 for HVAC work at Denton Elementary School and $5.5 million in early planning and design costs for a new or expanded middle school over the next two fiscal years.
$76 million in requested funding from the state for a new middle school build is listed next on the form. Mengel said that $76 million in requested state funding is around 89% of the total $86 million estimation for years one and two, meaning the county would be responsible for around 11% of the funding.
Maryland's Interagency Commission on School Construction, which the funding form will be submitted to, is looking at an approximate capacity of 126,000 square feet for a potential new build, according to Mengel. Mengel said the district's main point of negotiation is "How do we get more square footage?"
Cost per square foot has risen sharply year to year, the director of operations noted.
"If we get shovels in the ground in FY28 and we're able to move in for FY30 school year, that could be at or north of $490 per square foot," Mengel said. "So that's the driver."
Commission President Travis Breeding asked that the school district keep the county updated on the early planning and feasibility study results.
"Keep us in the loop on the study, because we would like to, if we're on the hook for 11% of this, we'd like to have input into, is it a renovation, addition, new location, all those discussions," Breeding said.
Mengel said he doesn't want work to begin on a large capital project if it's not set to accommodate increases in student population.
"I am aware, and so is the Board of Education, that there are some communities that are planned in and around Denton and points north (in) Caroline County," Mengel said. "We expect that there will be some students moving in impacting our populations. The last thing I want to do a build such as this, and then have it be at 100% occupancy within a couple of years."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on plans for a new middle school, discussing funding, feasibility studies, and school district operations, which are core education matters, though it involves local government officials.

The proposal, reviewed by Maryland’s Interagency Commission on School Construction, addresses projected enrollment growth and facility shortfalls.

title: More Than Half of Talbot County Students Receive Free and Reduced Lunches
author: Tom McCall
content:
More than half of Talbot County students receive free and reduced lunches

 November 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Life 
 
 944
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — More than half of students in Talbot County Public Schools receive free or reduced cost meals at school every week, according to the Maryland Department of Education.Free and reduced meals allow them to eat well at school.
"It is basically healthy for them. They get a fruit, a vegetable, a protein and they get a milk," said Michelle Garniga, assistant coordinator at the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center for the after school program. She has six children in TCPS.
The number of free and reduced meals in a school is a measure of poverty and food insecurity in a community.
The Maryland Department of Education found 58.41% of the students in Talbot County received free and reduced meals in 2022-2023, just under 13% higher than it was the school year prior.
At some county schools, this rate is even higher.
"What drives up the numbers are Easton Middle School and Easton Elementary School," said Catharine Poe of the Talbot Hunger Coalition, an organization of food banks and resources fighting food insecurity in the county. "Easton Elementary is 76% and the Middle School is 64%."
At other schools, numbers alone may not be enough to gauge the full scope of students' needs. Poe said the Easton High numbers trend lower because the kids do not want the other kids to know they need food.
Debbie Gardner, communications director for Talbot County Public Schools, said "We definitely talk about hunger. We consider feeding children to be one of our responsibilities in addition to educating them. We know the needs are greater than even what we see on paper."
FOOD INSECURITYThe increased rate of students receiving free and reduced meals mirrors a growing amount of food insecurity in Talbot County, where costs of food, housing and other necessities are outpacing salary growth.
"If you make $15 an hour (minimum wage) and work every single day for a 40 hour week, you only make $31,000. So if you have a family, that is not going to go very far. As soon as you have multiple children, it becomes impossible," Poe said. She said you need $38,000 for one person to make it in Talbot County.
Emily Moody, cofounder of CarePacks, said they started the nonprofit because "on weekends some kids were not eating until they got back to school on Monday morning. That is the nature of food insecurity — the uncertainty. Free and reduced meals are a lifeline. No question about it."
"Food insecurity is on the rise everywhere," Moody said. "What we have seen in the school system is an increase in the free and reduced meals program. People are working, but at wages that are not a livable wage and we live in an area where the cost of housing is really exorbitant. The cost for basic necessities like food and gas and utilities have increased. The place where the budget gets squeezed is with food at the grocery budget."
Katie Fox, community school program manager at Easton Elementary School, is the school based coordinator for CarePacks.
"Transportation impacts, if you don't have reliable transportation, which a lot of people in Talbot County don't have. That is a non-negotiable," Fox said.
And if you live in the far corners of Talbot County like Tilghman Island, it is hard to even get to a grocery store."
Moody said, "For people who are working full time to be able to afford housing and afford transportation and insurance and utilities. When those needs are met , then ideally there is room in your budget to be able to feed your family too."
It is not an issue of lazy for the working poor.
"It is not that people are not going to work. It is just that living is really expensive right now," Fox said.
FREE AND REDUCED MEALS HELPFamilies in need benefit from the free and reduced meals at the TCPS, which ensure students receive at least two meals a day for five days a week.
"It is not easy to give $4 every single day to four or five kids. That is like $24 a day. It would be fairer if everyone got free food. Just because you make more money, it is not fair for kids not to get the lunch," Garniga said.
Garniga said without the program she would be in debt and that over $100 a week for food would be a lot.
"It takes a lot of pressure off especially if you have a household with several kids. Being able to rely on the school system to provide breakfast and lunch every day, it is one of the biggest roles that the school plays," Poe said.
"They have figured out that it would save the average family $1,200 a child each year. It would end all this, and everybody who goes to school gets a free meal," Poe said.
Children in Talbot County are not alone in experiencing the benefits of free and reduced lunch programs.
At the state level, Gov. Wes Moore has signed a state Senate bill requiring the Maryland Department of Education to report to the General Assembly how much it will cost to provide free meals to all public school students in Maryland.
SB 579 opens with, "The Maryland General Assembly recognizes the positive impact on student's academic, physical and social and emotional health that results from ensuring students have access to breakfast and lunch programs while at school."
Figuring out how much it costs is the next step in pursuing universal expansion of free school meals, lawmakers argue.
The bill still needs to be funded, and it looks like the state budget is getting tighter. According to the latest briefing in the state's Spending Affordability Committee, there is a projected $2.7 billion budget shortfall that will confront the state legislature in January. 

 © Copyright 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on school–based free and reduced–price meal programs, discussing their impact on students and school policy, which aligns most closely with the Education topic.

key_people: Michelle Garniga — Assistant Coordinator, Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center
Catharine Poe — Member, Talbot Hunger Coalition
Debbie Gardner — Communications Director, Talbot County Public Schools
Emily Moody — Cofounder, CarePacks
Katie Fox — Community School Program Manager, Easton Elementary School
Wes Moore — Governor, State of Maryland
key_initiatives: Blueprint is not mentioned, but the bill is related to free meals, so we leave as is.
summary: On Nov. 30, Talbot County Public Schools reported that more than half of its students qualify for free or reduced-price lunches. Officials—including Assistant Coordinator Michelle Garniga, Hunger Coalition member Catharine Poe, and Communications Director Debbie Gardner—cited the data to support Maryland’s SB 579 effort to expand meal access statewide.

title: Caroline Board of Ed Welcomes New Members, Elects President
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Board of Ed welcomes new members, elects president

 December 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 458
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Chrissy Bartz and Stefanie Johnson were sworn in Tuesday as the newest members of the Caroline County Board of Education, while Michele Wayman was unanimously selected as the board's new president.Wayman, who has served on the board since 2021, was nominated for president by Board Member Troy Plutschak and confirmed in a 5-0 vote. She previously worked at Caroline County Public Schools in various teacher and administrative roles for a combined 36 years, retiring in 2009.
"I can promise you as president of your board, I will do the very best that I can do," Wayman said during Tuesday evening's meeting.
Bartz nominated Mark Jones to once again serve as vice president of the board alongside Weaver. All five members voted in favor.
Bartz, who was appointed in June to the Board of Education, ran unopposed in District 1. She is the director of community based programs at Choptank Community Health, overseeing the school-based health centers and serving as a provider at Greensboro Elementary.
In an interview, she said she's "excited" about the district's direction, particularly the fact that eight of nine schools are designated community schools by the state's education initiative, Blueprint for Maryland's Future.
"In a county that's rural, it is really important that we recognize that our schools really are hubs in our community and that we can bring a lot of resources to families and kids alongside of the education that they receive in those buildings," Bartz said. "It's a safe place for families."
Assuming outgoing President Richard Barton's District 2 seat is Johnson, who also ran unopposed. In an interview with the Star Democrat, Johnson said she's looking forward to the new role.
At first, she was hesitant about running, but the idea grew over time as she thought about her 11- and 14-year-old daughters, who both attend Caroline County schools. She said it's a great way to be a part of "conversations that can make change."
"When you're a parent sitting on the 'outside, you hear all of these things, and they may not necessarily make sense to you as a parent," Johnson said. "People get in their emotions and they run with that. But I'm that type of person that I want to know why, and I'm going to go straight to the source to figure that answer out."
Johnson is the executive director of the His Hope Ministries shelter in Denton and a board member for the Caroline County Chamber of Commerce.
"There's still parts of Caroline County that I haven't gotten to see or be connected with," Johnson said, "so I'm really excited to be able to go to different parts of the county and just see what's happening, see what schools are doing."
This report has been updated to correct the spelling of Michele Wayman's name. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

summary: On Dec. 6, 2024, the Caroline County Board of Education added members Chrissy Bartz and Stefanie Johnson, elected Michele Wayman as president, and pledged to advance the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future, collaborating with Choptank Community Health and His Hope Ministries.

title: DCPS 'Encouraged' by 2024 Maryland School Report Card
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.ccom
content:
DCPS 'encouraged' by 2024 Maryland School Report Card

 December 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.ccom | Section: Local News 
 
 370
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — As Dorchester County Public Schools leaders pursue their goal of improving the district's state ranking in academic achievement, they are considering the recently published 2024 Maryland School Report Card results as "encouraging."According to a news release from the district, North Dorchester Middle School and Mace's Lane Middle School both gained a star on their report cards. Stars are gained using multiple indicators, including academic achievement, academic progress, graduation rate and school quality.
According to the report card, the academic achievement indicator went up 0.2 points — from 7.6 to 7.8 — overall at Dorchester elementary schools. At Dorchester middle schools, the academic achievement indicator went up 0.6 points, from 6.7 to 7.3 points. Elementary and middle schools can receive up to 20 points for academic achievement.
Dorchester high schools increased their academic achievement overall by 1.1 point, from 12 to 13.1 points. High schools can receive up to 30 points for academic achievement.
The school district news release also stated districtwide improvement in English language arts and math proficiency as well as improved graduation and attendance rates.
"While our schools have shown movement in a positive direction, some areas and schools have seen significant gains with others advancing more slowly," Superintendent Jymil Thompson said in the news release. "To achieve our ambitious goal of moving from 23rd to 15th in academic performance statewide, a larger percentage of growth is necessary. Continued focus on targeted strategies and interventions will be crucial to accelerate this progress."
Since becoming superintendent in June, Thompson has made known his hope of bringing the district's ranking up from 23rd to 15th in the state in four years. This year, the district is focusing on instructional leadership, taking a top-down approach in an effort to improve student success.
In September, Thompson told the Star Democrat that in order to jump from 23rd in the state to 15th in four years, the district will need to be consistent with developing instructional leadership and following through on it.
"Making sure that I'm having meetings with the principals, having conversations on how they're progressing on their goals," he said in September. "And if they're not progressing, how can we shift and go in a little different direction to ensure that they're meeting their goals?" 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses school district performance metrics, rankings, and improvement plans, which directly relates to education.

title: Caroline Superintendent Projects 'Good Budget Year,' Discusses Blueprint
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Caroline superintendent projects 'good budget year,' discusses Blueprint

 December 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 617
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — At last week's Caroline County Board of Education meeting, Superintendent Derek Simmons provided board members with a preview into the district's fiscal year 2026 outlook as budget season nears.Simmons said he and his team are in the process of developing a draft budget. What happens in this year's state legislative session is expected to impact how the budget looks, the superintendent said.
"We are really contingent upon what happens at the state level for our funding, and we do expect the General Assembly to be very engaged in things that could impact us budget-wise," Simmons said. "So it is 100% likely we will not have a clear picture of our budget, of our revenue numbers until mid-April at best."
At the Dec. 3 meeting, Simmons reviewed the fiscal year 2025 budget, noting that around 60% of unrestricted funds were spent on salaries and wages. Those funds largely come from the state, as the district received around 66% of its FY25 revenue from the state in unrestricted money.
"When we talk about where our expenses come from, it's people," Simmons said. "No surprise as we've said for years, we are a people business. It takes people to educate children. It takes people to make school work."
Contracted services accounted for just under 7% of the unrestricted budget. Board Member Troy Plutschak said he wants the board to find out how much auditing through outside companies costs.
Simmons said the district is often audited, but that moving audits in-house would be difficult and put the district in a "world of hurt." Potentially, one or two finance-related positions would be added, along with adding a stress onto the workload of school principals, Simmons said.
According to the superintendent, he doesn't expect federal money or county allocations to drastically change heading into fiscal year '26. "We knew '25 was the tight year," he said.
Assuming no major changes are made to the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's initiative to increase education funding, Simmons has an optimistic outlook. That's partly due to increased multilingual learner, special education and overall enrollment in the county.
"We are anticipating what should be a good budget year for Caroline County Public Schools," Simmons told the board.
BLUEPRINTWhile there was positivity in the fiscal year 26 forecast, Simmons made clear to board members that the outlook could drastically change if state legislators enact major adjustments to funding in Blueprint.
Changes to fiscal 26 funding "can have absolute detrimental impacts to Caroline County Public Schools," he said, since Caroline County Public Schools is "not a district that has extra wealth to go to to fill gaps."
"Not trying to paint a dire picture, but I don't want to paint roses where they may not exist," he said. "They should. But I want to make sure that everybody in the public is very clear as well. It should be, but if they go changing things in the FY 26 formula, it will hurt in this county more so than others probably."
State legislators may be tasked with discussions about Blueprint funding this winter, as the state faces a predicted budget deficit of $2.7 million for fiscal year 2026.
Blueprint will require all schools to meet a minimum teacher salary of $26,000 by July 2026. Caroline County Public Schools has not met that mark yet, but Simmons said the district is making progress.
"We are still working to get our starting teacher salary up to the mandated $60,000 by FY27," Simmons said. "We have done a great job through negotiations. We're roughly $5,000 away."
Looking to the next budget cycle, salaries and maintaining adequate staffing levels are at the top of mind for the superintendent and his team.
"We need to stay competitive with salaries and benefits for all employees," Simmons said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Caroline County Board of Education's budget outlook, funding sources, and the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, which are core education issues.

Board member Troy Plutschak highlighted expected resources for school improvements.

title: Easton Middle School Drops a Star in Maryland School Report Card
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.co
content:
Easton Middle School drops a star in Maryland School Report Card

 December 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.co | Section: Local News 
 
 461
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In the 2024 Maryland School Report Card, most Talbot County schools held steady or slightly improved their ratings. However, Easton Middle was the lone school in the district to lose a star compared to 2023 ratings.The report card, released by the Maryland State Department of Education on Dec. 3, awards schools points based on performance in four categories: academic achievement, academic progress, progressing in achieving English language arts proficiency, and school quality and student success.
Easton Middle notched a two-star rating and 32nd percentile rank, down from three stars and 48th percentile last year. Star rating and percentile rank are based off of a school's total points out of 100. Easton Middle scored 44, down from 46.1 in 2023.
Easton Middle's 2024 scores in academic achievement (7.7 out of 30) and academic progress (16.7 out of 35) remained the same. It increased slightly in English proficiency, from 2.2 to 2.6 out of 10 total points, while decreasing from 19.5 to 17.1 points out of 35 total in school quality and student success.
Talbot County Public Schools' Director of Communications Debbie Gardner said in a statement that the district is "closely examining" the report card results. "Findings and recommendations" will be presented to the Talbot County Board of Education at its Dec. 18 meeting, she added.
"We are encouraged by the improvement shown in student proficiency in both math and English language arts in all of our student groups," the statement read. "There was progress in other areas as a result of our continued focus on our district priorities. We also see opportunities for additional data collection and analysis to inform our short and long-term planning."
Of the eight schools in the district, St. Michaels Elementary rose from three to four stars, while White Marsh Elementary had the district's largest percentile increase, from the 69th in 2023 to the 82nd percentile in 2024.
OTHER SCHOOLSOf all schools in Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot counties, Easton Middle was the only one to see a year-to-year decrease in its star rating, though other schools did drop in their percentiles or overall points.
Compared to fellow middle schools, Easton's 2024 rank slots in above Mace's Lane Middle (two stars, 6th percentile) and Lockerman Middle (two stars, 30th percentile), but below North Dorchester Middle (three stars, 56th percentile) and Colonel Richardson Middle (three stars, 62nd percentile).
By student group, the Easton school had mixed results. All student groups saw year-to-year increases in English proficiency except for Black and African American students. Asian students and economically disadvantaged students reached their annual targets in English proficiency, according to the report card results.
However, in math proficiency, only Asian students and multilingual learners improved from 2023. None of the subgroups reached their annual targets in math proficiency.
To view the full Maryland School Report Card, visit reportcard.msde.maryland.gov/. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the Maryland School Report Card ratings for Easton Middle School, focusing on academic performance metrics and district education officials, which aligns directly with the Education topic.

summary: Easton Middle School in Talbot County lost one star on the 2024 Maryland School Report Card, reflecting declines in student achievement and attendance. Director Debbie Gardner said the drop signals needed improvements, and the Board will develop corrective actions under state accountability guidelines.

title: MACo's Blueprint Panelists Stress Importance of Local Context at Session in Cambridge
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
MACo's Blueprint panelists stress importance of local context at session in Cambridge

 December 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: State News 
 
 542
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Some state education officials are calling for a readjustment of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future with more of a local focus.During a Maryland Association of Counties Winter Conference session on the Blueprint, a panel of superintendents and Blueprint coordinators from across the state identified some of the challenges and areas of progress in implementing the education plan.
"We are all dealing with different challenges, different barriers, different successes," Garrett County Blueprint Coordinator Nicole Miller said during the session Thursday morning. "Local context matters."
The Blueprint for Maryland's Future — a plan passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 that aims to improve student outcomes and education quality across the state through a $3.8 billion education funding increase over a 10 years — has garnered some concern from different counties across the state due to funding challenges.
Last year, MACo sent a letter to Gov. Wes Moore (D), Maryland Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) and Maryland House of Delegates Speaker Adrienne Jones (D-Baltimore County). The letter stated that record education spending by Maryland counties in recent years and additional mandated funding for Blueprint will make it difficult for counties to fund other things in their jurisdictions.
During Thursday's MACo session, titled "What we've learned About Learning: The Blueprint in Year Three," panelist and Charles County Blueprint Coordinator Christina Miller spoke on the importance of equity, saying that it's not only important to make sure every district gets a shoe, but every district gets a "shoe that fits." She said it is time for a readjustment of Blueprint.
"Are we calling the baby ugly? No," she said. "But frankly, it is time for an assessment to see what's working and what's not working."
Panelist and Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said that something written three years ago isn't going be perfect today. He said everything needs to be revisited.
"The Blueprint is no different," he said. "We can still achieve the outcomes. We can probably do them better if we take the time to revisit what was passed with a lens of local flexibility and understanding (the) context of each and every 24 (local education agencies)."
Panelist and Harford County Public Schools Superintendent Sean Bulson pointed to some of the progress his district has made in implementing the Blueprint before mentioning recommendations made by the state's superintendents to reduce the Blueprint's overall cost.
Bulson said achievements in his county include making "good progress" toward increasing teacher starting salaries to $60,000. He said last school year, no 4-year-olds "with the greatest needs" were turned away from public pre-K in Harford County.
"While this isn't the end goal that the Blueprint envisioned, it's great progress that, again, wouldn't have been made without the Blueprint," Bulson said.
During the question-and-answer portion of the session, St. Mary's County Commissioner Mike Hewitt said he didn't want to raise county taxes in order to pay for the Blueprint. He asked the moderator of the session, Sen. Mary Beth Carozza (R-Somerset, Wicomico, Worcester), what can be expected from the General Assembly.
Carozza said Gov. Wes Moore has said he would be willing to make some adjustments to Blueprint. She said it will be important that the school districts and counties stand together with their priorities "(so) that we can make the changes that you're calling for." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dorchester BOE Votes to Keep Staffing Positive Change Academy Through School Year
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester BOE votes to keep staffing Positive Change Academy through school year

 December 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 554
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Public Schools will continue to provide alternative education to the district's youngest students through its Positive Change Academy on Glasgow Street.At a Dorchester County Board of Education meeting Thursday, the board voted in favor of an agreement with PASS Educators, a substitute and permanent staffing provider out of Delaware, to staff the Positive Change Academy through the end of the school year. The program serves pre-K through second graders in the district.
The agreement will allow the current Positive Change Academy staff to finish out the school year.
In October, the board voted to terminate a one-year contract with Transforming Lives, the company that brought the Positive Change Academy to the district. Transforming Lives had been using PASS Educators to provide staffing at the academy.
In an email Friday, DCPS Communications and Community Outreach Specialist Valerie Goff said the academy is still under contract with Transforming Lives, but that contract is "due to end imminently."
With the new agreement, the Positive Change Academy staff provided by PASS Educators will be able to continue to serve district students after the contract has been terminated.
At the board's last meeting in November, the board voted against pursuing contracts with other alternative education companies that reached out through a request for proposal.
Superintendent Jymil Thompson said at the November meeting that the district and board had reviewed the proposals and he recommended they not move forward with any of them due to "budgetary restraints." He said the district would instead work to continue staffing its Positive Change Academy.
The agreement with PASS Educators will cost the district $238,000.
Before the board voted on the PASS Educators agreement, multiple people — including Positive Change Academy staff — spoke in favor of it.
Ronnell Page, the founder of PASS Educators, said his company was introduced to Dorchester County Public Schools about three months ago due to an "essential need" with the elementary alternative education program. He said that over the past two months, he has been traveling to the district to show support. He said they have staff in place that "genuinely cares" and wants to do the best for the students.
"We really believe we can make a huge impact from Hurlock all the way to Cambridge," he said.
Dane Harris, the principal at the Positive Change Academy, said that when he stepped into the role, the program was "in a state of crisis." He said that since then, there has been "undeniable" growth, both academically and behaviorally. Harris said this wouldn't be possible without the academy's current staff.
"The staff members are not just employees, they are the backbone of this program," he said. "They've earned the trust of students. They deserve the opportunity to continue to do great work."
After the board voted in favor of the agreement, people in the audience clapped.
At the end of the meeting, board member Brandy Dawson Cumberland spoke about the importance of consistency for students. She said she hopes the district can have a steady program without "consistent turnover."
Board member Christine LaMonica thanked those from the Positive Change Academy that spoke during the meeting.
"I think as we sit here as a board and always consider our students first, it's good to hear that there's passion for our students and for their academic achievement, as well as their behavioral and mental health," she said.

title: Dorchester BOE Reelects Leadership, New Members Sworn In
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester BOE reelects leadership, new members sworn in

 December 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 322
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — December's Dorchester County Board of Education meeting was particularly important for each one of the board's five members.During the meeting Dec. 12, three members were sworn in for their term.
Also during the meeting, Board President Sheri Hubbard and Vice President Talibah Chikwendu, who are in the midst of their terms, were reelected by the board as president and vice president. They will remain in those roles for a year.
In July, Hubbard and Chikwendu were elected to their respective roles after former Board President Mike Diaz and former Vice President Susan Morgan resigned for separate reasons.
During the meeting Dec. 12, Hubbard thanked the board for their "vote of confidence."
"I will try to do my very best to serve you well," she said.
At the end of the meeting, other board members congratulated the two.
"Thank you for your leadership and for agreeing to continue," board member Chris Wheedleton said.
Wheedleton and fellow board members Brandy Dawson Cumberland and Christine LaMonica were all sworn in for another term at the beginning of the same meeting.
This will be Wheedleton, Cumberland and LaMonica's first full term. All three were appointed to replace former board members.
Wheedleton was appointed to the board in 2023 to replace former board member Laura Layton, who resigned from the board that April. Wheedleton won against Jerome Harris to maintain his seat in the recent Nov. 5 general election.
In July, both LaMonica and Cumberland were appointed to the board. LaMonica was appointed to fill Morgan's seat after she resigned in mid-June following a contentious board vote to terminate an alternative education contract.
Cumberland was appointed to fill Diaz's seat after he resigned in late June, citing family and health concerns.
Before being appointed, LaMonica and Cumberland had been running against Morgan and Diaz, respectively, in the 2024 general election. Both LaMonica and Cumberland ultimately ran unopposed in the November election, allowing them to stay in the roles they were appointed to for another four years.

title: Budget Discussions Kicked Off at Talbot Board of Ed Work Session
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Budget discussions kicked off at Talbot Board of Ed work session

 December 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 619
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot Board of Education was presented with preliminary budget considerations during a Monday work session as planning for the fiscal year 2026 budget is underway.Talbot County Public Schools Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones outlined the priorities her team is focusing on. Those priorities include achieving academic equity in math, fostering an engaging environment for students and staff, and recruiting and retaining staff members.
Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said those areas were determined as priorities during a board retreat last year.
"When the dust all ended, we said that these were the three priorities that we wanted to move forward with," Pepukayi said. " … And then most recently, we've talked about special education being a focus for us as well."
During the meeting, Jones provided an overview of the budget process and how the state's expansive 10-year education funding initiative, The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, allocates money on a per-student basis.
"Every student in our system grades (K-12) qualifies for a base amount, and that's called our foundation funding," Jones said. "That's how we keep our lights on. That's how we have insurance."
Then, depending on student classifications in other categories, such as multilingual learners and special education, more money is allocated to a school. Each school receives different funding based on their enrollment statistics, Jones said.
She added that the expectation from the state is that "at least 75%" of the money given toward a certain school is "spent directly at that school." Costs related to human resources, finance and transportation often aren't school-specific.
According to Jones, the district needs to "make some shifts" in two programs — compensatory education and multilingual learners — in order to comply with Blueprint requirements. No district in the state is fully compliant at this time, she noted, but the Blueprint Accountability & Implementation Board is seeking progress.
"We're just not spending enough money on those areas to meet criteria," Jones said.
Pepukayi said the strict requirements affect funding for smaller schools, a topic that's come up in her discussions with fellow superintendents on the Eastern Shore.
"The foundation funding is insufficient to do all that we need to do, particularly for the smaller schools, the districts that have smaller schools," she said. " … It's compliance-driven and rigidness for our budgeting versus giving us the flexibility to make those decisions and differentiate ourselves."
Schools and departments in the district submit budgets every year, along with providing a list of requested positions. Position requests include teachers, coaches, English second language professionals, special education staff and social workers.
"We're not at the level where we were at last year," Jones added.
Board President Emily Jackson brought up whether or not the district could revisit previous hopes to hire someone for a grants manager position since managing grants is a significant stress on the finance department.
Jones said it's "burdensome" to track all of the necessary results and data from grants.
"You have to have a really detailed knowledge of the public education landscape to be able to write those grants, I would say," Jones said. "And that was our challenge."
However, Jones was optimistic on the prospect that a grants manager could eventually help Talbot County Public Schools bring in more revenue.
"Hiring a grant person might make sense financially," she said. "They might at least be able to pay for themselves, and then hopefully generate some revenue in other ways."
The Talbot County Board of Education will meet with the Talbot County Council on Jan. 7 to discuss a proposed budget. The proposed budget will first be brought to the board at a Jan. 13 work session, and then on Jan. 15 for first reader.
As of now, a public hearing on the budget is scheduled for Feb. 10, with a potential board vote slated for Feb. 12. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Talbot Board of Ed votes in Jackson as president, Dodson as vice president

title: Talbot Leaders Optimistic About Improvements at Easton Middle, Across TCPS
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot leaders optimistic about improvements at Easton Middle, across TCPS

 December 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 697
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — During its monthly meeting, the Talbot County Board of Education was provided with a detailed look into the Maryland School Report Card results, including where improvements may be needed.Released by the Maryland Department of Education earlier this month, the report card awards schools points based on performance in four categories: academic achievement, academic progress, English language arts proficiency progress, and school quality and student success.
St. Michaels Elementary School rose from three stars in 2023 to four stars this year, while White Marsh Elementary School — which remained steady at four stars — produced significant gains in test scores and percentile ranks.
Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, focused her presentation on Easton Middle School, which was the district's only school to have a year-to-year drop in its star rating.
She explained what caused the school's rating to drop from three stars to two stars and pinpointed improvements that weren't reflected in the report card.
"Given the number of factors that make up this star rating and the complexity of the formulas, I wanted to share with you a deeper dive into what impacted the decrease in stars for Easton Middle School so we all have a better understanding of what's happening," Einhorn said.
Einhorn noted that there were small increases in academic achievement and academic progress at Easton Middle. "It was not notable in the MSDE reporting because they truncate the values for their calculations," she said.
The state report did show an increase in points scored for English proficiency. That and the small gains in the other categories show the school's progress, Einhorn says.
"The steps that (Principal Kelly Murdoch) and her school are putting in place at Easton Middle are having an impact in improving outcomes for students," Einhorn said, "even though it doesn't show up in that calculation for the star rating."
Easton Middle's score for school quality and student success dropped from 19.5 points in 2023 to 17.1 points in 2024, which largely caused the star rating drop. Einhorn said that mostly stemmed from the rate of chronically absent students, the "largest single measure that impacts the star rating of a school."
A common misconception is that only unexcused absences count toward considering a student chronically absent. That is not the case, Einhorn said, emphasizing that both excused and unexcused absences count in the tracking for whether a student is chronically absent or not according to the state.
"(Do) we have some investigation going on into what is causing that so it's not carried over into the high school?" Board Member Karla Wieland-Cherry asked.
Einhorn said the district has "several checkpoints" in place and is working with teachers, social workers and administrators to reduce chronic absenteeism.
Board Vice President Amy Dodson expressed optimism about the work being done to improve student achievement at Easton Middle.
"I've spoken to some parents of students at Easton Middle, and they give glowing reports of what they're doing over there," Dodson said. "And some of our neighboring counties did not fare so well with the star system. So keep up the work, there's still plenty of work to do."
"I see every day the work that Easton Middle School is doing, so to have this be the measure of your work is really hard," responded Einhorn. "I appreciate your recognition of what's happening there and the effort they're putting in."
Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the district is constantly assessing school performance and data internally in order to "(celebrate) the growth that we're seeing at Easton Middle School and all of our schools."
"We take our own internal approach, and we just don't wait for the stars to come out every one time a year, or the (Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program test scores) to come out one time a year," Pepukayi said.
Einhorn said while she didn't want to "suggest that we should be happy with a two-star rating," she hoped the detailed breakdown provided context around how Easton Middle is improving.
"I know that with time (and) support from this board that Easton Middle School will continue to see gains in their school improvement efforts," Einhorn said. "I'm really proud of their innovation and persistence in looking at ways to improve outcomes for the students they serve." 

 © Copyright 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot Board of Ed Voices Mixed Opinions Over 2025-26 Calendar Draft
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot Board of Ed voices mixed opinions over 2025-26 calendar draft

 December 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 548
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A draft version of a calendar for the 2025-2026 school year drew varying opinions from Talbot County Board of Education members on Wednesday evening.The calendar committee, which plans the district's upcoming calendars, put together the draft that was shown Wednesday. It included two days off in the second week of March 2026 for students and a five-day spring break for students from April 2 to April 6, 2026.
"The thinking of the committee was to put some days off in March, and then to do the April holiday," Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, said. "Dividing the break would also minimize the impact on our students who rely on the support of our schools for their meal support."
Board President Emily Jackson, who serves on the calendar committee, expressed confusion with the draft calendar that Einhorn presented.
"It was a surprisingly contentious group, with a huge set of ideas that ran the gamut," Jackson said of the committee. "So what I am seeing presented today, to me, does not accurately reflect what I took away from the discussions that were had."
Jackson said she was expecting multiple draft calendars, not just one. She added that past surveys have indicated there are strong opinions on extending spring break and having "time for teachers in their classrooms without students."
"Personally, I come back to wanting to give our community what they're asking for," Jackson said. "So I'm looking for a calendar that has an actual spring break on it."
Board Member Deborah Bridges said she liked the two days off in March.
"I think the March break is wonderful from a mental health standpoint, because March is long, dreary," Bridges said. "And everybody — kids, parents and teachers — need a little break, and I think that's a really good thing to do."
Board Member Dyshekia Strawberry raised concerns that the shorter spring break could increase chronic absenteeism in April. Vice President Amy Dodson said while the draft calendar "looks good," an off day in March could possibly be moved to extend spring break.
Jackson also brought up the possibility of staggered starts for students in "transition" grades that are starting at new schools. Einhorn said that she is waiting on direction from the state to understand how other districts do staggered starts while still complying with 180-day requirements.
Feedback from Wednesday's meeting will be taken back to the calendar committee and discussed before a draft calendar is presented for second reader at the board's January meeting.
Einhorn said it'd be possible for the committee to look at keeping the two off days in March, as well as extending spring break, by moving the last day of school back.
Jackson vouched for "consistent breaks" in order to accommodate student needs surrounding mental health, travel needs, college tours and more.
"There are ways to put this together that do make sense and don't look like this," the board president said.
"I think we have to put everything out on the table because we have constraints," Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said. "We can't have it both ways.
"And while I know we want extra days off, I hear loud and clear from parents (about) child care. But we also want to balance, because I also hear from staff, more planning time. We just have to find out, what is that balance?" 

 Copyright 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Lockerman Middle School Celebrates New STEM Center
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Lockerman Middle School celebrates new STEM Center

 December 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 469
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Lockerman Middle School's new science, technology, engineering and mathematics center was celebrated on Tuesday for providing students with unique opportunities and STEM-related resources.The STEM Center held a ribbon-cutting Tuesday afternoon with partners from the University of Maryland Medical System. A $500,000 grant was given to the Cal Ripken, Sr. Foundation, which is funding STEM centers at 10 different schools in Maryland, including Lockerman.
Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said the foundation's contribution is bringing unique experiences to Lockerman students.
"There's no way that this level of resource and these tools would be able to get in the hands of our middle school kids if it wasn't for your partnership and Ripken Foundation's work," Simmons said.
On Tuesday, students showed off the new tools and gadgets that were funded by the grant, such as a 3D printer, coding robots and electronic kits. In the school cafeteria, two students flew drones.
Sixth grader Gracie Spiering showed off her knowledge of how to make backpack security alarms or model cars using littleBits Electronic kits. She knew how to order the kit's pieces and wires, and learned how the coding worked.
"It's been so much fun to have in class," Spiering said. "Everybody's been so ready to come into that class."
Meanwhile, many students have been utilizing the 3D printers to make ornaments for the holidays. Seventh grader Madison Watson said it's been a smooth learning process thanks to the help of her teachers.
"It's pretty fun to have them just at any time we really want them to be here," Watson said.
Lockerman Middle School Principal Jeannine Necessary said students love learning how to use the new materials. Staff members were trained and encouraged to integrate the STEM tools into everyday learning, the principal said.
During the ribbon-cutting, University of Maryland Shore Regional Health President and CEO Ken Kozel said the healthcare system appreciates students involved in STEM because the students are "highly motivated and educated."
"We're here to promote STEM because it's such an important part of the healthcare system," Kozel said. "We're local, we're small, we're a community hospital system, but we need our community to help support our workforce needs."
With a handful of students excited to show off the new technology on Tuesday, Simmons reflected on how much the grant means to the Denton middle school, given the district's financial challenges.
"About 60 to 65 percent of our students qualify for free and reduced meals, which puts a little bit different lens on the opportunities that our kids have to access things," Simmons said. "It also puts a lens on the opportunity the school system has funding-wise to be able to provide those avenues.
"We are thrilled that we were selected by you guys, in partnership with the Ripken Foundation, to be able to provide opportunity and access that we could've never funded for our students." 

 Copyright 2024

title: Classical Charter School Looks to Open in Queen Anne's
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Classical charter school looks to open in Queen Anne's

 December 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 414
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The first classical public charter school in Queen Anne's County hopes to open in the fall of 2026.Queen Anne's Classical Charter School (QACCS) is a proposed tuition-free pre-K through eighth grade school to provide an alternative educational approach and complement the work of other public schools to over four hundred students.
The drive for QACCS was formed by local parents, educators, business, and community leaders to provide an educational alternative within the public school system to ensure Queen Anne County students are reaching grade level proficiencies, according to co-founder Audrey Scott, of Queenstown.
Disillusioned with national grade level proficiencies in which a concerning percentage of students in any grade were not meeting grade level expectations, QACCS was founded through the support of local parents, grandparents, and community leaders, seeking to provide alternatives, Scott said.
"If you're aware of what's going on with the education system, you've got to take action," she said.
Researching where students were more likely to perform at grade level and above led Scott to identify classic charter schools of Frederick and Anne Arundel counties with proven track records of proficiency.
"Classical charter schools are rapidly gaining national attention for higher student performance and cultivating character and critical thinking," Scott said.
Scott is a former teacher who said the proposed charter school will provide parents educational "alternatives and enhancements," while still being part of Queen Anne's County Public Schools.
The classical charter school curriculum will include a focus on phonics, Western civilization, cursive, as well as Spanish offered in addition to Latin as part of language arts, she said.
With a board made up entirely of parents, charter schools offer more hands-on opportunities for "tremendous parental involvement," which can make a significant difference in performance, Scott said.
Queen Anne's County Commissioners have been supportive of the initiative and presented a $20,000 grant for an application consultant, she said. This application is due in March, she said.
Students will be selected for enrollment via lottery, with all county students eligible to attend, she said.
Options for school facilities are still being explored with the hopes to mirror Frederick County and Anne Arundel counties' business park locations, Scott said.
"It would be a real feather in the cap of Queen Anne's County to have the first one on the Eastern Shore," Scott said.
A public meeting about QACCS welcomes the community to learn more Jan. 25, 2025 at 10 a.m. at Kent Island Fire Department, 1610 Main Street in Chester.
More information including a petition of support can be found at QueenAnnesCCS.com and its Facebook page. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: State Eyes New Way to Count Students in Need
author: Jack Bowman Capital News Service
content:
State eyes new way to count students in need

 December 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JACK BOWMAN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 376
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland is set to examine its current method of evaluating poverty in schools throughout the next year, potentially opening a pathway to boost funding for schools with students in need.A new study is meant to address the undercounting of poverty in Maryland public schools, according to Maryland Comptroller Brooke Lierman. The Board of Public Works approved funding for the study at its Dec. 4 meeting.
"This issue is exacerbated for undocumented students or citizen children of undocumented parents," Lierman said at that meeting.
The current method of tabulating poverty "really penalizes" schools with large numbers of immigrant students, Lierman said.
The state currently uses proxy measures, such as eligibility for national programs like Medicaid and SNAP, to calculate aid for public schools, according to the proposal for funds from the Department of General Services.
According to the Governor's Office for Children, an accurate count of students in poverty is important to ensure that they get adequate resources. The office also told CNS that the "Blueprint for Maryland's Future created several new school funding streams that rely on counts of low-income students."
Schools currently rely on applications for the free and reduced meals program and enrollment in social programs like Medicaid as methods of calculating student poverty. According to the Governor's Office for Children, "not all low income families participate in these programs."
The office also said that "districts that provide free school meals to all students under the federal community eligibility program do not collect that data."
In the case of immigrant families, some may not qualify or, as the office told CNS, may be hesitant to enroll and reveal their citizenship status.
Other data the state might rely upon is out of date. According to Lierman, the Maryland State Department of Education recently proposed using data from 2013 to calculate school poverty in Baltimore City. Lierman said that many public schools have been shuttered in the city since that data was collected.
"As a Baltimore City Public School mom," Lierman said, "I've got a lot of strong feelings about this."
The board approved the DGS request for $48,000 monthly for "modeling, analysis and providing a presentation on findings."
According to the Office for Children, a recommendation based on the results of the study will be made to the Maryland General Assembly by Dec. 1, 2025. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a state‑level study to improve how student poverty is counted for school funding, which directly relates to education policy and funding.

summary: Maryland Comptroller Brooke Lierman urged the Board of Public Works and the Department of General Services to adopt a new data system that more accurately counts students qualifying for assistance under the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future, with the Governor’s Office for Children overseeing implementation by early 2025.

title: Phone Pouches Improving Student Focus, Discipline in Caroline, District Says
author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Phone pouches improving student focus, discipline in Caroline, district says

 January 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 624
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An experimental pilot program aimed at keeping students off their phones saw some success in its first semester being implemented at Caroline County Public Schools.Cellphone pouches created by the company Yondr were tested in both Caroline County middle schools last semester.
"We've been pleased with the outcome, Superintendent Derek Simmons said. "You see attentiveness much higher in classrooms, kids learning how to talk to each other, even in the cafeteria. It's been really cool to see at the middle schools."
The students carry locked pouches during the entire school day, with their phones inside but not accessible.
Each student has their own pouch, which travels with them daily from home to school. Phone are locked into the pouches at the beginning of the school day and unlocked at the end using a magnetic device. If a student leaves the pouch at home, they put their phone in the school office for the day.
Every classroom in Caroline County comes equipped with a wired phone for use in case of an emergency, and teachers have been given a special pair of scissors to cut through cellphone pouches if needed.
For students with health needs, the schools offer special services allowing students to check their phones for medical purposes only.
There have been talks within the county of expanding cellphone pouches to ninth graders in coming years, but that determination has not yet been made, district officials said.
In determining whether the pouch program will be expected, the district still has to weigh the pros and cons, officials said. They hope that by the end of the school year they will have a solid understanding of the program's successes and shortcomings.
SUCCESSES
The pouches have done a good job at keeping students off their phones during the school day, district officials said. But beyond that, the middle schools where the pouches have been implemented have seen some other benefits from the program.
The cellphone pouches help prevent cyber bullying in the school during the school day, they said. Students have needed less disciplinary intervention since the pouches were rolled out.
"We've seen about a 21% reduction in discipline incidents," Simmons said.
Simmons also said teachers report that taking cellphones out of the picture has allowed them to better focus on instructing students.
"We ask a lot of our teachers, most of our class sizes average 20 to 20 plus students, so if you're asking them to improve reading or improve mathematics on top of being able to see if they're on cellphones it's a lot," Simmons said. "With the pouches they don't have to be the cellphone police."
Although schools don't yet have test scores back for last semester, the superintendent said pass rates have gone up with the cellphone pouches.
DIFFICULTIES
Reception of the cellphone pouches has not been entierly positive among students and parents in the district, Simmons said.
Students have tried to tamper with or break into their pouches during the school day on multiple occasions.
"They're not indestructible, they're not the end all be all, but they are a great preventative tool to put in place," Simmons said. "They're easy to tell if somebody's tampered with one, It's also easy to tell if a kid has their phone or has a phone out because they don't want their pouch or pouches to look empty."
Some parents do not like the idea of the phone pouches because they prefer to have a direct line of communication with their child, Simmons said.
Students have not yet been polled on their feelings about the pouches, but the districts plans to weigh student attitudes toward the program in any future decisions made.
"I think overall, we're seeing a positive impact on the academics, on the social skills piece. If we asked kids if they'd rather have access to their devices, I'm sure they would," Simmons said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a school district's pilot program to improve student focus and discipline by using locked phone pouches, which directly relates to educational policies and classroom management.

key_people: Derek Simmons — Superintendent, Caroline County Public Schools
summary: Caroline County Public Schools introduced phone pouches in January 2025, requiring students to store devices during class. Superintendent Derek Simmons reported the measure boosted focus and reduced disciplinary incidents across district schools, citing improved test scores and fewer disruptions as early results.

title: Talbot Board of Ed Sees Initial Budget Proposal
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed sees initial budget proposal

 January 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 720
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot Board of Education had its first look at the district's proposed budget for fiscal year 2026 Monday.During a board work session Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones presented the draft budget, which totals $85.8 million in unrestricted dollars — an $8.6 million increase from fiscal year 2025, Jones noted.
Jones provided the year-to-year budget changes by looking at 12 different categories of expenditures. The areas in which increases were highest are fixed charges ($2.23 million increase), instructional salaries ($1.7 million increase) and other instructional costs ($1.47 million increase).
Jones added that while $9 million to $10 million in grants are expected next year, anticipated grant funding is more than $5 million less than last fiscal year. That drop in grant funding precipitated a portion of the rise in the requested unrestricted budget.
In Annapolis, it still remains to be seen how Maryland's expected $2.7 billion deficit is tackled and if legislative decisions will impact funding for The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's education improvement and funding initiative.
Talbot school leaders say budgeting will be a fluid process in the coming months as they keep an eye on state legislation and the Accountability & Implementation Board, an entity that ensures the state and county governments are correctly implementing Blueprint.
"There's one area where I did do a little bit of hedging our bets, on the conservative side," Jones said of the proposed budget. "I don't think we'll know any of that until April or May. But as certain pieces of legislation gather steam and seem to gather support and seem likely, then I think we will work behind the scenes to figure out how we will address this if this comes to fruition."
In creating the draft budget, Jones and Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi emphasized that the district considered its top priorities: academic equity in math, an engaging environment for students and staff, recruitment and retention levels, and meeting Blueprint objectives.
Monday's discussion included a breakdown of 33 proposed additional positions for the next fiscal year. The proposed budget includes a $3.6 million jump in salaries and wages.
"This list is whittled down, if you can believe it, from a longer list of wants and desires," Jones said. "And it was very much informed by school administration. This is what they felt they needed in their buildings."
ADDITIONAL POSITIONSJones outlined the 33 additional positions that are in the requested budget. Six of those positions are for English for Speakers of Other Languages teachers, assistants or coaches.
She cited the district's need to serve its multilingual population, along with the state funding for multilingual learning, for adding the positions.
"Our (Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program) data … demonstrates that we do consistently underserve our multilingual students," Jones said. "And so, we just need to provide more resources there."
Board of Education President Emily Jackson asked if those English for Speakers of Other Languages positions will be difficult to fill.
"Because I know we've had problems — specifically with ESOL in the past — finding people who are qualified and had a desire to do that," Jackson said. "And that's a quarter of the positions we're looking for."
Zulieka Jarmon-Horsey, assistant superintendent of administrative services, systems and strategies, said it's a challenge both in Talbot County and statewide. She said recruitment and retention are key aspects.
"We have to definitely start promoting earlier and just doing the best that we can," Jarmon-Horsey said. "And doing things that are unconventional, like our on-site career fair that's going to be happening here this week."
Other requested positions in the budget include: an art teacher at Easton Middle, a high school math coach, a middle school reading coach, four special education positions at Easton Elementary and a special education teacher at Easton Middle.
One athletic trainer to serve Easton High School and St. Michaels Middle High School was also on the proposed list.
"I'm happy to see that at the top of the list," Jackson said of the athletic trainer role. "I would be in favor of two … making sure that we have coverage for all of our athletic events. I know sports parents, they have eyes on that."
The draft budget will be discussed again at Wednesday's monthly Board of Education meeting before the board hosts its joint meeting with the Talbot County Council on Jan. 22. On Feb. 10, the board will host a public hearing on the budget. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Talbot Board of Education's budget proposal, detailing school funding, staffing, and educational initiatives, which aligns directly with the Education topic.

Sharon Pepukayi — Superintendent, Talbot County Public Schools
Emily Jackson — President, Talbot County Board of Education

summary: Talbot County Board of Education reviewed CFO Sarah Jones’s initial budget proposal on Jan. 15, 2025. Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi highlighted alignment with the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future, while Board President Emily Jackson said the board will refine funding before the Accountability & Implementation Board’s final approval.

title: Talbot Board of Ed Adds Makeup Day for Snow; Approves 2025-26 Calendar
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed adds makeup day for snow; approves 2025-26 calendar

 January 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 580
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — During Wednesday's meeting, the Talbot County Board of Education added a day onto the end of this year's school calendar following last week's snowstorm.Talbot County Public Schools was closed Monday through Friday last week due to snow that blanketed the Mid-Shore. However, the 2024-2025 school calendar only had four inclement weather days built in, meaning an additional day was needed to comply with the state's 180-day requirement.
Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, recommended that a day be added in June, moving the last day of school for students to Friday, June 13.
The last day for teachers would be Monday, June 16. Einhorn said that historically, most teachers complete mandated training that affords them with not having to come in on the last day.
The board unanimously passed the adjusted calendar for this year.
2025-26 CALENDAROn Wednesday, the board also chose the district's calendar for the 2025-2026 school year.
At last month's meeting, Einhorn presented a draft calendar with two days off in March and a five-day spring break, which was the recommendation of the calendar committee. Board President Emily Jackson, however, expressed frustration there weren't multiple options posed.
This month, Einhorn returned with three draft calendars. The first was similar to what the board saw in December, with a four-day weekend in March and the shorter spring break. The second draft removed the off days in March and had an eight-day spring break.
A third draft included both the March break and an eight-day spring break, pushing the last student day back to June 10, 2026.
All three drafts included the typical days off in November for Easton's Waterfowl Festival, as well as a winter break from Dec. 20, 2025, to Jan. 4, 2026.
"There is no calendar that we're going to create that is best for every single person," Jackson said.
Jackson said it's clear — based on previous polling and community input — that most families favor the extended spring break. Board Vice President Amy Dodson suggested the board move forward with the second or third calendars.
Board member Karla Wieland-Cherry said she preferred the first calendar with the shorter spring break.
"You're losing a lot of school time for eight days off for students," Wieland-Cherry said. "You're losing a lot of momentum. And plus you're concerned with providing day care. Not all employers are going to allow that. That's quite a long time to take off of work and find day care and so forth."
She added that not all families are looking for a longer spring break.
"My only concern is that if 59% of our students are at the poverty level, we're really talking about more of a smaller group who are really going to financially be able to afford an Easter holiday," Wieland-Cherry said. "… You really could possibly potentially be causing more hardship for something that's more an elitist type thing, quite honestly."
Jackson said while she agrees with Wieland-Cherry's point, she has "to go with what the community is saying."
"We have asked again and again, and the majority of the respondents to any time we've asked this have said they like that spring break," Jackson said.
Following board discussion, Jackson motioned for approval of the third calendar featuring two off days in March and five days for spring break. Her motion included an amendment to the calendar that the March days off serve as two of four inclement weather days for the district.
By a 6-1 vote, with only Wieland-Cherry voting against, the board approved the 2025-2026 school year calendar. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
