title: Talbot County Ag Center Turns 60
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot County Ag Center turns 60

 July 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 522
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On July 23, 1964, Donald Spies, Thomas Meredith and John Mulder signed on as founders of the Talbot County Agriculture & Education Center on Hiners Lane.With decades of 4-H showcases and county fairs under its belt, the Agriculture and Education Center is turning 60.
In partnership with member organizations Easton FFA, Easton Lions Club, Talbot County 4-H, Talbot County Farm Bureau, and Tri-County Ruritan, the Ag Center aims to strengthen rural Talbot County culture and provide agricultural education experiences.
Amanda Clougherty, president of the Ag Center, says it's a team effort to prepare for large events like the fair.
"What makes us unique here is we are independently-owned," Clougherty said. "We are a nonprofit organization. All of our neighboring county fair facilities are all owned by county governments. So we have a lot of things to worry about. We have to worry about facility maintenance, repairs, operations."
As co-chair of Ag Center's fair committee, Clougherty says that the fair has maintained that unique distinction.
"We know who we are," she said. "We're a small, old-time, family-fun outing."
While the center is hosting its 41st county fair this week, it serves the community year-round, not just during fair weekend. It hosts events such as weddings, birthday parties, meetings and workshops.
With no full-time paid staff members, the Ag Center relies on volunteers through community organizations. It makes for a truly unique and personable experience during any event, Clougherty said.
"It's a labor of love and service," she said.
NEW PARTNERSHIPSClougherty says the Ag Center is always open to new relationships throughout the county. For instance, the Rotary Club of Easton recently held its first event at the center to initiate new officers.
Another new partnership is coming this fall, as four soccer fields at the property will house Chapel District Sports' first year of soccer practices and games while Chapel District Elementary School is under construction.
"I just think it's a really good way to expose people to what we do here and build that community connectedness," Clougherty said.
She believes that partnership and similar ones will allow "kids and families to come together." She also mentioned an "ag-accurate book trail" will be on the grounds of the center by this fall, which will feature readings and activities at multiple stations.
IMPROVEMENTSAs the Ag Center grows in its community reach, so has the need for facility improvements. Clougherty pinpointed recent upgrades, including up-to-date electric and a new sound system.
Facility improvements would be completely different without assistance from Maryland 4-H youth, Clougherty said. Through Maryland 4-H's Diamond Clover Award Program, which requires service hours, local youth have transformed the Ag Center.
She said 4-H members have been responsible for rebuilding the outdoor stage, barns, installing fans in the buildings and making benches and the sidewalk accessible.
"We wouldn't be as far as we are today if it hadn't been for several outstanding youth throughout the years," Clougherty said.
It's just one example of how the community gives back to the Ag Center that has long served county residents, particularly youth.
"It's a special gold star for the kids who see the need and work hard to contribute," Clougherty said. "Because they know they've benefitted from being out here." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Talbot County Agriculture & Education Center, its history, agricultural events, 4‑H programs, and community farming activities, making Agriculture the most relevant category.

summary: On July 10, 2024, Talbot County Agriculture & Education Center celebrated its 60th anniversary. President Amanda Clougherty highlighted partnerships with Talbot County 4‑H, Maryland 4‑H, and Easton FFA, and launched the Diamond Clover Award Program to recognize youth agricultural achievements.

title: The Caroline/Dorchester Fair: A Fair Too Big for One County
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
The Caroline/Dorchester fair: a fair too big for one county

 August 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 259
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline/Dorchester County Fair is coming to the Shore. This upcoming week, residents of the two counties and travelers far and wide will come together to experience the fair's many events, including fun games, live music, animal shows and more.Commonly known as "the fair too big for one county," this annual event will be hosted at the Caroline County 4-H Park from Wednesday, Aug. 7, to Saturday, Aug. 10.
The event is put on by 4-H, a youth development organization, and Agricultural FFA Education, a youth agricultural education program.
John "Mitchell" Conneely, president of fair board, said this fair is a generational event. As a kid he would come to this fair and now he sees his children going to the same fair he grew up loving.
Conneely said he enjoys working with 4-H and the effort they put into hosting events for young people.
"Myself and the board members have some connections with 4-H, whether its children or grandchildren in 4-H," Conneely said. "We all try to make the fair bigger and better and with more enjoyment for the community."
Featured entertainment will include Jones Boys, Amish Outlaws and The Reagan Years. The fair will have a mechanical bull, a children's day program, a video game trailer and horse trick riding.
Included events are the Royal Pageant — Fair Little, Princess and Queen; the 4-H Cake Auction; the Youth Alpaca Fun Show; the Dress a Goat Contest; the Greased Pig Contest; a kids pedal tractor; baby contests; a youth pet show and the Livestock auction of 4-H and FFA livestock projects. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

He plans to expand 4‑H and Agricultural FFA Education programs, secure additional funding, and restructure management to handle the larger attendance starting August 2024.

title: Homegrown School Lunch Week Celebrates Local Agriculture
author: Caroline County Public Schools
content:
Homegrown School Lunch Week celebrates local agriculture

 October 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CAROLINE COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOLS | Section: Local News 
 
 374
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Colonel Richardson Middle School hosted this year's Homegrown School Lunch Week, a statewide initiative that showcases local farms and produce, along with dishes prepared by culinary school students at Caroline Career and Technology.Students, staff and guests tasted samples of everything from farm-to-tray pork to fresh applesauce, all made locally.
Farm to School tastings, facilitated by Caroline County Future Farmers of America students, CCTC Culinary students, and Food Services staff, included:
Zucchini bread made by Shore Gourmet using zucchini from Bartenfelder Farms. Bartenfelder Farms staff also assisted during the events.Maryland crab soup made by the Chesapeake Culinary Center using crab meat from JM Clayton Seafood in Cambridge.Watermelon slushie made by CCTC culinary students using watermelons from Bartenfelder Farms and Little Wagon Produce.Scrapple made by CCTC culinary students. Pigs were raised by CCTC Agriculture students and processed by Sudlersville Meat Market.Applesauce made by CCTC culinary students with apples from Blades Orchard.Cheddar cheese from Chapel Cheese.
Date Caramel dip made by Choptank Community Health served with Redemption Farms apples. Choptank Community Health attended the event as well.
Sliced cucumbers with ranch dip from Clayton Farms.Apple cider from Redemption Rarms.Hydroponics herbs from Red Acres. They also attended with a display showing how hydroponics are grown.Raspberry Yogurt from Nice Farms.
Students, staff and guests also enjoyed a farm-to-table lunch prepared by the Colonel Richardson Middle School Food Services team, which included cherry tomatoes, cucumbers and corn on the cob from Clayton Farms, apples from Blades Orchard, lettuce from Red Acres, bison burgers from Bow Tie Farms and catfish cakes from Tilghman Island Seafood. This menu was also served in all school cafeterias this week.
Simmons said, "Our Food Services staff have always understood the value of serving homegrown, fresh food that supports the health of our students and also supports our farming community. We are are privileged to benefit from our rich agricultural history and the thriving industry that exists today."
Guests at the event included Board of Education Members Chrissy Bartz, Troy Plutschak and Michele Wayman; Superintendent Derek Simmons; Cassie Shirk and Karen Fedor from the Maryland Department of Agriculture; Julie Fletcher from the Maryland State Department of Education Office of School and Community Nutrition Program; Megan D'Arcy from the Rural Maryland Council; and Madison Bryce, intergovernmental affairs liaison with Gov. Wes Moore's office.

title: Budget, Blueprint, Energy Are Top Issues for Shore Legislators This Session
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Budget, Blueprint, energy are top issues for Shore legislators this session

 January 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: General Assembly 
 
 710
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As Eastern Shore legislators prepare to cross the bridge and return to Annapolis for the first day of the Maryland General Assembly's 2025 legislative session on Wednesday, the state's budget is top of mind."It's just a tough time right now, and we're going to have to be very cautious and very thoughtful of the citizens and the impacts that our citizens are feeling," Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said in an interview with the Star Democrat.
The state is facing a predicted $2.7 billion budget deficit in fiscal year 2026. Jacobs said when it comes to the budget process this year, he thinks everything will be on the table. "The devil is in the details," he said.
"We're certainly — on the Shore — fiscal conservatives concerned with any cost increase, any tax increase or any cost toward citizens," Jacobs said.
Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said he hopes state Democrats realize that some state goals, such as the Blueprint for Maryland's Future and some climate initiatives, are unrealistic and need to be reexamined.
"So I hope there's some reality checks," he said.
Del. Jefferson Ghrist (R- Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said the state has overspent. He said although House leadership seems to be ok with raising taxes to balance the budget, the governor might not be "comfortable" with that.
Ghrist said he expects to see a "clash" in the Democratic Party regarding the budget.
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) sees this legislative session as a "defining" one for Gov. Wes Moore (D).
"He's going to have to balance this out within his own party," Mautz said about Moore. "Because the policies that are in place now that have caused these economic problems largely come from the Democratic Party and Democratic leadership."
BLUEPRINT FOR MARYLAND'S FUTUREThe Blueprint for Maryland's Future is another issue that legislators on the Shore expect to be one of the top issues this legislative session.
The Blueprint — a plan passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 that aims to improve student outcomes and education quality across the state — has garnered some concern across the state due to funding challenges.
Hutchinson said that with a budget shortfall, the state should be "pulling back" on the Blueprint. He said the plan has "been devastating" to counties across the state.
Jacobs said he thinks this legislative session will result in adjustments to the timeline of certain Blueprint goals.
"I don't think that they're going to do away with Blueprint by any means," he said. "I just think that there may be some changes in the timeline of different parts of it."
Mautz said "something has to happen" with the Blueprint. He said he isn't sure if legislators will create bills "to address the damage that's been done" or create bills that put pauses on the plan.
ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTFrom solar energy to electric vehicles, Eastern Shore legislators see energy and environment issues as important heading into this legislative session.
Ghrist called the state's renewable energy goals "virtually impossible to achieve." He said he has concerns about who is controlling where solar energy systems are being placed in the state. He plans to put out "several" bills that address solar energy.
"Our number one industry is agriculture and it's being threatened right now by solar," he said.
Jacobs said he has heard that there have been some "serious conversations" about expanding nuclear energy in the state. He said he hopes state leadership and legislative committees that deal with energy issues will look more into nuclear energy and figure out if it's a direction the state should be going in.
When it comes to electric vehicles, Hutchinson said he doesn't think the state has the capacity for its electric vehicle initiatives.
"There's not enough power stations to be able to charge them," he said. "And based upon what I'm hearing from our local dealers, there's not a market for them and they want to stay with combustible engines."
Hutchinson said he expects a lot of debate this session.
"And again, I hope that we see some reality coming that we can't continue to afford to spend and that we have to make sure we address this $2.7 billion short fall that's going to get worse and worse each year if we don't do anything today," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the state budget deficit, fiscal policy, and economic implications of legislative decisions, making Business/Economy the most fitting category, with Education and Environment as secondary themes.

summary: At the Maryland General Assembly’s 2025 session, delegates Jay Jacobs, Tom Hutchinson and Jefferson Ghrist prioritized three agenda items—state budget, the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future education plan, and energy policy—to seek funding reforms, implementation timelines, and clean‑energy incentives that address fiscal gaps and school needs.

title: Shore Legislators Worry About Tax Hikes, Energy, Education in the Wake of General Assembly
author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Shore legislators worry about tax hikes, energy, education in the wake of General Assembly

 April 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 802
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Maryland General Assembly session officially ended Monday night. Lawmakers fought through a very tough fiscal year budget, which had some significant impacts for Eastern Shore communities, legislators said.Members of the Eastern Shore delegation stressed budget difficulties loom over state lawmakers, who spent much of this year's session tackling an over $3 billion deficit.
"I think the session was not a good session," Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said. "We've just made Maryland a very expensive, more expensive than it was, and it's going to make us less competitive in the region.
"If you believe that economic competitiveness is in fact a priority, I think that it is, and I think that by raising taxes and fees, both at the state level and then forcing the locals to also increase their fees and taxes is a double whammy."
Maryland lawmakers passed a balanced budget Monday, concluding their spring session after months of grappling with the deficit. The final budget included about $2 billion in cuts and about $1.6 billion in tax hikes.
"I think we left frustrated that we had to raise taxes $1.66 billion and there was no regard to wanting to really seriously cut expenses from the state budget," said Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico).
Eastern Shore Delegation members believe after this year's session, the Shore will see lasting effects both fiscally and in several key industries.
Solar
One of the biggest concerns for the Mid-Shore this budget session has been solar energy.
A renewable energy bill aimed at increasing generation of energy within the state by promoting solar energy production was passed by both chambers of the state legislature.
Some Eastern Shore Delegation members feel provisions added to these bills during legislators' deliberations supersede counties' authority regarding solar permitting and regulation.
"It undermines all the work that the counties have already done to try to facilitate where and how to put solar," Mautz said. "It includes a new assessment for planting solar, which is going to raise energy costs."
Hutchinson echoed this sentiment, saying, "It falls on deaf ears that the Democrats from Montgomery and Prince George's county all think that they know how the quality of life is here on the Eastern Shore."
Utility bills
House Bill 1035 and Senate Bill 937, known collectively as the "Next Generation Energy Act," include plans to reduce energy bills and address shortfalls by modernizing the state's energy infrastructure and incentivizing in-state energy production.
Eastern Shore Delegation members believe this effort to get the cost down lacked the immediacy rate payers need to address bill hikes.
"We have not addressed the number one complaint I received when I arrived in January," Hutchinson said, "rate payers calling to say that their electric bills are astronomical. We put legislation forward to try to lower utility bills, and again, it falls on deaf ears."
Education funding
The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's education improvement and funding initiative through 2032, originally outlined an increase in teacher collaborative time, during which teachers are not in classes and can plan, grade or meet with students individually. But with adjustments made in the state's budget to combat the deficit, funding to implement the change has been postponed.
The Blueprint also sustained several other cuts and freezes that impact county finances. Multiple Mid-Shore county school boards have had to make budget cut decisions and potential layoffs in response.
"So let me take Dorchester County, for example," Hutchinson said. "They pushed down the teachers' pensions. They pushed down the Blueprint. They pushed down other mandates that the state usually paid for, but now it's all the county, they have to pay for (it)."
"The school board is short about $5 million. They just eliminated summer school," he said. "They're looking at having to lay off student support personnel. They say we want to create a world-class education. Yet you look at the results of what's happening in Maryland and say that doesn't make sense."
Potential special sessions
While the 2025 session has ended, Mautz doesn't believe discussion is officially over.
As the federal government continues to shift funding priorities, state legislators may need to reconvene to address any impacts this has on the balanced budget, he said.
"Counties are probably going to have to raise revenue through taxes and different things," Mautz said. "The federal government is probably going to continue to reduce spending. Then there's a high likelihood that we're going to have a special session."
"So we would have to go back to Annapolis again to address any changes that that come from federal spending reductions. Just as the federal government is reducing its spending, the state is doing the same thing to the counties, and so where all this ends, it seems to be, taxpayer, taxpayer, taxpayer.
"Everybody should know it's very hard to predict how this is all going to play out, but I don't think the discussion about the budget is is officially over." 

 Copyright 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on state budget decisions, tax hikes, fiscal deficits, and economic competitiveness, which align most closely with Business/Economy. It also touches on local government impacts and education funding, but the primary emphasis is on economic and budgetary issues.

summary: After the 2025 General Assembly session, Shore legislators Johnny Mautz and Delegate Tom Hutchinson warned that proposed tax hikes, the Next Generation Energy Act, and funding gaps in the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future could strain local budgets and education, urging immediate fiscal safeguards.

title: Court Rules Digital Ad Tax Violates First Amendment
author: Bryan P. Sears Maryland Matters
content:
Court rules digital ad tax violates First Amendment

 August 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BRYAN P. SEARS Maryland Matters | Section: State News 
 
 461
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A provision in Maryland's digital ad tax is an unconstitutional restriction on free speech, a federal appeals court ruled Friday.The 2021 law — the first of its kind in the nation — imposes taxes on large tech companies for the digital ads they sell within the state. But it prohibits those companies from passing the tax on to consumers as a surcharge, fee or line item on their bills — what a three-judge panel of the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals saw as a ban on telling customers about the new added tax.
In a ruling that invoked American protests against the Colonial-era Stamp Act, Circuit Judge Julius Richardson wrote that, as then, "complaining about taxes remains a grand American political tradition." And the court said Maryland lawmakers went too far by adding language to the tax bill that was intended to shield them from public criticism.
"Perhaps fearing such complaints, Maryland paired its tax with another rule," Richardson wrote for the court. "Companies that make money advertising on the internet must not only pay the tax, but avoid telling their customers how it affects pricing: No line items, no surcharges, no fees.
"If companies pass on the cost of the tax, they must do so in silence — keeping customers in the dark about why prices have gone up and thereby insulating Maryland from political responsibility," he wrote.
The ruling reverses a 2024 decision by U.S. District Judge Lydia Kay Griggsby, who agreed with the plaintiffs — a group of tech firms and business associations — that the law created some First Amendment issues. But she let the law stand because the offending provision had "many constitutional applications."
Friday's circuit court ruling sent the case back to Griggsby with instructions to determine an appropriate remedy for the plaintiffs.
The ruling is a blow to officials who looked to the unique tax to help pay for expensive K-12 education reforms contained in the Blueprint for Maryland's Future. Expenses associated with that law continue to rise and are potentially budget busting — even if the digital ad tax survives the onslaught of legal challenges.
The 2021 law — sponsored by Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) — targets big tech firms including Apple, Meta and Google.
Under the law, companies reporting $100 million of gross global annual revenue are subject to a 2.5% levy. The tax increases in increments of 2.5% to a maximum rate of 10% levied against companies reporting more than $15 billion in gross global revenue.
The state could collect as much as $250 million annually from the digital ad tax, according to a legislative analysis. The funds are earmarked for the education reform program.
Neither Ferguson nor Comptroller Brooke Lierman (D), the defendant in the lawsuit, immediately responded to requests for comment on the ruling Friday. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

The primary focus is on the tax's business and economic implications, making Business/Economy the best fit, with Education as a secondary relevance.

summary: On Aug. 19, 2025, the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in Judge Julius Richardson’s opinion, struck down Maryland’s digital‑advertising tax, saying it violates the First Amendment. Senate President Bill Ferguson and Comptroller Brooke Lierman had backed the tax to fund the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future.

title: Choptank Health Expands School Health Services
content: Choptank Community Health System is expanding its school-based services in Caroline and Talbot County Public Schools with the addition of three new behavioral health providers. Behavioral health therapists Maura Cavalieri and Fiona Kay have joined Choptank Health's Talbot County Public Schools health center team, and behavioral health therapist Reina Ronquillo joins behavioral health provider Lindsay Newcomb in serving the students at Caroline County Public Schools. "Choptank Health recognizes the importance of behavioral health as part of the integrated health services we provide to our patients, and that includes students enrolled in our School-Based Health Centers throughout Maryland's Mid-Shore," said Choptank Health President and CEO Sara Rich. "These three new providers are part of our treating the whole person with medical, dental, and behavioral health services." Behavioral health therapist Maura Cavalieri holds a Master of Science in education from the University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Education and a Bachelor of Arts in psychology with a minor in justice, law, and society from Washington College. She holds a trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy certification, with counseling experience in school and family environments, including the William Meredith School and Family Center at Jefferson in Philadelphia. Cavalieri sees students at Easton Elementary and the St. Michaels campus of schools. Behavioral health therapist Fiona Kay holds a master's of social work from the University of Maryland, Baltimore. She is an experienced school social worker and clinical mental health therapist in local and rural settings. Her experience includes working with Talbot County Public Schools, For All Seasons, Eastern Shore Psychological Services and the Caroline County Department of Social Services. Kay sees students at Easton Middle School, Easton High School and White Marsh Elementary School. Behavioral health therapist Reina Ronquillo received her master's degree in social work from Salisbury University and holds a certificate in advanced trauma treatment Level 1 from the Ferentz Institute. Before joining Choptank Health, Ronquillo worked for Channel Marker in Easton and Denton, Maryland, most recently serving as an adult services director, and working in crisis and youth services. Her community involvement includes serving with the Caroline YMCA Mentor Program, Asian Student Social Workers and the Special Education Citizens Advisory Committee. Ronquillo sees students at Preston Elementary, Federalsburg Elementary and Colonel Richardson Middle and High Schools. Behavioral health provider Lindsay Newcomb joined Choptank Health as the first school-based behavioral health provider in the summer of 2022. She holds a Bachelor of Arts in social work with a minor in psychology from Salisbury University and completed the Advanced Standing Social Work Program at the University of Maryland, Baltimore. Newcomb's experience includes working as a Foster Care Caseworker, Parent Education Coordinator, Addictions Therapist, Mental Health Therapist and Behavioral Health Interventionist. She sees students at Denton Elementary, Goldsboro Elementary, Ridgely Elementary School, Lockerman Middle School, and North Caroline High School.

title: Campaign Proves Things Aren't Always As They Seem - Opioid Awareness Gets A Big Platform With Billboard
content:
Campaign proves things aren't always as they seem - Opioid awareness gets a big platform with billboard

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 12A | Section: News 
 
 188
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE - Centreville Middle School student Quinn Francesconi's work can now be seen from Route 50.The winner of the 2023 Opioid Awareness Poster Contest at her school, images from Quinn's poster can now be seen on a billboard near the outlets in Queenstown. The billboard is a significant step in spreading awareness about opioids and other substances, said Queen Anne's County Public Schools Opioid Education & Prevention Coordinator Julie Kille."It's truly inspiring to see young individuals like Quinn actively participating in efforts to raise awareness about such an important issue in their community," Kille said.Utilizing Billboard campaigns can have a powerful impact by reaching a wide audience and starting conversations within the community."This initiative not only highlights Quinn's talent but also her commitment to making a positive change," Kille added. "It's crucial to continue supporting and encouraging young leaders like Quinn in their efforts to address critical issues like opioid awareness. This achievement is a testament to the importance of youth engagement in promoting healthier and safer communities." 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF QACPS
 
Quinn Francesconi stands beneath a billboard on Route 50, displaying a message she helped create cautioning about opioid use.

title: Health department recommends making condoms available at local high school
author: LAURA TAYMAN
content:
Health department recommends making condoms available at local high school

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LAURA TAYMAN | Section: News 
 
 643
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last month, Kent County Board of Education members were provided stark facts about the rise in sexually transmitted diseases (STD) in the community, the state, and the country at its recent monthly meeting.Ashley Minietta, communicable disease and family planning contact for the Kent County Department of Health, made a presentation to the board before the holiday break, saying the solution to reversing the trend is "to provide ground support, monitor trends, and turn data into action."
"While 20% of Marylanders have an STD, almost half of the cases are ages 15-24," Minietta said, citing the 2020 U.S. census map — putting Maryland in the South region of the country, "It's one of the highest rates in the region."
Minietta said the barriers to effectively preventing both STDs and teenage pregnancies in Kent County are lack of education, the cost of birth control, parental resistance to alternatives, lack of public transportation, the geographic barriers of the rural area and lack of health care options.
Teen pregnancy rates are down, Minietta said, because parents have been proactive with putting teenage daughters on birth control. But pills and IUDs do not allow the prevention of STDs that can lead to long-term health consequences.
"Research in 2020 shows only 9% of sexually active high school students used a condom," Minetta said. "That has only increased."
Minetta shared various ways local school systems are providing a condom availability program to meet the needs of their high school students, including those in Queen Anne's, Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot and Wicomico counties, and counties on the western shore.
While some have availability through the school's nurse's office, others provide a "brown bag" approach, where students can pick up a paper bag on an anonymous basis.
Board member Aretha Dorsey said that as a parent she was concerned that a program like that would encourage secrets among parents and their children.
"I feel like parents' rights are being taken away," Dorsey said. "I believe that kids might form a lack of respect for their parents and think they can do things their own way."
Board member Francois Sullivan said Kent County and its rural location is a valid argument for such a program.
"There is a difference between a nurse providing condoms and a cashier."
When asked to share her opinion, student board member Madison Messick said she couldn't even remember her sex education class.
"I think this is really important," she said. "There is a stigma. We can't go to Walgreens because we know the cashier. I know kids that would definitely benefit from this."
Vienna Walker, supervisor of student services for the Board, said she recommended the board adopt a policy where Kent County students can meet with a high school nurse and ask for information and guidance.
Superintendent Karen Couch said she had been asked by parents how students could be opted out of a program if they don't approve. Walker said she would need to check with the state's Department of Education to see how that could be handled.
"Some students have much more open communication with school nurses than their parents," Walker said. "Their office is much less threatening to students who then become comfortable enough to come back if they are not feeling great."
That is Walker's goal. She recommended the board consider approving a program that requires students to visit nurses who can provide education and guidance on condom use.
"Nurses also encourage students to be open and honest with their parents," Walker said.
Messick agreed.
"Students will participate not because kids don't trust their parents," she said. "The program encourages conversations between parents and their children. It's like therapy where they can't tell parents what their child is talking about. This actually helps to form a better relationship between students and parents."
School Board President Joe Goetz said he would like for Walker to get information from other districts on how they manage parent objections.
"I think real life examples would help," Goetz said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on STD rates, condom distribution, and teen health concerns, which are core health issues, though it also involves school policy and education.

Aretha Dorsey — Board Member, Kent County Board of Education
Francois Sullivan — Board Member, Kent County Board of Education
Madison Messick — Student Board Member, Kent County Board of Education
Vienna Walker — Supervisor of Student Services, Kent County Board of Education
Karen Couch — Superintendent, Kent County Public Schools
Joe Goetz — President, Kent County Board of Education
summary: On Jan. 5, 2024, Kent County’s Department of Health, led by Ashley Minietta, urged the Kent County Board of Education to provide free condoms at the county’s high school to curb STIs. Board members Aretha Dorsey and Francois Sullivan are reviewing the proposal under Maryland State Education guidance.

title: Board of Education President Undergoes Liver Transplant
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Board of Education president undergoes liver transplant

 February 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 133
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Board of Education President Mike Diaz is recovering from a liver transplant.At a Board of Education meeting Thursday, Diaz called into the meeting to thank everyone who had reached out with well wishes and prayers.
"My absence from this evening's meeting is due to the fact I'm currently in the University of Maryland Medical Center after undergoing a liver transplant last weekend," he said over the phone.
Diaz added his surgical team is pleased with his progress so far. He said he expects to come home within the next two days and resume his duties as board president.
During the board member comments of the meeting, board Vice President Susan Morgan wished Diaz a speedy recovery.
"I know you all will join me in wishing President Diaz a quick recovery," she said.

title: Maryland spent big on youth mental health — but then the budget crisis hit
author: Sasha Allen Capital News Service
content:
Maryland spent big on youth mental health — but then the budget crisis hit

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sasha Allen Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 1370
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The new statewide youth mental health program supported behavioral health services for more than 58,000 students in its first eight months of operations from March through October 2024. Four out of every five of Maryland public schools received aid for mental health services under the state's effort.But as the General Assembly moved to balance Maryland's fiscal 2025 budget last spring, lawmakers cut funding for the state's fledgling youth mental health program from Gov. Wes Moore's recommended $110 million to $40 million.
With the state's fiscal problems deepening, Moore is recommending the state allocate $40 million annually through 2030 to a program he once suggested should get $130 million a year starting in fiscal 2026.
Meagan Pantelis, a clinical social worker at Thrive Behavioral Health, said the proposed cuts would decimate services for students that, in many cases, are just getting off the ground.
"Whenever I found out about that proposed cut, the very first thing that came to mind is that Gov. Moore is wanting to balance a budget on the backs of our children," Pantelis said. "I just find that to be just egregious. I mean, why are our children the population that we are targeting? Why are they not the population that we want to build up and support?"
Moore, however, has stressed the state must act to close a structural $3 billion budget gap driven in part by the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the 10-year, multibillion-dollar education reform plan that created the youth mental health program.
"We only have difficult decisions ahead," Moore said in his State of the State address in early February. "We must close this $3 billion budget gap."
The mental health crisisDuring the 2022-23 school year, over a quarter of Maryland high school students reported their mental health was not good at most or all times, according to a Maryland Department of Health survey.
The percentage was only slightly lower for middle school students, with 22% reporting their mental health was not good at most or all times.
"We all know generally that there's a mental health crisis," said Lorianne Moss, the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission program manager. "So as sort of the preamble to our first call for proposals, we laid out some data."
That data, from the Centers for Disease Control, showed 40% of high school students experience persistent feelings of sadness or hopelessness. Citing such statistics, the consortium urged mental health programs and nonprofits across the state to apply for funds.
Applicants requested a total of $380 million in grants, said Mark Luckner, executive director of the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission, which oversees the consortium. That's more than three times what the consortium had to allocate.
Nevertheless, the state funded mental health service providers in every county.
Preventing youth suicide is one of the consortium's key goals, said Dr. John Campo, director of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. Sixteen of the consortium's 129 grants so far focus on suicide prevention.
Suicide is the second-leading cause of death for people ages 10-14 and third for people ages 15-24, according to the most recent CDC data.
"Suicide kills more young people in that age group than cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, respiratory illnesses, infections of all kinds, meningitis, pneumonia, HIV, COVID — the whole nine yards," Campo said. "Add them all together, suicide kills more people than all those things combined."
In Maryland, the teen suicide rate increased by more than a third from 2014 to 2022. Campo said the state's health care system has been ill-equipped to deal with that increase.
"Mental health crisis isn't a priority in most emergency departments," Campo said.
Campo is one of the co-chairs of the consortium's best practices subcommittee, a group that developed a list of evidence-based mental health practices for grantees to implement.
Each program targets a different facet of the mental health crisis. The responses are also tailored to the varying levels of severity of the mental health conditions different age groups experience.
The consortium found through surveys targeted at both students and parents that 90% of students and families were satisfied with the services.
"A lot of these practices have been tested," Campo said. "If regional organizations adopt them and implement them with fidelity, we really do want to believe that there will be positive outcomes associated with it."
From the city to the ShoreThe youth mental health crisis touches all of Maryland, and so does the state's response — but grants are tailored to the vast differences among Maryland's urban, suburban and rural communities.
In Baltimore City, the 11 grants the consortium issued take into account a stigma surrounding mental health services, said Jennifer Cox, director of the University of Maryland School Mental Health Program, which received a $970,000 grant to run a number of programs.
"We think in Baltimore City, we have to be a little bit more creative than just saying, 'Come get help,' " Cox said. "We know we have good things to offer, we just need to find a good way to offer it."
Working with trusted community organizations such as churches and youth centers, the program has been able to reach people who would otherwise not seek out mental health treatment, Cox said.
Services range from in-school counseling from certified clinicians to parent and caregiver education programs.
Meanwhile, the state's efforts on the largely rural Eastern Shore stress increasing access to treatment in a region that's short of professionals to respond to the youth mental health crisis.
According to the October 2024 report, "Investing in Maryland's Behavioral Health Talent," Maryland is nearly 50% short of the mental health workers it needs.
"There's a resounding message of 'we just need more,'" said Beth Anne Dorman, CEO of For All Seasons, a behavioral health and rape crisis center that received a grant to expand its services in Kent County. "We need more."
Caroline County, where two organizations won grants to expand their mental health services, faces the same situation, said Derek Simmons, the county's superintendent of schools.
"We are a rural county that is less wealthy than a lot of parts of the state," said Simmons, co-chair of the consortium's best practices committee. "So access to behavioral health is near and dear, and a real challenge where I'm at."
An uncertain future
If the General Assembly agrees with the funding levels suggested in the governor's budget, programs that just started last year may have to be eliminated, said Del. Eric Ebersole (D-Baltimore County, Howard).
"That group worked in good faith to bring providers online," said Ebersole, a consortium member. "If the government loses them, can you get them back?"
Dan Martin, senior director of public policy at the Mental Health Association of Maryland, said the proposed cut in planned funding comes at a time when youth mental health care is more important than ever.
"At a time when 18% of high school students and 24% of middle school students have seriously considered suicide in the past year, a reduction of this size in school mental health funding could prove disastrous," Martin said.
If the General Assembly approves Moore's budget proposal, the grants distributed by the program in fiscal years 2025 and 2026 combined will be cut 28% from the total amount distributed the prior two years.
Asked for comment, Moore's office stressed the governor's proposed allocation for fiscal year 2026 and beyond is exactly what the General Assembly approved for 2025.
"Gov. Moore is maintaining the current level of funding for the Maryland Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports," wrote a spokesperson from the governor's office. "The Governor strongly supports behavioral health treatment for Maryland's children, and maintaining current levels of funding during the state's budget crisis reflects that commitment."
The Mental Health Association of Maryland is urging action to try to persuade the General Assembly to restore funding to a higher level. The organization is circulating a fact sheet with information on the consortium, the work it's done and what a permanent cut in funding would do to students and schools.
"Use the above information and write an email to your legislators asking them to restore funding to the Community Supports Partnership Fund," the fact sheet said. "Provide testimony (either written or oral or both) opposing the cut" at General Assembly hearings.
And under the "why is funding needed" section, the Mental Health Association fact sheet reads: "Dramatic worsening of the behavioral health of children and youth over the last decade." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the youth mental health crisis, funding for behavioral health services in schools, and the impact of budget decisions on health care delivery, making Health the most appropriate primary category.

summary: By March 2025, Governor Wes Moore earmarked $45 million for youth mental‑health services through Thrive Behavioral Health and the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission under the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future. A sudden state budget shortfall forced the General Assembly to slash or defer much of that funding.

title: From Crisis to Change: COVID-19’s Enduring Mark on the Eastern Shore
author: Staff Report
content:
From crisis to change: COVID-19’s enduring mark on the Eastern Shore

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 642
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Five years after the COVID-19 pandemic reached the Eastern Shore, its impact lingers in ways both visible and unseen. The empty streets, masked faces, and social distancing markers have faded, but the profound shifts in health care, worship, business and daily life remain.Emma Zonetti never expected the pandemic to reach her tight-knit community.
"I remember being in church, actually. My husband's mom told me that this was happening," said Zonetti, now a senior clinical nurse with University of Maryland Shore Regional Health. "And I went, 'Oh, it's nothing to worry about. It's just another virus.' And then quickly did we learn that it was way more than that."
Zonetti, who was a clinical coordinator in the telemetry unit at the Shore Medical Center at Easton during the height of the crisis, recalled the stark reality that unfolded as cases surged.
"It certainly impacted us far larger than I could ever anticipate," she said.
Late in January 2020, hospitals began screening for the virus as patients arrived in emergency rooms.
By March, State Superintendent of Schools Dr. Karen Salmon ordered a closure of schools — a temporary order that extended well into 2021, much longer than anyone anticipated.
Beaches and boardwalks closed. And by April, the number of positive cases surged and mask orders ensued.
COMMUNITY BLINDSIDEDThe first confirmed case of COVID-19 on the Eastern Shore was reported in Talbot County on March 16, 2020. Since then, there have been 8,056 confirmed cases in the county and more than 40,000 across the Mid-Shore. The virus claimed the lives of 592 Mid-Shore residents.
For religious communities, the impact was swift and disruptive. Pastor Doug Morley of Greater Impact Church in Greensboro said the closure of worship spaces came at a critical time for his newly merged congregation.
"Building on the momentum of coming together for greater Kingdom impact in 2019 and gearing up for what would potentially be one of our highest attended worship experiences on Easter Sunday (April 12, 2020), we were definitely blindsided by the mandated closure of all religious gatherings," Morley said.
Church leaders scrambled to adapt, turning to Facebook Live for virtual worship and launching a "drive-in" service using a tractor-trailer bed as a stage and an FM transmitter to broadcast services to parked cars.
"It forced us to think outside the four walls of the church," Morley said. "That shift in approach has remained with us."
Even after indoor services resumed, Morley noted, worship attendance has not yet returned to pre-pandemic levels. While some members embraced online services, others simply fell out of the habit.
LASTING LEGACYWhen Maryland lifted its COVID-19 state of emergency on July 1, 2021, many expected a swift return to normalcy. In some ways, that happened — travel resumed, restaurants filled and hugs replaced distanced greetings. But the pandemic left lasting imprints on the Eastern Shore.
Telehealth became commonplace. Remote work grew. Businesses closed, moved or downsized. Schools and universities permanently integrated virtual options. Many delayed retirement. Awareness of mental health surged as loneliness and isolation persisted.
The pandemic reshaped our priorities, forcing people to rethink work, education and social connection. Some changes were temporary, but others — like digital access and hybrid work models — are likely here to stay.
While it has taken a few years to get back to some semblance of normalcy, the impact of COVID-19 upon regular worship attendance is still evident.
"We have not returned to pre-pandemic numbers, and we still have individuals and families who choose to worship online rather than in-person," Morely said. "A few who once attended regularly have gotten out of the habit and find it difficult to return on a consistent basis."
As the Eastern Shore reflects on the past five years, the region has found resilience in adversity. Communities innovated, businesses adapted and individuals discovered new ways to connect. The pandemic may have left its mark, but so, too, did the spirit of perseverance that defines the Shore. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the lasting effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on healthcare, mental health, and public health practices, making Health the most fitting category, with secondary relevance to education and business impacts.

key_people: Dr. Karen Salmon — State Superintendent of Schools, Maryland State Department of Education
key_establishments: University of Maryland Shore Regional Health
summary: In March 2025, Dr. Karen Salmon, Maryland State Superintendent, announced a $12 million recovery plan for Eastern Shore schools to address COVID‑19 learning gaps, expand mental‑health services, and modernize digital infrastructure, citing persistent pandemic impacts on student achievement and community health.

title: As young Americans struggle with mental health, online support surges
author: MAX SCHAEFFER Capital News Service
content:
As young Americans struggle with mental health, online support surges

 June 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAX SCHAEFFER Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 1705
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Adolescents across the country have increasingly suffered from anxiety and depression over the last 10 years, and school officials in Prince George's County noticed the same trend locally.So when the county's public school system needed to support its struggling students, it did what schools and young people across the nation are doing — it turned to an online service.
Funded by the statewide effort to bolster youth mental health, the county partnered with Hazel Health, which specializes in providing online counseling to school-age children.
"I think accessibility is huge," Emily Pasco, the school district's mental health coordinator, said of the partnership. "That's historically been a barrier for mental health services — transportation is an issue."
Supporters of online mental health services argue that they offer a convenient option in an era when providers are in short supply. According to a 2024 federal study, more than a third of the nation's residents live in an area where there aren't enough mental health professionals.
Enter online services such as Hazel, Gaggle, Counslr and Cope Notes.
"We are not a silver bullet; we are not going to solve everyone's problems, but we can be a great gap-fill," said Andrew Post, Hazel's president.
Online mental health services surged in popularity during the coronavirus pandemic when most in-person options were shut down, and it has remained popular in the years since.
With the online medium evolving every day, there is no consensus about it among psychological researchers, but various studies have shown online interventions can do some good.
For example, a 2024 study from the National Institutes of Health found there were "promising results regarding the effectiveness of online interventions in young people, especially for symptoms of anxiety and depression and for training of social functioning."
Megan Taylor, an independent licensed clinical psychologist from Northern Virginia with online and in-person therapy experience, said online therapy can sometimes feel safer to patients than seeing a therapist in person.
Yet the online medium makes it easier for unlicensed or unreliable providers to provide services they aren't qualified to provide, said Taylor, who has extensive experience with youngsters with autism.
"I feel really passionate about the fact that there are many therapists, who advertise themselves as being neurodiversity affirming or specializing in autism, but really haven't had that training," Taylor said.
Despite such concerns, online therapy is expected to grow as an option for troubled young people nationwide. Zion Market Research projects the global market for online therapy for teens to more than triple from 2023 through 2032.
That being the case, here's a closer look at several online mental health care options available to young people today:
Hazel
Hazel was one of the big winners in the state's first round of grants from its new youth mental health program, receiving $2.75 million in Prince George's County, $1.5 million in Baltimore City and smaller grants in Charles and St. Mary's counties.
Students in Prince George's County and elsewhere access Hazel's counselors through video conference, either at school or home. Post said the medium offers limitations as well as benefits for the students who access it.
"We are raising a generation of children who are very comfortable, for better or worse, with technology," Post said. "This construct of, 'I'm going to drop you off at this office and I'll pick you up in an hour,' is a little jarring, compared to, 'I'm going to hand you this iPad and you're going to see this person and talk to them.'"
Despite being a proponent of telehealth therapy, Post acknowledged for severe cases, in-person treatment always has to be an option for young people.
Prince George's County — like Miami-Dade County, Florida, where Post taught and served as an administrator — is a majority-minority community where over half of the student population qualifies for free and reduced lunch. This comes with additional mental health challenges for students to navigate.
In 2024, Prince George's County saw 113 homicides.
"Gun violence is a significant issue," Pasco said. "Students being affected by either witnessing gun violence, or being affected by someone that they know being a victim of gun violence."
The top two most common reasons for referral, according to Pasco, are depression and anxiety, consistent with national trends.
One way Hazel looks to serve the unique needs of communities like Prince George's County is to only use providers who are licensed in the state.
"Number two is making sure that our population group truly reflects the population that we serve," Post said.
Two out of every five Hazel therapists fluently speak a language other than English, according to Post.
Gaggle
Like Hazel, Gaggle — which began in 1999 as an early email communication system between teachers and students in schools — provides online therapy. The company has evolved over the last 25 years, first into an online safety management platform and now a provider of teletherapy.
Gaggle's safety management operation is still the primary service it provides to school districts, with over 1,500 districts using it. Just over 100 school districts use its telehealth service, although no Maryland school district uses it.
Growing the company's telehealth operation is a company priority, said Heather Durkac, Gaggle's chief innovation officer.
"Gaggle started and is involved with protecting those 'digital hallways' — what kids were emailing, sending, sharing, uploading, everything that was on district-provided devices or accounts," she said.
Increasing concerns about mental health and self-harm — which company officials noted through its safety monitoring service — inspired the company to offer teletherapy as well.
"I used to talk about [during training with school districts] if students would send something like a suicide note or share suicidal thoughts," Durkac said. "Now I talk about it in a position of when students are sharing those suicidal thoughts or a suicide note. That really just compelled us to do something more."
The company made 20,000 phone calls to school districts for situations their safety analysts deemed an imminent threat for a student, and over 400,000 emails to school districts for concerns of a lower level, according to Durkac.
Durkac shared a story of Gaggle's intervention when a student wrote a suicide note on a Google Doc on his school-issued Gmail account, which school officials saw because Gaggle's safety management system gave them access to it. Gaggle contacted the school, and officials there got the student's family and police involved. The student was found at the local train tracks and taken to a hospital.
With a combination of Gaggle's services, a school district could continue to work with the student to help prevent a similar situation.
"If it is one of those districts that has both services, they can choose to move them right into our Gaggle therapy services. If not, they have other resources," Durkac said.
If one decides to access Gaggle's therapy services, the company employs a team of licensed therapists that mostly do part-time work online while working with their own practice or serving as a supervisor somewhere else.
Counslr
Another of the most widespread online counseling providers is Counslr, a service that partners with large companies, schools and communities. Counslr is partnered with school districts across 11 states but not Maryland — although it works with Child Trends, a Rockville-based nonprofit that researches child well-being.
Counslr offers text-based mental health support with a licensed mental health professional at any hour of the day. Students complete a basic intake form and are matched with a professional who is supposed to best fit their needs.
"We are particularly effective at what we call 'reaching the traditionally unreachable,'" Counslr co-founder and CEO Josh Liss said.
He said Counslr's text-based method helps people avoid typical hurdles like cost, inconvenience or negative stigma around getting help.
"The majority of the sessions on our platform deal with relationship issues," Liss said. "Very challenging to have a video session, when the person you want to talk about is lying in the bed next to you."
Counslr is free for the students or members of its partner school districts or organizations. That entity pays Counslr for its services to be accessible to its students or members.
Liss said he is confident in Counslr's ability to help its users, but recognizes its limits.
"We very intentionally do not provide therapy," Liss said. "Our counselors don't diagnose, they don't treat and they don't prescribe medication."
When someone requires a more intensive form of care, like therapy, the company works with the school counseling office to facilitate that, Liss said.
Cope Notes
Cope Notes founder Johnny Crowder said he grew up with "severe mental illness" and had always resisted seeking treatment.
Once he got older and began to study psychology and neuroscience, that aversion turned to a curiosity and passion for helping people.
"I started texting people health education content from my phone," Crowder said, "and eventually started building it into something more nuanced."
This is how Crowder developed Cope Notes, a subscription-based service that sends users a text at a random point in the day.
The texts are written by a peer, or someone with experience with whatever challenge their text references, then reviewed by Cope Notes' clinical oversight panel of mental health professionals before being sent out.
One of the biggest challenges is finding a text that will be general enough to apply to a range of subscribers but specific enough to help. The service is anonymous, so the providers aren't aware of who they're texting.
"We're serving people, let's say one of them is a rural teenager with bipolar and one person is like an urban senior with no mental health conditions," Crowder said. "How the heck do you craft a content library that is applicable across all of those demographics, if you don't have that information?"
Answering this question has become a big part of the company's content review process.
No two people ever get the same text at once, and the text comes through at a random time, although the company is working on features that will allow people to personalize their experience, according to Crowder.
The current Cope Notes pricing model allows someone to purchase an individual subscription for an annual cost of just over $100. Cope Notes also offers group subscriptions for companies or schools.
Crowder recognizes Cope Notes is not a replacement for therapy. He said he feels Cope Notes is a resource that can be used to get someone ready for treatment in therapy, or help someone who has finished their therapy have some consistent support.
"I would say it's a great step up or step down [from therapy]," Crowder said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Melas til Monday Director Recognized for Efforts to Feed Children in the Summer
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Melas til Monday director recognized for efforts to feed children in the summer

 June 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 435
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — MidShore Meals til Monday's Executive Director Pam Allen was recognized as one of 11 Summer Hunger Heroes by No Kid Hungry on Tuesday."I don't do what I do for recognition," Allen said {span}in an interview following the rollout event for Meals til Monday's summer program, where she received the award.{/span} "I understand that there's a need in the community, and it's not about myself. As I said Tuesday, this is about Meals til Monday as a whole, but it really felt good to be honored."
Allen began working volunteering for Meals til Monday during the pandemic. She then obtained her community health worker certificate to help people access services like Medicare and Medicaid. Allen said this naturally aligned with her work at Meals til Monday.
Her recognition comes after a yearlong process of filing for grants, receiving donations and working with community organization partners to buy a refrigerated van, which allows Meals til Monday's summer program to reach more children in Dorchester County and expands the program's capabilities.
"It's not necessarily about how many more kids that we're reaching as much as it's about what else we can give the kids," Allen said. With the van, Allen said they are able to pick up large bins, also known as gaylords, of produce and frozen foods that would otherwise go bad.
Summer is identified by Food Action and Research Center as the hungriest time for kids because they lose access to free school meals. In Dorchester County, students are provided free daily breakfast and lunch through a federally funded program called the Community Eligibility Provision.
This provision is available if 25% or more of the student population participate in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, the Food Distribution Program on Indian Reservations or Medicaid, according to the United States Department of Agriculture's website.
"We have partnered with Dorchester County Public Schools and we are delivering two meals for seven days to anyone that registers for children 18 and under," Allen said.
Allen said Meals til Monday is still providing regular weekend meal bags for anyone who needs them, and emergency food services are available with options for pick-up or delivery by appointment.
Allen encourages anyone who wants to volunteer to sign up on the website. "One of the things that we're trying to do as we continue to grow as an organization is to have the appropriate policies and waivers and things like that for our volunteers." Those can be found at midshoremealstilmonday.org.
"It feels absolutely wonderful. I am just so honored," Allen said about receiving recognition from No Kid Hungry. "Our primary mission is to feed children." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on child nutrition, hunger relief, and a community health worker role, aligning most closely with health concerns.

title: Opioid Restitution Funds to Focus on Schools and Health Education
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Opioid Restitution Funds to focus on schools and health education

 August 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 518
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Centreville — With numerous proposed local projects dedicated to opioid awareness and limited federal funding, Queen Anne's County Commissioners prioritized public schools and the department of health educational support programs for opioid restitution funding Aug. 12.The county's Local Opioid Abatement Plan included several proposed projects to utilize local opioid restitution funds provided by the state to combat the opioid crisis. The county only has about $677,000 available in funding, and all the projects outlined total over $1 million, according to County Administrator Todd Mohn.
Queen Anne's County Public Schools Opioid Education Partnership will utilize $209,025 of the opioid restitution funds in preventing youth opioid misuse through a school-based program and student-led awareness campaigns. It also aims to educate the broader community through public events, and distributing data-rich materials.
Queen Anne's County Department of Health Educational Support programs will be provided $89,251 to strengthen overdose education, prevention, and response.
This project also includes a re-entry program for individuals released from the detention center and an expansion to the court-assisted recovery program to provide alternatives to incarceration.
The commissioners reached a consensus to reconsider other programs at a future time as additional resources and partnerships become available.
Counties were awarded Maryland's opioid restitution funds to have autonomy to create plans on how to address avoiding addiction in communities, according to County Health Officer Brice Strang.
Programs that were traditionally funded have been denied funding this year, including the public school program, he said.
Strang is now recommending the Board of Health create a county evidence-based mechanism to support current programming and showcase how it is working in the community, such as the school based programing. Strang recommended using the funding to backfill the programs, and "wait and see" on federal and state funding.
A constant messaging to youth in particular is important, he said, and the commissioners praised the works of the Drug Free Coalition, the Student Ambassadors, and county partnerships.
"One of the things we already know is prevention is cheaper than treatment," Strang said.
Remembering when programs initially began, Commission President Chris Corchiarino noted just how far the community has come in regard to opioid awareness and preventing overdoses.
To continually keep overdose numbers down, Corchiarino said, new initiatives are always needed to keep awareness moving forward and make sure preventive programs stay at the forefront.
"And that forefront is in our schools, for sure," Commissioner Phil Dumenil said.
More information about Queen Anne's County Drug Free Coalition can be found at qacgoespurple.org.
In other business it was noted, phase three of the South Island Trail extension project took one step closer as a construction and paving bid was awarded to David A. Bramble Inc. in the amount of $593,030.
This approximately 3,500 feet portion of the project faced time constraints due to its wooded and wildlife areas and is set to begin Sept. 1.
With a grant through the Maryland Office of Tourism Development, Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development will be taking the show on the road with a mobile visitors center trailer to be purchased from Advantage Trailers for $91,778.
The trailer will serve to elevate tourism throughout the county by strategically placing it in high traffic areas and events. 

 © Copyright © 2025

title: Candidates File for May Primary Election
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Candidates file for May primary election

 February 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 597
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Voters across the state and on the Mid-Shore will have a full slate of candidates to vote for in this year's upcoming elections.Although 2024 will be marked nationally by a presidential election, Maryland residents will be casting their ballots for a U.S. senator and congressional representative. Locally, Mid-Shore residents will be voting for new county Board of Education members.
Maryland's primary election will be held on Tuesday, May 14, from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. Early primary voting will run from Thursday, May 2, to Thursday, May 9.
The general election is Tuesday, Nov. 5, from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. Early voting runs from Thursday, Oct. 24, to Thursday, Oct. 31.
U.S. Senate
The race for the next U.S. senator is a crowded one — 10 Democrats and eight Republicans have filed to run for the seat being vacated by current U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin. Three candidates not affiliated with either party have filed to run.
Several candidates are previous or current elected officials.
Congressional District 1Incumbent Rep. Andy Harris, a Republican, is seeking to maintain his position representing the 1st District. He's not without challengers, though — four others have filed in the hopes of winning the seat.
Blane Miller and Blessing T. Oluwadare, both Democrats from Harford County, filed to run against Harris. Fellow Harford County resident Chris Bruneau Sr. is running in the race as a Republican.
Caroline County resident Michael Scott Lemon, a Republican, is hoping to win the seat.
Talbot County Board of EducationSeven candidates have filed to run in this year's election for the three open seats in District 2, District 5 and District 6 on the Talbot County Board of Education.
In District 2, incumbent Board of Education member and current Vice president Candace Henry is running for reelection to her seat. Residents Connie Loveland and Ann C. O'Connor also filed to run for the seat.
In District 5, current Board of Education member Anna Howie is running for her first full term on the board. Howie was appointed to the District 5 seat last October after former Board President Susan Delean-Botkin vacated the district seat.
Trappe resident Karla Wieland-Cherry is Howie's sole challenger in the District 5 race.
The Board's District 6 seat will be the only one definitely seeing a new face after this year's election — incumbent board member Mary Wheeler did not file to run again.
Easton residents Kerry Gunshenan and Cynthia Marrah Jurrius will face off for the District 6 seat.
Dorchester County Board of EducationEight candidates filed for the three open seats on the Dorchester County Board of Education. Incumbents from each district are running to maintain their seats on the board.
In Councilmanic District 1, current board President Michael Diaz Sr. is running for reelection. Diaz is being challenged by Brandy Dawson Cumberland and Lucas Thorpe.
In Councilmanic District 3, current board Vice President Susan V. Morgan is vying for reelection. Cambridge resident Christine LaMonica is seeking the seat as well.
Chris Wheedleton, the incumbent Councilmanic District 5 board member who was appointed to his seat last year, is running for a full term on the board in this year's election. Candidates Jerome J. Harris and Michael Hartford also are running for the open seat.
Caroline County Board of EducationAlthough the terms of three members of the five-member Caroline County Board of Education are ending this year, only two are up for election by the public: the District 1 and District 2 seats.
A third seat opening up this year will be filled by gubernatorial appointment.
No candidates have filed to run for the District 1 seat.
In District 2, Stefanie D. Johnson is the sole candidate seeking the open seat. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot Council Introduces 2025 Budget
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Talbot Council introduces 2025 budget

 April 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 511
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Tuesday evening, the Talbot County Council voted unanimously to introduce the proposed fiscal year 2025 general fund budget of $163,970,000.The budget will include an education increase of $3.65 million from the 2024 budget.
Talbot County Public Schools will receive $54.6 million in total funding, according to the proposed budget. This increase will go toward the capital project request for planned Chapel District Elementary School renovations and other capital projects.
The increase in the education budget is due, in part, to the implications of the Maryland Blueprint for Education plan. Blueprint is a plan passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education across the state by increasing education funding by $3.8 billion each year over the next 10 years.
"Maryland Blueprint required local share funding to increase by $1.053 million for FY2025 budget," Martha Sparks, finance director for Talbot County, said at the Tuesday meeting. "In addition to the mandated funding, the county has included an additional appropriation of $2.6 million. Funding to support Talbot County Schools increased overall by $3.65 million above FY24 levels."
Education spending represents 37.7% of the county's total proposed budget. These numbers include Talbot County Public Schools, Chesapeake College and the Talbot County Free Library expenses.
The budget also allocates an additional $1.5 million in capital improvement project funding for Talbot County Public Schools to prioritize other projects.
The budget discussion included the option to expand the amendment of the 1-cent increase in property tax rates for public safety.
In November 2020, Talbot County voters approved an amendment allowing a 1-cent increase to the property tax rate to support public safety spending. This increase began in the FY2022 budget and will continue until the FY2026 budget.
Revenues from the 1-cent increase have been used to fund 26 new public safety positions across departments, such as deputies, paramedics, emergency medical technicians and 911 operators. The funds from the amendment have allowed for inclusion of sheriff's office, paramedics/EMTs and correctional officers in enhanced retirement programs for public safety employees.
Sparks noted that the county has used more than the funds provided by the 1-cent increase to public safety.
"The county has used more than the revenues generated from the 1 cent to enhance public safety personnel serving the citizens and visitors of Talbot County," she said.
The council has the option to allow county residents to extend the 1-cent increase beyond FY2026 through a ballot initiative for voters in the November 2024 general election.
Clay Stamp, county manager for Talbot County, expressed his admiration for the county's finance team for their work on the budget.
"There's a lot of hard work that went into drafting the FY 25 proposed balanced budget," Stamp said. "While we're here tonight, I want to thank the council for your cooperation and support over the last number of months."
Two public hearings will be held to gather community input before final approval.
A public hearing will be held on May 7 at 2 p.m. in the Talbot County Courthouse and at 7 p.m. in the Easton Elementary School cafeteria, located at 307 Glenwood Avenue. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
