title: MACo Leaders Meet with Talbot Officials to Discuss 2026 General Assembly
author: Konner Metz
content:
MACo leaders meet with Talbot officials to discuss 2026 General Assembly

 September 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Leaders from the Maryland Association of Counties shared predictions for a calmer legislative session in 2026 during a meeting with the Talbot County Council on Tuesday.Michael Sanderson, MACo's executive director, and Jack Wilson, the association's president and current Queen Anne's County commissioner, met for an annual check-in with Talbot officials.
Sanderson reminded the council members of last year's volatile General Assembly session, during which legislators and Gov. Wes Moore (D) had to reckon with closing a $3 billion gap in the state's fiscal year 2026 budget.
Some savings came through cost shifts placing more burden on county governments, the MACo leaders said. But they added that the upcoming 2026 session, and the fiscal year 2027 budget that goes along with it, likely won't be as dire.
"Relatively calm, probably not a big crisis," Sanderson said of his projection for this year's session, which officially kicks off Jan. 14 in Annapolis.
He said the large budgetary concerns are likely to reappear in 2027 as legislators put together a plan for fiscal year 2028.
"The story from last year is gonna repeat itself, but with a year off," Sanderson predicted.
Specifically, the executive director said Maryland's expansive education funding formula, The Blueprint, will influence the 2027 session. And in the short-term, some counties are already coming to grips with increasing cost shares for education.
"Every county is either in the midst or a year or two away from seeing a year where the increase in school spending required under Blueprint requires all the money or even more money than your county's likely to gain in revenue for that year," Sanderson said. "It's an obvious squeeze at the local level."
Talbot County's fiscal year 2026 budget included $55 million in education funding required by The Blueprint's formulas. On top of that, the council approved an additional $600,000 in funding to fill new positions.
That mark had been scaled back twice from the original ask the Talbot Board of Education made of the council — first requesting $5.5 million in supplementary funds, then $1.1 million.
County Council Vice President Pete Lesher, who supported the district's $1.1 million request earlier this year, said it was "short-sighted" for the county to only fund the district's request partially, given that Blueprint requirements are only set to increase in future years. But other council members opted to hold back on dedicating the full request as the county aimed to even out its spending hikes seen in years prior.
Sanderson said on Tuesday that housing legislation will be at the forefront this winter. Recently, Moore signed an executive order that aims to speed up the permitting and building of affordable housing projects.
"I anticipate that being a big fight," Sanderson said. "Whether it's a big fight in the more rural jurisdictions is yet to be seen."
Council Member Lynn Mielke asked how Easton fits into state plans to tackle the housing issue.
Sanderson said there's an opportunity for MACo to advocate for provisions so a potential housing package doesn't "overwhelm" local jurisdictions. He said the association can help push for certain changes to help counties and towns that lack authority in certain areas, such as the variation of impact fees on developers.
"At the same time, we generally want to keep land use decisions local," he added. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Jack Wilson — President, Maryland Association of Counties and Commissioner, Queen Anne's County

title: School Bus Crash Sends 11 to Hospital
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
School bus crash sends 11 to hospital

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1A | Section: News 
 
 425
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Eleven patients were transported to the hospital following a crash between a SUV and a Caroline County school bus near the intersection of Matthewstown Road and Three Bridge Branch Road just before 8 a.m.Monday morning.According to a preliminary investigation by Maryland State Police, a Kia Sportage failed to stop at a stop sign at a four-way intersection and crashed into the side of the bus.The school bus rolled over.According to a statement from Caroline County Public Schools, the bus was transporting high school students involved in the Navy Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps program to Easton High School. Nine students and the bus driver were transported to area hospitals. All parents of children on the bus were notified.The juvenile driver of the Kia Sportage, whose identity is being withheld by police at this time, was transported to an area hospital for treatment of injuries.In an email sent to parents Monday morning, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the driver was an Easton High School student.Police said the cause of the crash is under investigation. Charges may be filed pending the outcome of the investigation.Fog blanketed the area around the time of the crash. Neither Talbot County Public Schools nor Caroline County Public Schools issued a fog delay earlier in the morning.Troopers from the Maryland State Police Easton Barrack, Commercial Vehicle Enforcement Division and crash team responded to the scene to assist.All lanes on Matthewstown Road at Three Bridge Branch Road were closed for several hours during the investigation.Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and Caroline County Sheriff's Office also responded to the scene to assist. 
 
 Caption: TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A school bus lays on its side in the roadway following a Monday morning crash involving this SUV.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A cadet field manual lies next to the overturned bus and some broken glass. The bus was delivering Caroline County NJROTC students to Easton High School. Eleven people were injured in the crash.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A member of Maryland State Police inspects the bottom of the bus that turned over at the intersection of Route 328 and Three Bridge Branch Road on Monday, Oct. 30. The rear and roof escape hatches are open.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Although the bus crash occurred at the intersection of Route 328 and Three Bridge Branch Road, side roads were blocked off. They closed off Route 328 at Black Dog Alley. They closed off the other side of Route 328 at Councell Road. They would only let the parents of the students through and emergency services.

title: Students Evacuated for Bomb Threat at Easton Middle School
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Students evacuated for bomb threat at Easton Middle School

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 280
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Students and staff at Easton Middle School were evacuated Wednesday morning after the school administration received a bomb threat.According to a news release from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, front desk staff at the middle school received a bomb threat via telephone around 9:25 a.m.Wednesday.The caller said there were numerous explosive devices throughout the building that would detonate at a specified time, police said.Police said all identified calls were made from a New Jersey area code.School officials followed emergency policies and safely evacuated students and staff to St. Marks Methodist Church in Easton.Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office responded to the school and began investigating. Bomb detecting K-9 teams also responded to the building to complete a scan.Similar threats were made to schools across the state, including schools in Frederick, Carroll, Charles and Wicomico counties, police said.Students and staff were allowed to return to the building when the K-9 scan was completed.Police said there are no identified subjects and investigation is ongoing.Anyone with information is asked to contact the Talbot County Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020, by email at sheriff@talbotcountymd.gov, on Facebook at Talbot County Sheriff or online at talbotsheriff.org.

Law enforcement officers convene in front of Easton Middle School, where a bomb threat was called in Wednesday morning. The children were evacuated to St. Mark's Methodist Church.

title: Teens Charged With Assaulting School Staff Members in Separate Incidents
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Teens charged with assaulting school staff members in separate incidents

 March 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 224
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Two Talbot County teens were arrested and referred to the Department of Juvenile Services on separate assault charges last week.According to a news release from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, deputies from the School Resource Unit charged a 15-year-old with assault and disrupting school activities on Tuesday, March 5. Police said the Easton High School student was reported assaulting a 73-year-old substitute teacher.
According to the news release, the deputies obtained footage of the incident.
Police said the video showed the teen knocking the teacher off of a stool and onto the floor, standing on top of the teacher and threatening to assault the teacher more. The video shows another student intervening to stop the assault.
Police said the 15-year-old was issued a juvenile referral and released to a guardian "pending further action by the Department of Juvenile Services."
On Friday, police said deputies from the School Resource Unit charged a 15-year-old student at St. Michael's Middle High School with assault.
Police reported the student assaulted the school manager in the presence of the school resource officer. According to the news release, when the school resource officer tried to take the teen into custody, the teen pulled away and attempted to flee.
Police said the teen was taken into custody and issued a juvenile referral to the Department of Juvenile Services before being released to their mother.

title: Assault at Easton High School Sends Student to Hospital
author: Staff Report
content:
Assault at Easton High School sends student to hospital

 September 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 257
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Sheriff's Office is investigating the circumstances surrounding an assault that took place at Easton High School, located on the 700 block of Mecklenburg Avenue, on Sep. 10.At approximately 12:06 p.m., the deputy assigned as the school resource officer at Easton High School was alerted to an assault occurring inside of the school.
Deputies initiated an investigation into the circumstances surrounding the assault, in conjunction with the Easton High School administrative staff and the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office.
Pursuant to the investigation, two juveniles, who are students at the school, were identified and arrested in relation to the assault. Deputies were also able to identify two victims of the assault. One of the victims is an Easton High School staff member and the second victim is a juvenile student at the school.
The juvenile victim was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton via the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services for treatment of non-life-threatening injuries.
The juvenile suspects were transported to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office for booking and processing. They were charged with first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment and several other charges relating to the incident.
The Talbot County Sheriff's Office will be contacting the Department of Juvenile Services to obtain a release disposition for both suspects.
Easton High School was placed on a brief lockdown during this event.
If anyone has information they are requested to contact the Talbot County Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020, by email at sheriff@talbotcountymd.gov, on Facebook at Talbot County Sheriff or on our website at talbotsheriff.org. 

 © Copyright 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Videos of Easton High School Assault Circulate Online
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Videos of Easton High School assault circulate online

 September 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Crime 
 
 406
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Videos showing the Tuesday assault at Easton High School have been circulating online. The incident involved three students and one staff member and ended with a student being transported to a hospital for non-life-threatening injuries.According to a press release released by the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, the assault happened on Tuesday afternoon. The videos paint a picture of the incident, though no further official statement has been released by law enforcement on the assault.
In the videos, a group of students are circling around the three students involved in the assault. Seconds into the video, one student in a black hoodie moves toward a student in a red hoodie and assaults him. The student in red falls to the floor. Immediately following, an additional student in a gray hoodie proceeds to join in the assault.
In the video, a male staff member in a white shirt attempts to protect the student that is being assaulted and physically puts his body on top of the student, seemingly to act as a barrier between the students.
The other two students seemingly continue to assault the student in red and begin to also assault the staff member. Soon after, other staff members intervene and separate the students and defuse the situation. The incident lasted around 30 seconds.
Deputies were able to identify two victims of the assault, one was an Easton High School staff member and the second was a student of the school. No identities have been released, and the incident is currently under investigation.
The assault resulted in one student being transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton via Talbot County Department of Emergency Services to be treated for non-life-threatening injuries, police said.
The two other students in the video were identified and arrested in relation to the assault.
According to a statement from Debbie Gardner, director of communications for Talbot County Public Schools, the event is being evaluated and those involved will face appropriate disciplinary action.
"The safety of our students and staff is always our top priority. We are grateful for our partnership with the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and the presence of School Resource Officers in our schools," the statement said. "Deputy Horseman, along with several other Sheriff's deputies and members of the Easton High staff responded quickly to contain the incident. The students involved will face appropriate disciplinary action, and we are continuously evaluating safety measures to prevent or mitigate incidents of this nature." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

The Talbot County Sheriff’s Office launched an investigation, while Talbot County Public Schools, via communications director Debbie Gardner, condemned the incident and urged the public not to share the footage.

title: Updated: Social Media Post 'Not a Threat' to Easton Schools, TCPS Says
author: Tom McCall
content:
UPDATED: Social media post 'not a threat' to Easton schools, TCPS says

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: News 
 
 245
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Students in Talbot County Public Schools were put in a modified lockdown after a threatening social media post was made Friday morning. According to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.A message sent to families in the district later that morning stated that the Talbot County Sheriff's Office confirmed the incident was "not a threat to our schools or community."
"They are continuing to investigate and will notify us if any additional information is received," the message said. "Thank you for your support in keeping our students and staff safe."
"We got a notification from Easton, Pennsylvania that they got the same exact notice," said Talbot County Sheriff's Office Public Information Officer John Bollinger. "It is all over and it is Friday the 13th and somebody felt like having some fun. From what we can tell so far, the threat originated from out of the country."
An initial message sent to parents of TCPS students Friday morning said, "We have increased police presence at schools this morning as a precautionary measure."
"The kids aren't outside," Bollinger said. "There have been some very generic threats, nothing specific, so we are just going above and beyond."
"... They are not letting anyone out doing outside activities and limiting kids in the hallway," he said.
Easton Police Department is assisting the sheriff's office in investigating the situation and monitoring the school.
This report may be updated. 

 © Copyright 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot County Sheriffs' Office Investigating Another Threat, Threat Not Specific to TCPS
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Talbot County Sheriffs' Office investigating another threat, threat not specific to TCPS

 September 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: News 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — After a threatening social media post on Friday was determined to not be a threat to Easton schools, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office is investigating another threat that has been circulating on social media.Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said Monday morning that the threat, which originated on Instagram, is not a specific threat to Talbot County Public Schools, but to the 410 area code. He said the threat is a photo of a "clearly" photoshopped Instagram message that includes the 410 area code.
"We're taking it very seriously, as we do every threat," Gamble said, adding that, through investigation, the Sheriff's Office doesn't think there is "any viable threat to the safety" of TCPS students.
According to a letter from the district addressed to TCPS families, the district is "closely monitoring the situation" and working with local authorities. The letter says that school operations will continue as normal.
Gamble said a criminal investigation by the Sheriff's Office is underway. He said all school resource officers in the district are aware of the threat, and extra deputies are patrolling.
On Friday, TCPS students were put in a modified lockdown following a threatening social media post made that morning. According to the Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.
Gamble said the Sheriff's officer is aware of jurisdictions in other states that "have had 40 or 50 of these types of threats."
"It's happening all over our country where, for whatever reason, somebody is trying to disrupt school operations and put our kids in fear," he said.
Gamble said that a few years back, the district experienced something similar where about half a dozen non-specific threats were made during the course of the school year. He said he would expect to see more of these threats this year.
"This just seems like the thing to do these days for some reason," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: UPDATED: Easton High School Evacuating Due to Bomb Threat
author: Staff Report
content:
UPDATED: Easton High School evacuating due to bomb threat

 September 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 EASTON — Students and staff at Easton High School are evacuating after a bomb threat made Monday afternoon, according to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office.At 2:57 p.m., the Talbot County Sheriff's Office said in a release posted to Facebook that deputies are on scene at the school. Earlier on Monday, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office said it was investigating a threat made on social media.
Sheriff Joe Gamble said Monday morning that the threat, which originated on Instagram, was not a specific threat to Talbot County Public Schools, but to the 410 area code. It was not immediately shared by law enforcement if the Easton High lockdown resulted from this threat or from a separate threat.
On Monday morning, Gamble said all school resource officers in the district were aware of the threat, and extra deputies were patrolling.
On Friday, TCPS students were put in a modified lockdown following a threatening social media post made that morning. According to the Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.

title: Police Charge Suspect in Connection with Easton High Bomb Threat
author: Staff Report
content:
Police charge suspect in connection with Easton High bomb threat

 September 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 385
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A 17-year-old suspect has been charged in connection with a bomb threat that forced an evacuation at Easton High School Monday.In a social media post on Facebook, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office announced detectives located the residence of a 17-year-old female and charged her with "making a threat of mass violence." Police say she is not enrolled in the Talbot County Public Schools system.
Students and staff were evacuated out of EHS on Monday afternoon after the threat was made just after 2 p.m. Police say a caller contacted the front desk and "advised that there was a bomb inside of the school and hung up."
"The caller re-contacted the front desk staff a few minutes later and asked when dismissal was," the Talbot County Sheriff's Office stated.
Police stated EHS staff immediately notified the school resource officer of the threat, leading to a quick evacuation from the building. The sheriff's office said all students and staff were safely evacuated as of Monday afternoon.
Deputies responded to the school, and bomb-detecting K-9 teams searched the building and surrounding property. Once cleared, staff returned to the school building.
"I am so grateful for the outstanding work our Talbot Deputies, Easton Police Officers, and our Talbot County Department of Emergency Services Dispatchers performed today to identify the caller of the bomb threat," Sheriff Joe Gamble said in a release.
"Within two hours the suspect was identified, located and charged," he said. "The teachers and staff at Easton High worked tirelessly with law enforcement to make sure everyone was safe. We are so fortunate to have such dedicated professionals in our community who work very hard to keep our children safe."
Deputies are working with the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office and "will be seeking additional charges if applicable," the sheriff's office said.
At Monday's Easton Town Council meeting, Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello thanked staff and first responders who handled the situation on Monday.
"I want to offer my sincere thanks to the teachers and the staff, and the first responders who attended the bomb threat today at Easton High School," Abbatiello said. "You all were professional in caring for our children and put them first. In this day and age, you cannot be too careful."
Anyone with information is asked to contact the Talbot County Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020.
This report may be updated.

title: Caroline County School Bus Slides Off Holly Road
author: Tom McCall
content:
Caroline County school bus slides off Holly Road

 September 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 212
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — A school bus with students aboard slid into a ditch on Holly Road Wednesday. A Caroline County school district official said no one was injured.It was a rainy and slick road that the No. 7 bus was traveling to take students home from North Caroline High School and Lockerman Middle School Wednesday afternoon.
"Bus 7 was involved in a minor accident in which no injuries were incurred," said Sandi Barry of the Caroline County school district. "Families of students from NCHS and LMS were notified that student drop off at stops would be approximately 45 minutes late."
Kristie Thompson, a Greensboro resident, had a friend who was a school monitor on the bus behind No. 7.
"Supposedly a mail truck stopped in front of the bus to deliver mail," Thompson said. "The bus hit the brakes and went into the ditch."
The bus fell not quite on its side, its right front and right rear tires in the ditch.
Holly Road is used as a detour for the construction underway on River Road.
According to a text sent from the Ridgely Elementary School administration, "Bus 7 is currently running late due to an issue on an earlier run."
A voicemail message left for the Caroline County Sheriff's Office for further details was not returned Wednesday evening.

title: Queen Anne's County High School Gets School Security Grant
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's County High School gets school security grant

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 308
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Queen Anne's County High School has recently been awarded $70,000 to pursue the hiring of the district's first School Security Employee (SSE), according to Joe Saboury, coordinator of school safety and security.As of August, the district received funding from the Maryland Center for School Safety School Resource Officer (SRO) Adequate Coverage Grant under the 2018 Maryland Safe to Learn Act, Saboury said.
This funding allows school districts to hire an employee to serve as a supplement to the SRO already in place, he said. Resource officers already serving the school district fall under the direction and budget of the county sheriff's office.
The statewide grant funding assists in supplementing law enforcement coverage for public schools with $10 to 15 million in FY26 and $20 million in FY27 and each year thereafter, he said.
As school security is considered a top state priority, a minimum three years of funding following this year is secured, according to Saboury.
"So really that's putting additional eyes and ears in our schools, which is a wonderful thing," he said.
As a member of the district, the SSE works more closely with school leaders on safety measures, often outside law enforcement scopes, and are more closely involved with student behavior, support and providing intervention to mitigate and prevent harm, he said.
As district employees, QACPS has the flexibility to utilize SSEs for after school sporting events or field trips Saboury said.
"It's a great resource that the school district has never had before," he said.
SSEs are held to the same standards and certification programs through the Maryland for School Safety Model training as SROs.
Training, uniforms, equipment and overtime are all budgeted into the grant with no cost the district, he said.
With the potential for increased funding down the road, Saboury was hopeful to be able to build the program and continually create a safe learning environment for students. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat. All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a grant to hire a School Security Employee and improve safety measures in a public school, which is primarily a public safety issue rather than general education content.

Coordinator Joe Saboury said the money implements provisions of the 2018 Maryland Safe to Learn Act, enhancing safety for students and staff.

title: Police, EMS Perform Active Shooter Drills at School
author: Konner Metz
content:
Police, EMS perform active shooter drills at school

 July 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Newsletters 
 
 187
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Local police and emergency medical professionals took part in a serious training of the utmost importance in Easton on Thursday.Active shooter situations in elementary and secondary schools caused 328 deaths from 2000 to 2022, according to the National Center for Education Statistics.
That's why before every school year, local first responders have made it a habit to complete active shooter trainings. This year's training brought Talbot and Caroline sheriff's deputies, Easton police, local EMTs and paramedics, and others to The Country School.
Caroline County Cpl. Kenny Tull led a drill Thursday afternoon, showing me just how critical it is that first responders from different counties to work together cohesively under stress.
And the results were enlightening: officers and EMTs didn't always make the correct decision every split-second, but they did confer with each other on what steps to take during the next drill, learning how to get better along the way.
To learn more about the training, read my story below. Also in today's newsletter: Talbot Mentors helps local students achieve their goals, a conservation easement will become a public park in Dorchester County and more.
Thanks for reading.
— Konner Metz 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

The exercise, aided by Talbot Mentors, aimed to improve emergency preparedness for students and staff.

title: Seconds Count: The Country School Hosts Active Shooter Training for Law Enforcement, EMS
author: Konner Metz
content:
Seconds count: The Country School hosts active shooter training for law enforcement, EMS

 July 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 591
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With schools starting back up next month, police and first responders gathered at The Country School in Easton on Thursday to partake in active shooter training.Four separate drills took place Thursday. Officers entered the school to take down a mock shooter. They joined with paramedics and EMTs to locate mock students in classrooms, assess their injuries and evacuate them from the building in a safe manner.
Responders often communicated with one another on how to follow the proper incident command tactics, at times acknowledging the improvements they could make to their decisions during the drill. Caroline County Cpl. Kenny Tull said the drills will help improve all aspects of emergency response if a school shooting occurs on the Mid-Shore.
"It's a learning experience for everyone," Tull said.
In previous years, active shooter training took place at schools in Talbot and Caroline counties.
Recently, the drills have included a team of both law enforcement and EMS personnel called the Rescue Task Force. Once a hallway or area is cleared, officers will protect unarmed EMTs and paramedics in "warm zones," where danger may still exist even if the main threat is eliminated.
That practice is life-saving in a real situation, Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said.
"Before, (EMS personnel) didn't go in until the building got cleared, which caused more deaths," he said. "The quicker we can get treatment for people, the quicker we can get paramedics in there with us, the more people that hopefully will survive."
Still, the top priority is eliminating the shooter or main threat.
"The initial driving force is stop the killing, because the statistics will show you that an assailant can kill more people than you can treat," Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said.
"Their driving force is stop the dying," Lowrey said of EMTs and paramedics. "You toggle between those two driving forces."
Gamble said first responders have taken FEMA-required incident command training, which serves as a common baseline for members of different agencies.
"A lot of this stuff spawned out of 9/11, getting fire, police, paramedics everybody on the same page. Square up communications," Gamble said.
Having so many agencies on hand Thursday was an opportunity for first responders to acclimate with one another and become more comfortable working together during an emergency response, agency leaders said.
Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker emphasized that local agencies already share a solid rapport.
"You'd be surprised how much there is interaction between counties and agencies," Baker said.
Plus, the geography of Mid-Shore counties sometimes means Caroline County police may be first on the scene to a Talbot County emergency, or vice versa.
"For something that happens at Preston Elementary, Talbot County will be the first ones there," Talbot County Maj. Steve Elliott said. "If something happens at Chapel Elementary, Caroline County will be the first ones there."
Tina Kintop, EMS division chief for the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, said it's most important for EMTs and paramedics to be disciplined and properly trained to participate in the rescue task force with police.
On Thursday, the drills didn't stop when the mock shooter went down. First responders secured students, assessed the severity of their injuries and evacuated them from the building. The job doesn't end there, Kintop said.
Police and EMS focus on locating a site for reunification of families. Gamble said different schools already have plans in place for reunification spots, some of which have been used for fire drills or bomb threats in the past.
By practicing these processes Thursday, agencies worked to create a streamlined plan they hope they will never have to use.
"It's all about organization and accountability," Kintop said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Two Students Arrested After Fights at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Two students arrested after fights at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School

 September 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 335
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Two students from Cambridge-South Dorchester High School were arrested on the second day of school after multiple fights broke out, Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips said.The school resource deputy alerted the Sheriff's Office that a student was assaulting the school safety monitor. Before it was over, Phillips said several deputies and school staff were assaulted, and one staff member was taken to the hospital. Phillips did not disclose the extent of their injuries, but he said that everyone was going to be OK.
The school safety monitor received multiple blows to the head and was held down on the floor, and three deputies were spat on by students, Phillips said.
"That's a biological thing, you just don't know what you're dealing with, now they have to get tests done," Phillips said.
Phillips said the incident was prompted by something that happened outside of school. He did not provide further details on what incited the fighting.
The response from law enforcement was substantial, including 10 Cambridge police officers, seven sheriff's deputies and five state troopers.
"A majority of law enforcement in our small geographical area was at C-SD," Phillips said.
Public details are limited due to the involvement of juveniles, but a 15-year-old was arrested and charged with five counts of second-degree assault, resisting arrest, disorderly conduct, failure to obey a lawful order, disturbing the peace, disrupting school activities, obstructing and hindering, and affray, according to the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office press release.
The second student arrested was 14 years old. The student was charged with one count of second-degree assault, disorderly conduct, failure to obey a reasonable and lawful order, disturbing the peace, disrupting school operations, obstructing and hindering, and affray, according to the press release.
"The crowd was actually larger than that (the two arrests). A lot of onlookers with their cameras and stuff," Phillips said.
The two juveniles were taken to the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office, then released to their guardians with referrals made to the Department of Juvenile Services, according to the press release.
This report may be updated. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Woman Charged for Graffiti Acts at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary
author: Konner Metz
content:
Woman charged for graffiti acts at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary

 September 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 719
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A woman is being held at the Talbot County Detention Center after being accused of spray-painting graffiti around town, including at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary School.Sian Radaskiewicz-King, 32, was arrested Friday by Easton police on charges of malicious destruction of property and use of a hate symbol. She was later charged with defacing religious property and disturbing school operations, among other counts.
According to court documents, King allegedly spray-painted the transgender symbol on dumpsters, the sidewalk and a step outside the Catholic school off of Route 50. Other spray-painted symbols were found on a fence at the Hampton Inn next to the school, per court records.
The symbols were found elsewhere in town, including outside East End Liquors, The Market at Dover Station and other businesses. The transgender symbol, often used to encourage gender inclusivity, is a combination of the male and female signs.
At an unusually crowded bail hearing on Monday afternoon, Talbot County District Court Judge Karen Ketterman ordered King to be held without bond in the Detention Center. A trial is scheduled for Oct. 28.
Many parents and school officials from Sts. Peter and Paul filled the courtroom. School Board Chair Peggy Wilson asked Ketterman to not approve King's release. Wilson cited the Aug. 27 shooting at Annunciation Catholic School in Minneapolis, which killed two children and injured 18 people, as a reason why the school community is concerned for the safety of students.
"Our fear is not the symbol itself, but the possibility of a copycat situation," Wilson said.
King, according to public legal representation, is transgender. She previously attended Sts. Peter and Paul School.
The Minneapolis shooter, Robin Westman, was referred to as transgender by federal officials. Westman's gender identity wasn't clear, according to The Associated Press.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook said in a statement this weekend that the graffiti incidents are "especially painful" given the Minneapolis Catholic school shooting.
"It reminds us of the responsibility we all share to ensure our children's safety and well-being," Cook wrote. "We condemn such acts of intimidation, they have no place in our community."
In a statement Sunday, the Delmarva Pride Center condemned the graffiti acts as a "misuse" of the international transgender symbol.
"We are deeply troubled that an LGBTQIA+ symbol was misused in a way that could be construed as hateful," the statement read. "Symbols such as the Transgender Symbol exist to affirm identity, celebrate diversity, and foster belonging — not to spread fear or division.
"This incident occurs at a time when Transgender people continue to face targeted attacks in society. We call on our neighbors, allies, and community members to stand together, to reject hate in all its forms, and to embrace the values of acceptance, compassion, and love."
On Monday, Easton Police Deputy Chief Greg Wright said the agency will increase patrol this week at Sts. Peter and Paul School and other schools in town. He said police "have no reason to believe that there was any attempt or desire to harm anyone."
BOND DECISION
Bridgette Lane, an assistant at the Talbot County public defender's office, argued in court on Monday that King should be granted release based on the low severity of charges, an otherwise clean criminal record and the Detention Center's recommendation.
Lane said King has "expressed remorse" and understands "she can't be acting out in these ways."
King, who is listed as having a Baltimore address, was recently staying in Easton with her mother, Lane said. If released, the expectation was for King to stay with her mother.
Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said the graffiti incident is concerning due to the context of the Minneapolis shooting last month, as well as the fact that King's mother's house is close to the school.
"Here we have this clear warning sign," Coale said. " ... We don't know if the defendant is capable of carrying out something worse. But the state doesn't want to find out."
Ketterman said both sides made good points, but she hammered home that there are "no conditions of release" that would ensure the safety of the community. The judge said she's concerned about the location of the graffiti and King's documented mental health diagnoses, which include bipolar disorder and PTSD.
"I don't think the court has another choice," Ketterman said after ruling no bond and ordering the defendant complete a mental health evaluation.
Information from The Associated Press contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Sheriff: Youth Justice Laws Add to Crime
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Sheriff: Youth justice laws add to crime

 September 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Crime 
 
 539
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — In the past week, there have been three juvenile arrests related to violent crimes in the City of Cambridge.Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips said this level of violent crime is "not normal" and officers feel their hands are tied by the current juvenile justice laws Phillips said lack accountability.
On the second day of school at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School last week, two students were arrested after assaulting the school safety monitor. Phillips described the scene as a "melee."
Phillips said three sheriff's deputies were spat on and the school safety monitor was taken to the hospital. Two boys, ages 14 and 15, were arrested following the incident.
The 15-year-old boy, Jaheem Mortaz Brown, was released to his step-father's custody. Three days later, the Brown allegedly shot his step-father in the face. The extent of the step-father's injuries has not been disclosed.
In addition, Phillips said Cambridge police received a call this weekend that juveniles around 11 years old were shoplifting from the Wawa on Sunburst Highway.
"They're shoplifting because they know they (the juvenile system) can't do nothing with them," Phillips said.
Phillips said the problem of juvenile crime will continue until the "broken juvenile justice system" is changed.
"The juvenile justice system in the state of Maryland is broken; it's not working," he said. "We're not holding anybody accountable."
The former Secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services, Vincent Schiraldi received intense backlash from Mid-Shore sheriffs, including Phillips. The Maryland Sheriffs Association sent a letter to Gov. Wes Moore calling for Schiraldi's immediate resignation last year. Schiraldi stepped down from the position in June.
"Consistently in Maryland, juveniles have been charged with serious violent crimes," the letter states, "only to be turned right back over to a parent or guardian, and back out on the streets to commit more crimes."
After an in-person community meeting with the secretary around two years ago, Phillips said "He had the audacity to tell us, 'The data that I'm receiving doesn't support your claim of increased juvenile crime,'" Phillips recalled. "And our reply to that was, 'Well, obviously the numbers are going to go down because you're not allowing us to charge (them) anymore.'"
In 2022, the Maryland General Assembly passed a juvenile justice reform bill stressing rehabilitation rather than punishment in addressing juvenile behavioral issues, according to its proponents. The reform took effect in 2024.
In August, the Cambridge Police Department presented its quarterly report, which revealed that overall crime decreased, but there were concerns regarding homicides, robberies and juvenile violence.
Homicides, assaults, larceny and motor vehicle theft all increased from the second quarter in 2024. The homicide rate rose 200%, with two homicides that both led to arrests. One of those homicides was committed by a juvenile.
Phillips said this level of violent crime in Cambridge is not normal.
"I mean, it's not normal anywhere, but I think the biggest contributing factor we had last week is the failure of our juvenile system," he said.
Last school year, students in Dorchester County saw 1,682 long- and short-term suspensions with 1,232 of those suspensions related to violence, according to Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson.
In an attempt to curb suspensions, Dorchester County Public Schools launched a violence prevention initiative course for students, teachers, parents and staff to ensure there is community participation. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on juvenile crime, sheriff statements, and law enforcement concerns, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic, though it also touches on school-related issues (Education) and local officials (Local Government).

Jymil Thompson — Superintendent, Dorchester County Public Schools

He and former juvenile services head Vincent Schiraldi urged Superintendent Jymil Thompson to reassess the law.

title: Electrical Fire Closes QA High School for a Day
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Electrical fire closes QA high school for a day

 September 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Fire crews initially dispatched for a fire alarm activation at Queen Anne's County High School discovered a small electrical fire around 7:13 p.m. Sept. 9.Interim Superintendent Matthew Kibler said in a letter to the school community that the fire broke out in a special education room Tuesday evening. The sprinkler system activated, limiting fire damage to the room where it started.
According to the Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal, the fire originated in a rear first-floor office. The preliminary cause was deemed accidental, the result of "an unspecified electrical event of a power surge protector."
The fire marshal estimated about $30,000 in structure and content damages. No injuries were reported.
A total of 36 firefighters responded, with Goodwill Volunteer Fire Company the primary agency in charge. The fire was brought under control in about 30 minutes, the fire marshal said.
The fire alarm company contacted 911, and the school custodian also discovered the fire after the alarm activation.
Water collected in a back hallway, one special education classroom, an office and a conference room as the sprinkler system ran for about 20 minutes, Kibler said.
Third-party contractors were brought in to evaluate and assist. Normal operations resumed Sept. 11, after the school was closed to students and non-essential personnel Wednesday to allow cleanup and assessment. Other Queen Anne's County Public Schools were not affected.
QACPS expressed gratitude to first responders, the Queen Anne's County Fire Marshal's Office, the Maryland State Deputy Fire Marshal, and its custodial and maintenance staff for their work in returning the building to use.
On its Facebook page, QACPS wrote: "We are thankful that there were no injuries, and our fire suppression system worked appropriately."
Questions should be directed to Principal Lou Sheppard, Kibler said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat. All rights reserved.

title: Unknown History: Black History Month Offers Opportunity to Recognize ‘The People’
author: Niambi Davis Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Unknown history: Black History Month offers opportunity to recognize ‘the people’

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 211
 Words 

 Read News Document

 This month, in community centers, libraries, schools and churches like Bethel AME Church in Centreville, when citizens gather to honor the nation's greatest champions for freedom, justice and equal rights, they also honor the people.In 1915, the historian Dr. Carter G. Woodson founded what is now the Association for the Study of African American Life and History. The following year, he began publishing what is now The Journal of African American History, a publication of history, research and book reviews.
In 1926, Woodson founded "Negro History Week" to honor the history, culture and contributions of African Americans. He chose February to coincide with the birthdays of Frederick Douglass and Abraham Lincoln. In 1976, President Gerald Ford extended the observation to a month, now known as Black History Month.
Woodson believed that history was "made by the people, not simply or primarily by great men."
Local writer, Niambi Davis had the opportunity to contribute to the Black History display at Bethel AME. The subjects, Davis said, "are important and more than just the usual Douglass and Tubman stories; they're the unknown local, national and international folks."
The display is open to the congregation and anyone wishing to attend services. Service begins at 11 a.m. Sunday mornings. The church is located on Washington Road in Centreville. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Black History Month, highlighting African American history, cultural contributions, and the importance of recognizing diverse individuals, which aligns directly with the Race & Diversity topic.

Niambi Davis — Writer, Contributor to Black History Display at Bethel AME

summary: Historian Carter G. Woodson’s legacy inspired a Black History Month exhibit at Bethel AME, where writer Niambi Davis highlighted overlooked African‑American figures. The Association for the Study of African American Life and History promoted the display in February 2024, echoing President Gerald Ford’s 1976 proclamation recognizing Black History Month.

title: Local Documentary is 'Going Places'
author: Will Bontrager
content:
Local documentary is 'going places'

 March 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 1002
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The trip started out by collecting soil on Cross Street in Chestertown. The location where James Taylor, a 23-year-old Black man, was lynched in 1892.That soil would find its way more than 800 miles south in a powerful message to remember a bleak chapter in history.
That journey was followed in the documentary film "Get on the Bus."
Forty-two Kent County youths and adults made the trek, traveling to Civil Rights era landmarks in Alabama and Georgia, including the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church in Birmingham; the King Center in Atlanta, Edmund Pettus Bridge and the National Voting Rights Museum in Selma and the Equal Justice Initiative's Community Remembrance Project in Montgomery.
Directed by Justinian Dispenza of Andover Media, the film debuted on Valentine's Day at the Decker Theatre in Washington College with almost 200 people in attendance. it was also shown the at Ocean City Film Festival earlier this month.
After its debut, the powerful emotions it invoked resulted in people interested in screening it.
For Dispenza, it's uplifting to see his work yielding these results.
"That's what we're all aiming to do as filmmakers. To make a change in people's lives. It was an incredible experience," he said.
As people left the theatre, Dispenza reflected on the process of creating "Get on the Bus" in slight awe.
Because it did not start out as being a film.
The idea initially came from Program Director of Minary's Dream Alliance Paul Tue III and Co-Chair of the James Taylor Justice Coalition Philip Dutton, to take a trip, educating people about the past, to the roots of the Civil Rights Movement, Alabama.
What started as a field trip where Dispenza was brought on to take pictures became something else.
Dispenza, no stranger to films about social issues, was eager.
Except there were obstacles.
Before they left, he was diagnosed with Lyme's Disease. Forced to take antibiotics on the road, he was told by his doctor to avoid the sun.
"That's kinda tough to do, July in the Deep South," Dispenza said, laughing.
It was five days in that sweltering heat with cameras rolling 24-7, no cloud in sight.
While he and Lead Editor Tanner Presswood filmed, Dispenza used long sleeves like protective gear and a floppy hat to ward off the sun.
Perhaps if he didn't feel a strong sense of purpose, he would have thought of his discomfort more than three times in the trip. But seeing through the lens of time how racism was a way of life for many, which seemed like a different universe to him, busied him in a beneficial way.
They went to sites like the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, where on Sunday, September 15, 1963, at 10:22 a.m., the church became known around the world when a bomb exploded, killing four young girls attending Sunday School.
Eastern Shore girls the age of those victims read that and marveled.
"How can someone hate someone so much that they could hurt them and have no consideration in their heart?" Love Jackson asked.
As they ascended the steps to the upper part of the church they witnessed a reenactment of Reverend Martin Luther King Jr.
Overcome by the strong feelings standing where King stood, Pastor of the Presbyterian Church in Chestertown Joel Tolbert opened up.
"I sit in the pulpit every Sunday. But I tried to stand in that pulpit...it's a hard space," he acknowledged.
The emotions would heighten.
Just down the road there were statues of attack dogs, replicas of what Black people faced in 1963. There was a statue of children against the wall in a firing line and statues of enslaved people in chains, heads down in despair.
Broadcasted at the The National Memorial for Peace and Justice were some of the reasons they were lynched, horrific in their simplicity and ignorance.
One was lynched for not tipping his hat to the police officer.
Another to yield a better return in the sharecropping business.
There was one, where, since a man could not be found, his 2-year-old daughter was lynched in his place.
The group journeyed to Selma. At the Edmund Pettus Bridge, they crossed as others did in 1965, knowing that beatings, dogs and water hoses waited for them on the other side.
Founder of Minary's Dream Alliance, Doncella Wilson, felt that weight. Crossing the same bridge that 600 Civil Rights marchers crossed, she had to stop in the middle and reflect, before walking on., head high.
The camera captured the moment.
Inside the Equal Justice Initiative Museum while delivering the soil as an addition to the Legacy Museum, Dispenza broke down himself.
He sat on the floor and cried, having taken some ownership of the atrocities committed. But through that pain and despair, the tears and sorrow, shone hope.
"People were not afraid to be vulnerable," Dispenza said. "It led to healing."
They were receptive to the filming process too, seeing it as a tool to do good. "It was a tough film but a beautiful film," Dispenza said.
And the results of the film did not leave people in despair.
One resident leaving Decker Theatre told him the film "had given him a peace and hope he's never had before."
Throughout the film there were positive messages to the youth. Wilson told a group of children the activists they have read about and heard were no older than they were. Tue told the youths they don't know how powerful they are.
Dispenza's film echoed with its audience as well. After the debut, it has been featured at the Bill Johnson Film Festival in Indiana.
Tue, who was with them through the entire trip, was amazed at how the footage was compiled altogether.
He told Dispenza, "My God, this is going places!"
With eight or nine screenings already having taken place, he was certainly not wrong.
Dispenza sees this as an urgent message to spread. "This conversation needs to be had as school districts try to suppress Critical Race Theory," he said.
It is a topic debated among educational groups. Dispenza is more than happy to pursue these challenges and encouraged those who have great story ideas to reach out to him at Andover Media.
For more of his projects, visit his Imdb page at imdb.com/name/nm14340956/ as well. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a documentary about civil‑rights history, lynching, and ongoing discussions of Critical Race Theory, making race and diversity the primary focus, with secondary relevance to arts/culture (the film) and education (school debates).

Paul Tue III — Program Director, Minary's Dream Alliance
Philip Dutton — Co-Chair, James Taylor Justice Coalition

title: Ceremony Honors 18 Black Union Soldiers Buried in Unionville Cemetery
author: Tom McCall
content:
Ceremony honors 18 Black Union soldiers buried in Unionville cemetery

 May 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 618
 Words 

 Read News Document

 UNIONVILLE — It was a soulful reckoning with history.Soldiers clad in Union Army uniforms filled their barrels with gunpowder and fired three rounds to mark each of the names.
The loud volleys brought the assembled crowd to a quiet reverence.
John Blackwell …
Ennels Clayton …
Isaac Copper …
John Copper …
Eighteen names. Eighteen volleys of musket fire.
The men fought for the Union. They fought for freedom. Their freedom.
The 18 were Black Union soldiers who fought in the Civil War. They are buried in the cemetery behind St. Stephens AME Church in Unionville, the town named to honor their fight for freedom.
"Hearing the names is the best part," Pamela Roberts Price said. She has relatives in the graveyard.
Around 70 people gathered at St. Stephens on a recent Sunday. There was a contingent of Union-garbed men with rifles, flags and shiny brass buckles.
The sounds of "Amazing Grace" drifted over gravestones that are worn by thousands of rainy days. A solo violin played "Taps."
St. Stephens Pastor Eddie Scott opened the ceremony with a prayer. "Comfort us in knowing that these soldiers that we stand on their shoulders, that we can have life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness."
Harriette Lowery has more than 10 relatives in the cemetery.
"I am related to one of the soldiers, definitely," she said. "Benjamin Demby is my great-great-grandfather. My grandfather's mother was Agnes Demby Green. That was Benjamin's mother."
Like Price, Lowery loves hearing the names.
"Every time I hear the names it gives me such pride," she said. "Thinking about the chaos that is happening in our community or somewhere else, thinking about what they did, what they went through really touches me."
She noted that there were no promises to these soldiers.
"They did it hoping they would be free," Lowery said. "They hoped they would get emancipation."
She noted some of the local Black soldiers traveled as far as Texas, and some of them had to walk from Texas to get home.
"I want the history to be told over and over again because not only do our young people, all races of young people, need to know what they went through," Lowery said. "They sacrificed for us to do better. So don't give up on education and things like that. They need to know what people sacrificed."
Dan Cowgill of Middletown was master of ceremonies for the event. His ancestors were Quakers who donated the land for Unionville where freed slaves settled after the Civil War.
"We are honoring the 18 soldiers from the U.S. colored troops during the Civil War that created the town of Unionville," he said. "It is amazing I still get choked up when I read these words."
The African American history within 10 miles of St. Stephens Church is remarkable. Not all of it is known or even written about. Sandy Johnson is working to change that.
"I am a budding historic preservationist," she said. "It is good to honor those that came before us. It gives us a direction to know where we are going in life. Without the past you really can't move forward."
There were white participants in the crowd whose roots go way back too. Some of their relatives had owned big estates. Some have tilled this land for generations. A few got together to swap stories and show old black and white photographs. You could hear them saying old names too.
The Green Meadows Bluegrass Band finished playing "Amazing Grace," the sounds of the music falling softly on the worn gravestones marked with the names of the Union soldiers — John Blackwell, Ennels Clayton, Isaac Copper, John Copper, Benjamin Demby, Charles Demby, William Doane, William Doran, Horace Gibson, Zachary Glasgow, Joseph Gooby, Joseph H. Johnson, Peter Johnson, Edward Jones, Enolds Money, Frederick Pipes, Henry Roberts and Mathew Roberts. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on honoring Black Union soldiers and emphasizes African American history and community remembrance, making race and diversity the primary focus.

key_people: Eddie Scott — Pastor, St. Stephens AME Church
Pamela Roberts Price — Relative of Soldiers Buried in Unionville Cemetery
Harriette Lowery — Relative of Soldiers Buried in Unionville Cemetery
Dan Cowgill — Master of Ceremonies, Unionville Ceremony
Sandy Johnson — Historic Preservationist
summary: On May 26, 2024, Pastor Eddie Scott led a ceremony at Unionville Cemetery honoring 18 Black Union soldiers buried there. Relatives Pamela Roberts Price and Harriette Lowery attended, celebrating the soldiers’ service and restoring their overlooked historic recognition.

title: Nause-Waiwash Aim to Preserve, Uncover History of Native Americans from Dorchester County
author: Konner Metz
content:
Nause-Waiwash aim to preserve, uncover history of Native Americans from Dorchester County

 August 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 567
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Since 1989, the Nause-Waiwash Band of Indians have preserved, honored and passed down the stories of their ancestors, many of whom were Nanticoke people living along the Choptank River.Chief Donna Wolf Mother Abbott is the band's leader. The group preserves the tradition of the indigenous people who fled in the 1700s to the marshes after being converged on by foreign settlers.
Abbott's passion for exploring the county's native history began when she enrolled in the Nause-Waiwash around 20 years ago, though she wasn't always dead set on joining.
"There were probably two, three, maybe four generations that were brought up believing that it was disgraceful to claim your heritage, so they didn't teach it to their children," Abbott said. "And my grandmother was one of those."
Abbott's cousins convinced her to enroll around 10 years before she became the band's second chief in 2014, following the death of former Chief Sewell Winterhawk Fitzhugh.
"They brought up a very good point, and that was, 'If you don't (join), how are we going to preserve the history?'" Abbott recalled her cousins telling her. "'Because it's fading, it's dying quickly. And what are you going to tell your grandchildren?'"
The Nause-Waiwash is made up of around 300 descendants of not just the Nanticoke, but Choptank and Pocomoke people as well. Nause was a Nanticoke village outside of Vienna and Waiwash a Choptank village outside of Cambridge, Abbott said.
It's a "matrilineal society," one where the women hold the power to elect a chief and make important decisions. At meetings, the nonprofit organization plans upcoming events and collaborations with other tribes in the state, along with discussing heritage and history.
Two churches — Hughes African Methodist Episcopal Chapel near Cambridge and Wesley Chapel south of Cambridge in Andrews — are being renovated so the Nause-Waiwash can provide services and have a resource center. The organization is hosting its 32nd annual Native American Festival on Sept. 14 in Vienna.
Such outreach events are meant to educate people on the history of who occupied Dorchester land, but also how Native Americans treated the land and surrounding waters.
UNCOVERING HISTORYDespite living on the Western Shore, Erin Kennedy, a member of the Nause-Waiwash, often combs through records and land deeds in and around Taylor's Island, the community in which she grew up, hoping to piece together her mother's side of the family.
She took inspiration from her uncle, who created a family tree for her father's side of the family.
Online resources, records from the Maryland State Archives and discussions with fellow indigenous descendants on the Eastern Shore have helped Kennedy and other members of the Nause-Waiwash understand their line of ancestors.
Abbott emphasized that she's learning every day as well. She's uncertain if permanent state recognition is in the Nause-Waiwash's future given that it's not quite as large as other tribes. However, recent recognitions such as a historical roadside marker next to the Choptank River have raised the prominence of the dedicated nonprofit's work.
Nearly 10 years in, Abbott is developing a love and commitment to the work of the Nause-Waiwash.
"I have this passion for it, which I never really knew I had until I became involved," Abbott said. "And I do know that a lot of our history is gone. I want to read all these books and see if I can't find some new information out that I don't know. So I'm reading books that I'd never thought I'd ever read before." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a Native American tribe preserving and sharing its heritage, addressing historical marginalization and cultural identity, which aligns most closely with the Race & Diversity topic.

key_people: Donna Wolf Mother Abbott — Chief, Nause-Waiwash Band of Indians
Erin Kennedy — Member, Nause-Waiwash Band of Indians
Sewell Winterhawk Fitzhugh — Former Chief, Nause-Waiwash Band of Indians
summary: On Aug. 10, 2024, Nause‑Waiwash Band of Indians, led by Chief Donna Wolf Mother Abbott, member Erin Kennedy, and former chief Sewell Winterhawk Fitzhugh, partnered with the Maryland State Archives to collect, preserve, and publish Dorchester County Native American histories, aiming to safeguard cultural heritage and educate the public.

title: Rabbi Hyman Delivers Multicultural Understanding
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Rabbi Hyman delivers multicultural understanding

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: News 
 
 705
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Easton has been and is blessed with an extraordinarily number of exceptionally talented individuals engaged in a wide range of community service endeavors.One of them is Rabbi Peter Hyman DD (Doctor of Divinity) who is retiring in October after serving 18 years as the first full-time rabbi at Easton's Temple B'nai Israel.
Rabbi Hyman has a long history in walking his talk on promoting greater understanding of and respect for individuals with different religious beliefs and different faith journeys.
There is no more enduring symbol of Rabbi Hyman's commitment to respect for other religious beliefs than a Persian rug he bought in Israel 40 years ago. It is now on display in his office. That rug includes 99 names of God in Arabic. Rabbi Hyman views it as a metaphorical bridge connecting people of different faiths.
He once asked the leaders of a mosque if they could help him translate some of the Arabic words on his rug. They did so, amazed that such an inclusive rug was owned and displayed by a rabbi.
For Rabbi Hyman, it was simply his belief that "building relationships not only creates friendships, but they also cement ties."
A partial list of his local efforts to improve the quality of life in our community and beyond, includes serving as a member, program vice president and president of the Talbot Association of Clergy and Laity. He received an Award of Appreciation for Outstanding and Inspiring Interfaith Work in Talbot County for a Temple B'nai Israel February Lecture Series: "Introduction to Islam."
He was a recipient of the NAACP Dorothy Webb Black Community Service Legacy Award and a recipient of a Governor William Donald Schaefer Helping People Award. He was a member of The Frederick Douglass Celebration Committee and delivered the sermon at the Community Interfaith Worship Celebration, which was a part of the "Douglass Returns" statue dedication.
An author and teacher, he served as a presenter and instructor at Chesapeake College's Institute for Adult Learning and collaborated with Bishop Joel Marcus Johnson to launch a "Downtown Lunch and Learn" program. He was elected to the board of directors at the YMCA of the Chesapeake and appointed chair of the board at the Easton YMCA.
Support for Scouting has been a huge part of Rabbi Hyman's life since he earned his Eagle Scout award, as did his two sons. That is an achievement that has been earned by only 6% of all Scouts since 1912.
He has served as a scoutmaster and a chaplain at Scout World Jamborees in Thailand, England, Sweden and Japan and a National Jamboree in the United States. He was the first national chair for the Messengers of Peace Program, BSA, after having served as a national chair of the Jewish Committee on Scouting and as national Jewish chaplain — Boy Scouts of America. He was the keynote speaker at a national annual meeting of the BSA "Duty to God Breakfast" in Washington, D.C.
He is a recipient of the Silver Buffalo Award for distinguished service to youth awarded by the National Council of Boy Scouts of America. He is also a recipient of the Bronze Wolf Award, which is the Scouts' highest honor. It is presented by the World Scout Committee to recognize the service, commitment and contributions of volunteers to the Scout movement. Not surprisingly Hyman received the award for his interfaith activities and his lifelong commitment to "building bridges between people and nations."
Rabbi Hyman represented the BSA in Saudi Arabia at Saudi Nation Day when they received an award for the work of the BSA with the Messengers of Peace Program. This program promotes service projects through social media in effort to achieve world peace.
Hyman recalls that trip as the most amazing experience of his life because he was welcome in a Muslim country.
While the news of Rabbi Hyman's impending retirement is bittersweet, there is some good news.
He is not planning to leave the Eastern Shore.
Whether he stays here for the short term or long term, one thing is certain. He has made countless selfless contributions to help make Easton, Talbot County, and our world a better place.
Each one of them has earned Rabbi Hyman a well-deserved thank you and Godspeed.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant based in Easton. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Frederick Douglass Day Continues to Share Abolitionist's Legacy
author: Wendy Weitzel wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
Frederick Douglass Day continues to share abolitionist's legacy

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Wendy Weitzel wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 577
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The first time Harriette Lowery heard that Frederick Douglass had grown up in Talbot County was when she moved back to Easton with her husband in the early 2000s.Lowery was surprised to hear of Douglass' local origins. She had grown up in Talbot County, but she had never known it was the famed abolitionist's birthplace.
"The historical society had put a notice in the paper asking for people to respond to a question — 'Is anybody interested in honoring Frederick Douglass in some way since he's our native son.' And I read that and thought, 'I knew a lot about Frederick Douglass, but I did not know he was from Talbot County,'" she said Saturday, surveying the crowd outside the Talbot County Free Library that had assembled for the annual Frederick Douglass Day celebration.
"... I was a little embarrassed by that but more interested in doing something because of that," Lowery said.
Lowery and her late husband became founding members of the Frederick Douglass Honor Society, the group that spearheaded the process of having a statue of Douglass erected on the Talbot County Court House lawn. The statue was unveiled to a crowd of thousands in June, 2011, after years of sometimes tense back-and-forth between the honor society, members of the community and local governments.
Frederick Douglass Day evolved from that unveiling ceremony in an effort to continue the honor society's mission of educating the community about Douglass.
"Since 2011, the Frederick Douglass Honor Society decided that it wanted to continue efforts to continue the legacy of Frederick Douglass," said Walter Black, another founding member of the Frederick Douglass Honor Society. "So the main thing that we concentrated on is the Frederick Douglass Day."
On Saturday, Frederick Douglass Day filled downtown Easton with a parade, a ceremony, a lecture, a children's village and a city block filled with vendors, nonprofits and live entertainment.
"The event gets bigger and better every year," said Debbi Dodson, the Frederick Douglass Day event coordinator. "More people get involved and more people attend, so that is a sign that people appreciate it and really support it."
The keynote speaker for this year's event, Keidrick Roy, said that although this was his first time visiting Talbot County, he has been working with the Frederick Douglass Honor Society for several years.
Keidrick Roy, a fellow at Harvard University, signed copies of his new book, "American Dark Age: Racial Feudalism and the Rise of Black Liberalism," at the event. Roy said Douglass is heavily featured in the work.
"I've always wanted to be in the place where Frederick Douglass walked and talked and had many of his formative experiences, so it's very special for me to be here to do this," he said. "I loved the celebration this morning, seeing so many people from different parts of the city, different parts of the town come out and honor Douglass in a variety of ways."
In holding the event every year, Lowery said the honor society hopes to ensure that all members of the community are aware of Douglass's ties to Talbot County and of how the principles of equality and freedom that Douglass espoused are still relevant today.
"What we wanted was for everybody to look at Douglass as an American hero and not an African American hero," Lowery said.
On Saturday, Lowery remarked that Talbot County had made progress toward that goal since 2011.
"We're always growing and getting better, or we should be anyway," she said. "Every year, I know that there's progress." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community event honoring Frederick Douglass, highlighting his legacy, racial equality, and African American history, making Race & Diversity the most fitting category.

key_people: Harriette Lowery — Founding Member, Frederick Douglass Honor Society
Walter Black — Founding Member, Frederick Douglass Honor Society
Debbi Dodson — Event Coordinator, Frederick Douglass Day
Keidrick Roy — Fellow, Harvard University
summary: Harriette Lowery and Walter Black, founding members of the Frederick Douglass Honor Society, led the October 2, 2024 Frederick Douglass Day at Harvard University. Event coordinator Debbi Dodson organized panels and exhibits honoring Douglass’s abolitionist legacy and promoting continued civic education.
